author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Let's make the CMO be the CMO again. 

Your CMO should be the best storyteller at your company. 

Full stop.

That's my bias, but I'm sticking with it
text:
Let's make the CMO be the CMO again. 

Your CMO should be the best storyteller at your company. 

Full stop.

That's my bias, but I'm sticking with it.

The CMO is not the CFO (crazy, right?)

The CMO should be company's best storyteller.

Is the other stuff important? Of course it is. You need metrics. You need reporting. You need data. You need so many things.

But if you don't nail the story to your market, a clear POV, and true differentiation -- none of the other stuff will matter.

And if the CMO can't get the company (internal team) excited and rallied around the company mission, how will you ever be able to get strangers (customers) onboard?

The most valuable asset in any company is its story. And the CMO must be the chief custodian of that story. 

Not a bean counter. 

Not a data wrangler. 

A storyteller.

(my opinion)

A CMO who cannot craft a compelling story - who cannot articulate a clear point of view or highlight what truly sets the company apart - will find that all the data in the world wonâ€™t move the needle.

PS. This is more important now than ever. In a world of AI slop and sameness and customers who donâ€™t actually believe your claims in marketing - you need a strong POV and great storytelling. Led by a human.

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Iâ€™m excited to share an important update about the leadership structure at Exit Five.

After two years running our business as COO, Iâ€™ve promoted Dan
text:
Iâ€™m excited to share an important update about the leadership structure at Exit Five.

After two years running our business as COO, Iâ€™ve promoted Dan Murphy to CEO. 

My role as Founder & Owner does not change; more on that in a bit. 

This promotion isnâ€™t a shift in how we operate â€” itâ€™s a recognition of the role Dan already plays in our business and a critical step in preparing us to scale and maximize our potential in the years ahead.

In the book Traction they talk about the ideal pairing between the Visionary (Founder) and the Integrator (Operator).

That describes the partnership Dan and I have well:

â€¢ Visionaries are creative, strategic, restless, full of ideas, often bald - and honestly a bit dangerous without the right counterpart. They are known to start fires and run.

â€¢ Integrators bring structure and process. They turn chaos into clarity. They run the business, manage teams, keep the trains moving, and allow the Visionary to focus where they are most valuable. Thatâ€™s exactly what Dan has done since joining two years ago.

Dan has pushed me. He challenges every late night and weekend idea. He puts out the fires that I start. He sweats every dollar we spend. And he has consistently held a higher bar for what this company can be. Even if it's sometimes annoying and I want to yell at him :) That's what we need. That's the partner you want.

Exit Five has gone from â€œDaveâ€™s cute little solo businessâ€ to a real company with real scale because of the structure, stability, and leadership he has brought to us.

His growth over the last two years â€” from VP Marketing in his last job to a true operator today â€” has been incredible to watch.

Like in baseball free agency, you get paid for the job you've already done. So this title as CEO reflects who Dan has become and what our company needs for the future. 

We have big plans for 2026, 2027, and beyond. 

I am working harder on this than I have on anything in a while and having the most fun of my career.  Splitting up the CEO and Founder roles will make us all more successful for the future.

My superpowers are vision, content, product, and strategy. Working on copy, hooks, headlines, positioning, storytelling, and training our team to do the same. 

The best role for me at Exit Five is to be editor-in-chief and raise the bar on our ideas, our content, products, and the way we show up in the market. Thatâ€™s where I can create the most value.

This move gives us the foundation we need for a more ambitious Exit Five â€” one with more impact, more innovation, and more opportunity for our team.

Please join me in congratulating Dan on a well-earned promotion to CEO of Exit Five. 

This is an amazing milestone for our little business, and I canâ€™t wait to see where we go from here.

NOTE: He started wearing the fanny pack before becoming CEO. But that's how I knew it was meant to be.

Also, this means I am now in full-time #FounderMode for those keeping score at home.

Congrats Dan!

author: Chris Walker
hook:
It's the end of an era: I've exited Refine Labs. 

Last week, I sold all my remaining shares in Refine Labs to existing shareholders and a private inv
text:
It's the end of an era: I've exited Refine Labs. 

Last week, I sold all my remaining shares in Refine Labs to existing shareholders and a private investment firm for an undisclosed amount.

This marks the close of a chapter in my life and career that I will always look back on with deep appreciation for the journey, pride in what we built, and excitement for whatâ€™s next, for both Refine Labs and me. 

When I started Refine Labs from my South Boston apartment in 2019, I had three freelance customers, no employees, and $3,000 in my bank account. No investors. No social media presence. No impressive resume. Just a vision:

-To create the place where future B2B CMOs are forged.
-To design growth systems for the most iconic and emerging brands in SaaS.
-To push the boundaries and move the industry forward.

Refine Labs became exactly that. And far more.

To the current and former Refine Labs team - thank you. You brought the vision to life with relentless excellence, care for our customers, and a commitment to innovation.

To Gaetano DiNardi - co-hosting 100+ live shows together changed the trajectory of this company and helped thousands of GTM pros level up.

To Megan Bowen - your integrity, leadership, and unwavering commitment over the past five years have been the foundation of our culture and growth. Thank you.

To everyone who attended Demand Gen Live, tuned into the podcasts, or followed the journey on LinkedIn: your support has meant so much to me. 

Iâ€™m proud of everything we accomplished together. 

Over six years, we partnered with 250+ leading SaaS companies. 

We helped forge a new wave of CMOs who are both strategists and tacticians. 

Refine Labs alumni have gone on to lead Marketing teams at top brands or build companies of their own. 

Thousands of podcast listeners used the insights to get promoted, reimagine their careers, and drive impact in their orgs.

Iâ€™m excited for the future, both for me and for Refine Labs. 

Refine Labs will continue to operate and deliver for customers as it always has, with the same team, same leadership, and same customer focus. Iâ€™ll be cheering from the sidelines.

And for me, Iâ€™m turning the page. A new chapter is beginning. Just like when Refine Labs was only a vision, Iâ€™ve started seeing something new for what the future holds and how I can contribute. Iâ€™ll share more in time.

For now, Iâ€™m just grateful.

To every team member, customer, listener, and supporterâ€”thank you. We made something really special.

The best is yet to come. Hereâ€™s to the next era.

-Chris

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
If you only read one post about marketing this week it should be this one.

We are drowning in AI slop.

But I am going to throw you a life jacket.

C
text:
If you only read one post about marketing this week it should be this one.

We are drowning in AI slop.

But I am going to throw you a life jacket.

ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude, Perplexity, this agent or that. It's all great. But here's what you really need to know about the craft of marketing.

â€¢ People do not care about your company.
â€¢ They don't care about your product and your features.
â€¢ They don't care about the new integration you just shipped.

What they care about is themselves. 

We are biologically wired to be selfish.

So: if you can talk to someone about themselves, youâ€™ll have their full attention.

Focus on helping them first.

What is the selfish benefit to them? Why should they care?

Here are five timeless principles you can think about for your customers:

1. Make Me Look Good

Whether itâ€™s to a boss, their team, or their industry, people are wired to care about status. Can you help them impress someone? Can you give them an edge? Can they copy/paste your idea and look smart in the next meeting? I remember impressing my boss when I was 23 year old marketer being asked to build a marketing plan for a product launch for the first time. I had no idea what to do, found a great resource from HubSpot blog (the OG) and used it. She was impressed.

2. Save Me Time

Time is the one thing nobody has enough of. If you can help someone do something faster, with less friction or fewer steps, that's the way. People will pay for time savings. BUT they have to believe this. Can't just be a marketing claim. You need proof. Show the receipts. The examples.

3. Make Me Money

Capitalism seems to be the best system that exists in the world. I don't make the rules I am just observing. It doesn't seem like someone has created a better way, so yes - money matters. And whether they will admit it or not, your customers want to make more money (because they are people). Whether directly or indirectly, people are tuned in to ROI. If you can help someone drive revenue, get more leads, reduce churn, or land a raise then youâ€™ve got their attention. Again though: MUST BE BELIEVABLE. So you must have PROOF.

4. Help Me Avoid Pain

We are wired to avoid pain. We'd almost always rather avoid pain than get some type of gain. No one likes to look stupid, feel behind, or get in trouble. If you can speak to something theyâ€™re secretly worried about -- a mistake, a missed goal, a clunky process -- and show a way out, theyâ€™ll lean in.

5. Help Me Reach The Next Level

Great marketing often speaks to ambition. Career growth. Mastery. Confidence. People want to feel like theyâ€™re getting better â€” at their job, in their life, as a person.

***

There's a lot of noise in marketing right now because of tech/AI, but I'm more bullish than ever on understanding the timeless principles in marketing, and that starts with understanding people.

I hope these are helpful for whatever you're working on right now.

Leave me a comment with what you'd add if you could edit my post.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
I thought thereâ€™d be a consensus on how to monetize AI by now. I was (mostly) wrong. 

With your help, I've spent the past three months investigating
text:
I thought thereâ€™d be a consensus on how to monetize AI by now. I was (mostly) wrong. 

With your help, I've spent the past three months investigating what's actually happening in SaaS & AI monetization -- not just what's making headlines. And I've collected data from more than 240 software companies.

I'm so excited to finally release the findings. See for yourself here: https://lnkd.in/ePsQJT6X

Six takeaways from the new Tremont | Growth Unhinged State of B2B Monetization report:

1. Seats & flat-rate pricing are increasingly under threat.

The rise of AI, and AI agents in particular, means value gets decoupled from customers needing to buy more seats. And the costs of delivering AI means software companies need a mechanism to protect themselves if & when AI usage spikes.

2. As AI continues to gain traction, hybrid has become the â€˜itâ€™ pricing model.

Seats and flat-rate pricing are being replaced by hybrid pricing, i.e. combinations of subscriptions and usage. Hybrid pricing is up from 27% to 41% adoption (!) in the last 12 months.

Software and AI are becoming inseparable. More than half of survey respondents said they include AI capabilities as part of their core software product offering.

3. There are a seemingly infinite number of ways to structure hybrid pricing. Choose wisely (or support multiple models).

Software founders used to tell me their pricing was inspired by Salesforce or maybe Slack. Now they tell me they were inspired by Clay. Clay's hybrid model has multiple routes to expand customers while keeping pricing (relatively) simple: more features (subscription packages) and more usage (credits).

4. Outcome-based pricing is seen as the 'holy grail'. It's still out of reach for 95% of the market.

A mere 5% said their pricing model is outcome-based right now. But 25% said they expect to have outcome-based pricing by 2028. 

5. The shift toward pricing transparency seemed inevitable. This isnâ€™t playing out.

My two cents: many software companies, especially early-stage and AI companies, don't have pricing totally figured out. And as soon as they publish pricing, it gets way harder to adjust.

6. Pricing models keep evolving. Most of the market is unprepared to keep up.

Be careful to avoid pricing â€˜no-manâ€™s landâ€™ -- this happens between $5-20M ARR when ownership often falls through the cracks.

---

Hope you enjoy the report. THANK YOU for your support ðŸ™ 
 - Kyle

PS, the full report is available at the link above. No need to comment â€œpricingâ€ for it, but youâ€™re welcome to if you want ðŸ˜­

#pricing #ai #monetization

text:
You DO NOT need to post on LinkedIn to grow and here's the proof...

In the last 90 days MOSTLY I have been commenting, not posting.

90% of those comments are just total deranged silliness. 

This trend depresses me, because it means that straight LinkedIn trolling is 12% more effective (for growth of the account, not necessarily business growth or mindshift changes---an IMPORTANT distinction) than posting useful content on a consistent basis... 

I'll get back to the valuable posting grind shortly, I have been doing a LOT of Agent 7 2.0 stuff in the background trying to vibe code my way to a GTM Engineer in a Box course / tool / product.

It's coming along, kinda well, kinda bumpy, but to everyone out there... just be someone that people find enjoyable... it works.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
This data should be such a wakeup call for GTM teams. 

Public SaaS companies ended Q1 with an estimated average gross margin-adjusted CAC payback per
text:
This data should be such a wakeup call for GTM teams. 

Public SaaS companies ended Q1 with an estimated average gross margin-adjusted CAC payback period of 57 months based on data from Jamin Ball / Clouded Judgement (link in comments). Said differently, it takes the BEST companies nearly five years to recover their sales & marketing spending. Five years!

Zero public companies ended Q1 with a CAC payback period of less than 12 months. Only five were under 24 months (Digital Ocean, AppFolio, Atlassian, Olo and Q2). Meanwhile, 24 reported either a CAC payback period above 100 months or negative net-new ARR added.

Perhaps more troubling, this isnâ€™t some extreme outlier quarter. Itâ€™s not something we can continue to blame on â€˜the macroâ€™ or external events. 

The average CAC payback period over the past twelve quarters is now 41 months. CAC payback periods havenâ€™t been healthy since Britney Spearsâ€™s conservatorship ended in 2021!

Public companies can usually afford for their GTM to be inefficient in the short-term. They have plenty of profitable legacy customers who can subsidize sales and marketing. And they can sneak in a price increase or two (or three) to squeeze even more from these folks. 

But the subsidies canâ€™t go on forever. And a reckoning could be on the horizon.

AI isnâ€™t whatâ€™s coming for software GTM jobs, at least not yet.Â The real villain is GTM inefficiency. But AI might just be what saves them.

---

Interestingly, early-stage startups are going in the opposite direction. More on that here: https://lnkd.in/eW2AgEkh

ðŸŽ For more insights on all things software GTM, don't miss Growth Unhinged -- my free weekly newsletter: https://lnkd.in/exTbjKaM

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Here are 16 timeless lessons for B2B marketers:

Forget AI. You need timeless lessons if you want to grow your career in marketing. 

Here's my list t
text:
Here are 16 timeless lessons for B2B marketers:

Forget AI. You need timeless lessons if you want to grow your career in marketing. 

Here's my list that I created based on growing my career from PR intern to CMO:

1. Forget acronyms (MQL, ABM, blah blah blah you don't need it)
2. The story is the strategy 
3. Think hard about â€œoffersâ€ 
4. Push your team past incremental thinking 
5. Get on the same page as sales 
6. Donâ€™t â€œbeâ€ finance and ops...partner with them 
7. Master internal communication 
8. Articulate the strategy 
9. Think short-and-long-term 
10. Understand what the CEO cares about 
11. Make hiring your job, not a side project 
12. Create your own momentum 
13. Your job is to get the job done 
14. But do the job first, before hiring externally 
15. Get comfortable making bets without perfect data 
16. Spend the budget (all of it, or else)

I wrote all of these lessons down and share more in detail here, if you want to grab the full deck of my 16 lessons going from PR intern to CMO, here:

tinyurl.com/3un83phe

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook: Please don't get mad about this, but here's the truth I've learned: you get freed up to do great marketing when you are not under constant pressure to
text:
Please don't get mad about this, but here's the truth I've learned: you get freed up to do great marketing when you are not under constant pressure to deliver a direct response on everything you do.

When every activity is not measured by the exact ROI of that activity... you are actually able to do good marketing.

You'll be able to do things that stand out, generate awareness, capture attention, build trust, create loyalty, and maybe for once actually get people sharing things about your brand.

Word of mouth is the most powerful thing a brand could have. But you don't get it when ringing the cash register is the desired outcome from every brand touch point.

OK, but how? 

Everyone always wants to know how. 

Because inside of the company, the CFO wants to know how much everything costs. The VP Sales is on your ass about the leads. The CEO is standing up in front of the board next week and she needs to show growth.

You have to educate people on how good marketing works.

I have a ton of product ideas; but I have no idea how design and engineering work. 

So they have to explain that stuff to me.

Same is true in marketing. I believe it is a true skill, a craft. And when deployed properly, it's a strategic growth lever for the business.

Is it not worth having a strong POV on what great marketing looks like? 

To teach your company, to earn the trust of the CEO, CFO, VP Sales, board, internal teams? 

You must be able to articulate what good looks like and why marketing is not just direct response.

Now of course the dream scenario is you find out the CEO gets marketing before you join the company and you don't have to do as much of this ... but you might not always be in that position (or have control to get that information, or know it's real, etc.)

But if you didn't think part of the job in marketing was to educate people on how good marketing works; then it might be better to switch careers and become an engineer, show up to work at 10 AM and code silently in the dark until 7 PM and go home. 

OK that little paragraph was unnecessary. Literally no reason for engineers to catch strays from my LinkedIn post on this fine Thursday.

But anyway... my point is this:

Internal marketing is the most underrated marketing channel; I did not make this rule. 

I am just giving you my observations from my career. 

I'm still doing calls weekly with CEOs and Founders advocating for marketing; they still need education.

It's part of the job.

How do you educate your peers about how marketing works? Not in a patronizing way, but explaining how customers get information, how they buy, why the long game matters?

text:
The CEO should put the Product team and Marketing team together. 

In lock step. 

To drive momentum and success for the company. 

I see so much about Sales and Marketing. 

Not enough about Product and Marketing. 

There should be a vision. And a roadmap. And regular launches. Some small. Some big. And this becomes the operating system for the company. 

You can CREATE momentum for your company by doing this. Deadlines drive actions. 

These regular launches give Marketing and Sales regular opportunities to talk to new customers. 

The CEO should be in the middle of this.

PS. If this topic lands with you and you're a CMO: we've been running a super secret group for CMOs / VP Marketing doing $25M+ ARR at Exit Five over the last few months and we're now accepting new members. Community is more important now than ever and it's all about who is in the room. We have curated the right room for you. author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
Itâ€™s been 100 days since I left VC to become a full-time solopreneur. An update on how it's going:

For context, I write a newsletter about startup gr
text:
Itâ€™s been 100 days since I left VC to become a full-time solopreneur. An update on how it's going:

For context, I write a newsletter about startup growth and monetization called Growth Unhinged. I also work with tech companies 1:1 as an advisor and consultant.

1. Y'all haven't gotten tired of me (yet). 

After 10+ years of posting on LinkedIn, I just crossed 100,000 followers (although I'm not sure how many of y'all are AI bots). The newsletter passed 500 paid subscribers in December. 

While that might sound low, itâ€™s on track to hit 6-figures in subscriber ARR this month! (For folks interested in pursuing the creator path, you donâ€™t need a massive audience to have a successful business.)

2. I'm resolving to make 2026 the year of upleveling what I'm doing.

I got tired of complaining about the limitations of Substack now that I'm more serious and finally did something about it. I switched over to beehiiv on December 31st and honestly I wish I had done it sooner (I also signed up beehiiv as a newsletter sponsor!). 

It felt like Substack stopped innovating for writers and decided to become a closed social media platform instead. Now that Iâ€™m on beehiiv Iâ€™m taking more control of the newsletter look and feel, improving deliverability, collecting better data about readers, learning what an API key is, setting up automations, and no longer paying a 10% Substack tax. Iâ€™m also excited to try some of their newest features: digital products, podcast pages, an AI website builder, and ðŸ”¥ website analytics. 

This shift will let me invest more in community, events, and personalized experiences in 2026.

You can see beehiiv for yourself here: https://lnkd.in/epTX3QBQ

3. Iâ€™m still working on more premium offers to make paid subscriptions a no brainer without alienating free readers.

My first offer: subscriber-only perks on top GTM tools, up to $37,067 in savings for only $150 per year. Next up: special in-depth reports (including an upcoming AI x GTM report) and new ways to bring the community together.

4. I'm realizing I'll probably never be satisfied. But that's what pushes me to get better.

Someone else will come up with a brilliant idea I wish I thought of (and had written about). I'll spend a bunch of time on a post that flops. Growth never feels fast enough. 

No matter how well things are going, I'll always aim higher. I'm trying to make peace with that rather than obsess over the business 24/7. (In the meantime, sorry to those who've become my de-facto business therapists!)

â€”

Read more (& subscribe to Growth Unhinged) here: https://lnkd.in/eKVdKCxR

#beehiivpartner

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
I'm on the edge and I just can't take it anymore...



Since 2020, I've been focused on building at the bleeding edge of AI and GTM as the OG GTM Engi
text:
I'm on the edge and I just can't take it anymore...



Since 2020, I've been focused on building at the bleeding edge of AI and GTM as the OG GTM Engineer...

Most of that work has been speaking to other in-the-trenches practitioners, not worrying about leaving folks behind.

Today, I'm so happy to announce that Topline Media to the world... a chance to bring some of my ideas to GTM leaders around the world and not just to those on the bleeding edge.

Some stats from the team:
1. Today it takes 8000 attempts to get 1 real customer meeting.
2. It takes dozens of meetings to close a deal.
3. And then 40 months of revenue to break even on that deal.

We need actual practices to get out of this steep decline... a media outlet that is about documenting building, not talking heads.

I'd suggest you subscribe as my goal specifically when I contribute is to translate what is happening at the bleeding edge actually building workflows (Claude Code, APIs, data workflows, PVPs, PQS, my love of vertical SaaS and why) to folks who want to experiment there.

So you'll see me talk about topics like...
1. Why ICP and TAM scoring lead you way astray, and what to do instead
2. The horizontal SaaS company thought trap, and how to escape
3. The exact steps to build a useful GTM engine from absolute 0

Fellow wonderful contributors:
Mark Roberge, Gaurav Agarwal hommiee, David Spitz, Cassie Young, MEEE, Peter Walker, LatanÃ© Conant (she/her), Kyle Lacy KYLLEE, Dave Kellogg, Amy Konary, Kyle Norton KYLLLEE AS WELL, and Craig Rosenberg YOOO.

Thanks to Sam Jacobs and Asad Zaman for having me!

If you'd like to see what's happening at the edge... I suggest you subscribe...

Subscribe to watch: https://lnkd.in/g2NQyemA
Subscribe to read: https://lnkd.in/g3sEw8Gd
Subscribe to listen: https://lnkd.in/gTZdw3kZ

hook:
Today I am pardoning all you turkeys that say Clay is expensiveâ€¦ 

Hereâ€™s how to NEVER PAY more than $800/mo for Clay.

First off an enterprise yearly
text:
Today I am pardoning all you turkeys that say Clay is expensiveâ€¦ 

Hereâ€™s how to NEVER PAY more than $800/mo for Clay.

First off an enterprise yearly subscription to Clay with CRM integration is under $9k/year and your cost is 1.5 pennies or $0.015 per credit.

This means you can enrich 600,000 companies (1 clay credit), profiles (1 clay credit), or use a great AI search model like 4o mini for you guessed itâ€¦ 1 Clay credit. And they are good all year if you pay yearly, so you donâ€™t lose Clay credits.

Not to mention formulas (free and an amazing hack), live domain checker (free), job changer signal that only charges for results not checks (so cheap).

Okay, but Jordan, what about those things that cost 20 or 40 or 100 Clay creditsâ€¦ we are spending so much.

Well this is called a convenience taxâ€¦ where your sheer laziness costs you. 

This last week I paid like $300 for an eye exam when an in-network provider would have been $0â€¦ but itâ€™s just because I didnâ€™t want to like go figure out my Byzantine eye insurance.

I paid a dumb convenience tax, but Iâ€™m not blaming the ophthalmologist, I chose to do this.

Enter Clayâ€™s API BYK program and HTTP API integration. 

The Bring Your Key API program lets you pay clay ZERO EXTRA DOLLARS and just enter in your own API key and Clay EATS THE pass through costs. 

So scraping a webpage becomes so cheap (less than 1/10th of a penny) with Zenrows. 

Or use Claygent with your own OpenAI API key and only pay for tokens, Clay gives you the scraping ON THEM.

Clay is making money hand over fist NOT because they are trying to rake people over the coals, but because no one wants to take the 1-2 hours to configure their account to save so so so much money.

So use Clay credits like points (e.g. job changers is where you get SO MUCH for your buck because you arenâ€™t charged for searches just results) and donâ€™t use Clay for mobile phone enrichment as a direct API key will work best.

Stop complaining, thereâ€™s no other tool that makes it easy to NOT pay them.

Youâ€™re just committed to spending as a way to not understand what youâ€™re buying.

And, sadly, youâ€™re doing a great job burying your head and opening up your wallet needlessly.

Contact me, Iâ€™ll teach you how to save money.

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Make phone calls OK again. 

One of the greatest crimes of remote work: having to sit in front of a screen and do video calls all day. 

Here's a perk
text:
Make phone calls OK again. 

One of the greatest crimes of remote work: having to sit in front of a screen and do video calls all day. 

Here's a perk for you to consider for your team: trade as many video calls for phone calls as you can. I'm serious. This is not a bit. We need to cut back the need to be on video, it's too much.

If we can make it a phone call, let's do that. 

More walking and talking. 

Less sitting all day, staring at the computer. 

Ride the stationary bike if it's a meeting you aren't presenting on. Whatever it is. We need to move more. 

Good for the body. Good for the brain. 

That is one thing I miss about the office - we used to walk. 

Easily 15-20k steps a day around Boston like it was nothing. Every 1:1 was a walk. Hey let's go for a walk. Taking a call on a walk. MOVE!

Everyone in the family benefits when you walk (see photo) 

Also you get way more creative ideas. Less stress. Better sleep.

Comment "WALK" and get my free course on WALKING vs. Video Calls

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: New data from 6,525 SaaS startups: Itâ€™s easier to get into Harvard or Stanford than it is to reach $25 million ARR within 10 years. Let that sink in.
text:
New data from 6,525 SaaS startups: Itâ€™s easier to get into Harvard or Stanford than it is to reach $25 million ARR within 10 years. Let that sink in.

I'm pumped to announce that I've partnered up with ChartMogul as their Analyst-in-Residence (fancy title, huh?), which means I get to dig into their ðŸ”¥ dataset on subscription metrics going back 10+ years & share it with you.

What I found: 
 - Almost half of software startups do eventually make it to $1 million ARR after theyâ€™ve started monetizing -- if theyâ€™re willing to stick around.*
 - One-in-five make it to $5 million ARR. 
 - One-in-ten make it to $10 million ARR. 

Yet just one out of every fifty startups makes it to $25 million ARR within 10 years. The odds of doing this (2.3%) are lower than getting accepted into Harvard or Stanford (3.6% acceptance rate). 

If youâ€™ve done it, I hope you take a moment to celebrate. 97.7% of your peers didnâ€™t get this far. (And that doesnâ€™t even factor in the scores of startups that never start monetizing a product in the first place!)

*Worth mentioning is that this data is based on a 10-year period, meaning it looks at companies that launched & started monetizing in 2016 or earlier. The full report will include data on more recent cohorts!

---

We're wrapping up our first deep dive report called "The odds of making it". Subscribe to Growth Unhinged if you want to be the first to see it next week: https://lnkd.in/exTbjKaM

So excited to partner with Nick Franklin, Sara Archer, Thomas Anastaselos & the whole ChartMogul crew! It's rare to find folks who like to geek out about SaaS metrics as much as I do ðŸ˜

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Do things that donâ€™t scale. Pick up the phone. Write a hand written note. Go see customers. 

Please!!! This is where the nuance lives. 

You canâ€™t ju
text:
Do things that donâ€™t scale. Pick up the phone. Write a hand written note. Go see customers. 

Please!!! This is where the nuance lives. 

You canâ€™t just get it all from recordings of calls and transcripts and recaps from your AI note taker. 

Thereâ€™s no paint by numbers playbook for building something great. 

The real insights come from conversations. 

Thereâ€™s no room for nuance on social media and ChatGPT. 

Reminded of this first hand right now. young Matthew Carnevale has done 50 sales calls with CMOs in the last 30 days. 

Heâ€™s not a sales guy! Heâ€™s the community guy!

Do you know how valuable that information has been??

Maja and I asked our communities about their favorite B2B GTM tools in 2025 inc
text:
If you're searching for GTM tech this Black Friday, start with these:

Maja and I asked our communities about their favorite B2B GTM tools in 2025 including which were "most impactful" and which are "must try". 195 software GTM leaders weighed in. (And Gemini sorted through 1,000+ open-ended responses ðŸ¤¯.)

ChatGPT topped the list of most impactful tools with 50 write-ins. They were followed by OG HubSpot (40 write-ins) and breakout unicorn Clay (30 write-ins). This list included tried-and-true tools you're probably familiar with like LinkedIn, Gong, Notion, 6sense, Canva, Figma, Apollo & ZoomInfo.

Things got more interesting on the "must try" list. GTM leaders are trying out vibecoding (Lovable - 2nd, Replit - 5th, Magic Patterns) and AI agents (n8n - 3rd, Relay.app, Dust). Folks are also on the lookout for more & better tooling for advanced GTM plays (see: Clay, Keyplay, Unify).

If the "must try" list is any indication, we're eager to graduate beyond ChatGPT to more advanced AI use cases. But 2025 is still the year of AI experimentation vs. true impact.

Read the full 2025 State of B2B GTM report here: https://lnkd.in/ea_zYUzB

---

PS: I'm working on a new Growth Unhinged perks program. Let me know your favorite GTM tools and I'll try to help you save some $$! ðŸ™

#gtm #ai #b2b

text:

LinkedIn has made me more connections than X or IG or YouTube or Facebook combined. 

Meaningful connections. 

That translate to IRL. 

Candidates. Teammates. Partners. Friends. 

Itâ€™s influenced millions in revenue. AND I don't have to worry about seeing someone get shot when I open up LinkedIn, so that's a positive too.

Also, this platform is completely free. So I have nothing to say about the algorithm. That's their choice.

An old friend of mine DMd me last week and said "I used to think it was so cringey that you posted on LinkedIn but now I get it; what a huge advantage you have."

Yep.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
What's the right go-to-market (GTM) motion for your product? I finally have data to give you a leg up â¤µï¸

Introducing the inaugural 2025 State of B2B
text:
What's the right go-to-market (GTM) motion for your product? I finally have data to give you a leg up â¤µï¸

Introducing the inaugural 2025 State of B2B GTM report. Maja Voje & I teamed up to bring you objective data into what's working in GTM right now and where is AI honestly making an impact. It's based on data from 195 B2B companies, mostly SaaS and hybrids of SaaS & AI.

Get the full report in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/ea_zYUzB

The five takeaways you need to know:

1. There are six main GTM motions in B2B. Inbound is the most popular, but not by much. 

As much as people love to hate on Outbound, don't count it out. 37% of B2B companies rely on either Outbound or an Account-Based GTM.

Intent-based outbound is the 2nd most popular channel in terms of where teams plan to increase GTM budget in 2026. Outbound! (The 1st is AI discovery.)

2. 2025 was a year of (endless) exploration. The average software company says they have 5 core GTM channels and another 5.5 GTM channel experiments.

This is, frankly, too ðŸ‘ da** ðŸ‘ many ðŸ‘ channels for a $1-10M ARR business!

3. 2026 needs to be the year of ruthless scaling.

The single best channel in terms of likelihood of having an impact surprised me: intimate events.

The first-ever GTM scorecard can help prioritize where to place your bets (see the full report ðŸ‘€).

4. Everyone uses AI, relatively few see real GTM impact.

Three-in-four GTM leaders said they have top-down pressure to adopt AI. But the impact of AI is a mixed bag. More than half (53%) said they see either no impact or limited impact from AI. 

The disillusionment was most acute around AI SDRs. In the words of one survey taker, â€œWe tried an AI SDR for six months and were unable to generate a single opportunity.â€ Ouch.

5. The new GTM tech stack is mostly ChatGPT?

Thereâ€™s been a proliferation of next-gen GTM tools. Only one, ChatGPT, is having a breakout impact.

ChatGPT was rated the #1 most impactful GTM tool with roughly 50 write-in mentions. The closest alternative was OG HubSpot, which had about 40 write-in mentions. Clay came in third with nearly 30 write-ins.

---

THANK YOU to everyone who supported the survey!! ðŸ™ðŸ™
 - Kyle & Maja 

#gtm #ai #startups

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
I decided we're not doing holidays anymore. The whole Exit Five team is grinding over Thanksgiving (I sent them Door Dash gift cards to get food).

Be
text:
I decided we're not doing holidays anymore. The whole Exit Five team is grinding over Thanksgiving (I sent them Door Dash gift cards to get food).

Because life is too short.

I know other companies are out there grinding right now. 9-9-6 is what it takes.

We ARE changing the world.

We ARE the most important company that's ever been built.

Family, friends, hobbies, health - that's all stuff that can wait.

Because right now we have a window of opportunity and we must capture it.

We must win this war.

We must go for the home run. The grand slam. The Hail Mary. 

We'll pull the goalie if we need to.

War references. 

All of them. In every internal deck.

Something about Tom Brady in his late 30s to every new hire during onboarding.

Let it be known to my competitors: I will not settle for anything less than $1B revenue and pure global dominance in the B2B marketing space.

So no, I am not taking the day off today (or tomorrow) and having "Thanksgiving" -- one day my wife and kids will be "Thankful" that I didn't.

That's my plan for Thanksgiving.

PS. Subscribe to my newsletter.

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook: I know it sucks. But you pay $0 for a LinkedIn account. You know they say that if the product is free then you are the product. Youâ€™re at the mercy of
text:
I know it sucks. But you pay $0 for a LinkedIn account. You know they say that if the product is free then you are the product. Youâ€™re at the mercy of the platform. 

Thereâ€™s a ton of posts circulating about the LinkedIn algo. But it all just changes so much. And Iâ€™m pretty confident (completely making this up, I have no idea) that no one really knows whatâ€™s going on. Thereâ€™s been - for years - some basic features LinkedIn should have built for creators but they never come, and the way vertical video works is a perfect example. It just â€¦ makes no sense. Is anyone paying attention?

SO: my two cents. The only thing you can control is putting out interesting content. Iâ€™ll never whine about the algorithm. Thereâ€™s nothing I can do about it anyway.  

But I can try harder, write better, find new angles. Iâ€™d like to think itâ€™s still a meritocracy. 

Iâ€™d also remind you that we are all renting space here, and it could all be wiped out at any time. 

Find more channels. Build an email list. Use LinkedIn to move people from here to something you can own. 

Let me know three weeks from now when you see this post. 

And remember, I am a Thought Leader.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: New data from 6,525 SaaS startups: Only 3.3% reach $1 million ARR in less than a year from first revenue. And just 1-in-1,000 reach $10 million in les
text:
New data from 6,525 SaaS startups: Only 3.3% reach $1 million ARR in less than a year from first revenue. And just 1-in-1,000 reach $10 million in less than a year ðŸ¤¯

When you listen to VCs, you get the impression that revenue growth happens at warp speed. 

I partnered with ChartMogul as their Analyst-in-Residence, which means I get to dig into their ðŸ”¥ dataset on subscription metrics going back 10+ years & share it with you.

What I found: For startups that reach $1 million ARR, it usually takes between two and five years from initial monetization. 

1ï¸âƒ£ A mere 3.3% of startups reach $1 million in under 1 year
2ï¸âƒ£ 13.4% reach $1 million in under 3 years
3ï¸âƒ£ 25.1% reach that figure within 5 years

You can map yourself onto the curve below to find the figures that are most relevant to you including $1 million and $10 million ARR milestones.

My two cents: I think this is healthy! 

It takes real time to find product-market fit (PMF) and move from founder-led sales to repeatable growth. Premature scaling can kill an otherwise great business. 

Many of the best companies go slow to go fast: (a) Lovable spent 18 months building before their breakthrough success, (b) Clay grinded for 6 years before seeing revenue traction, (c) bolt.new's parent company spent 7 years clawing their way to $700k in ARR before their new product exploded.

Check out the full deep dive report in Growth Unhinged here: https://lnkd.in/eaByfNpk

Hope you find this useful ðŸ™ 

#startups #saas #growth

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
Itâ€™s been 30 days since I left VC to become a full-time solopreneur. How itâ€™s going so far:

For context, I write a newsletter about startup growth an
text:
Itâ€™s been 30 days since I left VC to become a full-time solopreneur. How itâ€™s going so far:

For context, I write a newsletter about startup growth and monetization called Growth Unhinged. I also work with tech companies 1:1 as an advisor and consultant.

1. I thought free subscribers would stall out when I introduced a paid tier. The opposite happened.

Subscriber growth actually accelerated and the newsletter passed 80,000 this week.

2. Demand for the paid tier has been solid & the newsletter cracked the Top 100 business bestsellers on Substack! 

But about half my subscribers are on monthly plans and Iâ€™m worried about what churn could look like. I need to create more premium offers to keep folks sticking around (very open to ideas!). 

Iâ€™m also getting disillusioned with the limitations of Substack now that Iâ€™m more serious. It feels like they want to be a social media platform more than they want to create tools for creators. (Iâ€™m considering beehiiv in case folks have opinions!) 

3. I was worried about being lonely and losing motivation. So far that hasnâ€™t been an issue. 

I carve out Mondays to hang with CJ and Ben Hillman & record our new Mostly Growth pod. I carve out Wednesdays for in-person meetings in Boston. Writing happens in the morning and I try to stack advising meetings in the afternoon.

Collaborations with other creators have been a big boost. Other writers are kinda like my chosen co-workers. (Shoutout to Maja for the partnership on our first State of B2B GTM report & our constant WhatsApp messages about ðŸ•)

4. I havenâ€™t been this stressed out in a while. 

Everything falls to me. When I drop the ball I canâ€™t blame anyone else. And Iâ€™m constantly making decisions Iâ€™m not confident about.

Some of this is probably natural with trying to start a business & run a business at the same time. Some of it is self-inflicted. My main action item is getting better at saying no (Iâ€™m re-reading Lennyâ€™s great piece on this for help.)

5. My dog has never been happier or more demanding. 

When I head out for a cold brew, he expects to make a stop at the dog bakery. (How can I say no to this face?!)

â€”

So far, so good. Thanks for following along ðŸ™

PS, if you made it this far, here's a shameless plug to subscribe to the newsletter ðŸ˜: https://lnkd.in/exTbjKaM

author: Kyle Poyar

This is from Jacob
text:
Inside a marketing team with 0 marketers. It's just the founder and ~40 AI agents collectively doing the work of a 5 person team ðŸ‘€

This is from Jacob Bank, founder & CEO at Relay.app, who finally got around to putting his AI agents into an "org chart" and it's super cool to see.

I sat down with Jacob to unpack exactly how he did it â€“ and how you can do it, too. The TL;DR:

ðŸ‘‰ AI agents haveÂ spiky intelligenceÂ and can be surprisingly powerful for marketing tasks.

ðŸ‘‰ Modern teams will have hundreds of AI agents in the org chart for every one person.

ðŸ‘‰ While that sounds complex, each individual agent is much easier to build than you think.

ðŸ‘‰ Thereâ€™s power in building your own personal AI agent stack thatâ€™s specific to your goals and style of working. (This stack is also something you can bring to future roles.)

You can get the full version and templates/screenshots in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/eeDrZrdv

Check it out, then chime in: how are you using AI agents in your GTM?

hook:
THE WORST ADVICE I EVER GOT

You can choose 2 of the 3

1. Family
2. Fitness 
3. Work 

Youâ€™ll never be able to be great at all three things at the sa
text:
THE WORST ADVICE I EVER GOT

You can choose 2 of the 3

1. Family
2. Fitness 
3. Work 

Youâ€™ll never be able to be great at all three things at the same time. 

Bullshit. 

Itâ€™s bad advice because it becomes a self fulfilling prophecy. 

An excuse. 

To get out of shape because youâ€™re building a startup. 

To let relationships lapse because work is busy. 

Not to get on some woo woo here but - you can do it. 

Not everything is urgent. 

I also think it is SO important for leaders and parents to MODEL healthy behavior. 

Is it hard sometimes? Absolutely. I often want to scream and throw my phone away. Delete LinkedIn. Get rid of my emails and Slack. 

And yes. It sucks to wake up early. When itâ€™s freezing. And dark. 

But man, itâ€™s a hell of a gift to be here, to be alive, to healthy - and for what itâ€™s worth, itâ€™s usually the guy that doesnâ€™t have all 3 things I mentioned above thatâ€™s giving the advice that you canâ€™t have them all at once. 

Iâ€™ve also met so many people through work and here on LinkedIn that believe in what Iâ€™m saying here, and itâ€™s important to me to be a positive force. A magnet if you will. 

ðŸ’ª

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook: No plans to raise money right now for Exit Five but I took a call with an inbound investor anyway. The guy just (politely) shit on my business for 17
text:
No plans to raise money right now for Exit Five but I took a call with an inbound investor anyway. The guy just (politely) shit on my business for 17 minutes and then we parted ways. Awesome!

I did get 13 minutes back though. And that matters.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
CONFIRMED WITH DATA: Paid social lead gen on Facebook & LinkedIn is terribly inefficient and provides very low ROI.

The same thing Iâ€™ve been saying f
text:
CONFIRMED WITH DATA: Paid social lead gen on Facebook & LinkedIn is terribly inefficient and provides very low ROI.

The same thing Iâ€™ve been saying for 6 years, now confirmed in a MASSIVE data set.

Metadata released their second B2B advertising benchmark report and the results areâ€¦.ummmmâ€¦.not good.

But this is an absolutely groundbreaking data set for B2B companies. Especially given the scale:

$42MM in total advertising spend
236,000 total â€œleadsâ€ collected
And all of the associated downstream data for pipeline & conversion rates

Hereâ€™s the breakdown and my analysis of the data set:

1. 90% of advertising dollars were spent on lead gen campaigns ($37MM of $42MM total spend)

This is consistent with what I see in my own analyses of over 100 companies. B2B companies primarily use paid social for lead gen campaigns because of the outdated demand waterfall models & requirements for digital touchpoint-based attribution.

2. â€œDownloadâ€ was the most popular CTA indicating that B2B companies are still using paid social to drive downloads of gated PDFs (shhheeeesh!).

The average cost was $126 to get someone to maybe open the PDF.

3. Based on the data, I estimate the lead-to-win % to be 0.3%. That means Sales needs 333 â€œleadsâ€ to win 1 deal, which is terribly inefficient.

This is consistent with what I see in my own analyses - average lead-to-win rate I see is somewhere between 0.1% - 0.2%, meaning Sales needs 500-1000 paid social â€œleadsâ€ to win a deal. The Metadata report is similar and confirms these inefficiencies in a very large sample size.

4. Low cost per lead does not indicate actual success.

The average cost per â€œleadâ€ was $172 across all lead gen campaigns. But given the very very very low win rate of these leads, we estimate advertising CAC to be $57,000 to win one deal. This is just the advertising cost and doesnâ€™t include Sales headcount, SDRs, marketing headcount, or other marketing programs such as events.Â Itâ€™s safe to say this performance is totally unacceptable.

5. Estimated advertising CAC payback period is estimated to be 21 months.

$38MM in total advertising spend on lead gen campaigns resulting in $22MM in closed won revenue.

This is just the advertising cost and doesnâ€™t include Sales headcount, SDRs, marketing headcount, or other marketing programs such as events. When you include all the other expenditures, you could reasonably estimate the total CAC payback on these programs is more than 48 months (meaning it takes 4 years just to pay back the cost of acquiring the customer, not adjusted for gross margin)

____

There is FINALLY sufficient data to say definitively that almost all B2B companies should STOP running lead gen campaigns on LinkedIn & Facebook.

#marketing #advertising #linkedin #b2b

p.s. This is in no way meant to be misconstrued as a knock on Metadata. They published a public data set and Iâ€™m providing my expert analysis of the data, specifically related to lead gen campaigns on paid social channels.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Hereâ€™s how our 3-person Marketing team puts out more content every day than most $100MM companies put out in a month:

1. Commit

You must be committe
text:
Hereâ€™s how our 3-person Marketing team puts out more content every day than most $100MM companies put out in a month:

1. Commit

You must be committed to executing on the right activities for a sustained period of time. Most companies fail at this because they do 3 podcasts & give up when they donâ€™t get any â€œleadsâ€.

2. Identify Your Subject Matter Expert(s)

Provide forward-thinking, relevant information that your buyers *want*. Most B2B marketing content doesnâ€™t hit because the person creating the content isn't an expert and doesnâ€™t deeply understand the buyer.

3. Content Creation Framework

Put pillars in the ground that help you create content on a recurring basis. Example: we host Tik Tok Live every Tuesday and bi-weekly live Revenue Strategy events. These pillars create raw content. We have 3 total recurring pillars.

4. Post-Production framework

Create a framework to *quickly* edit raw long-form content & optimize it for each distribution channel. We publish recorded content within 24 hours, while big companies take 3 months to do the same thing.

5. *Effective* Multi-Channel Distribution

Content makes ZERO impact if your buyers donâ€™t *consume* it. You must spend a lot of time in the DETAILS on each channel listening & engaging.

__

Strategize -> Create -> Post-Produce -> Distribute -> Listen -> Repeat

#marketingÂ #b2bÂ #demandÂ #gtmÂ #content

Bonus: Use Hatch for the best quality and most cost-efficient post-production framework to take your raw video content assets and optimize them for distribution across every dark social channel (LinkedIn, Podcast, YouTube, Tik Tok, Instagram, and more) âœŒï¸

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Whatâ€™s seen as glamorous and impressive on this platform will be known as toxic and destructive within 10 years.Â  

Things that are celebrated on this
text:
Whatâ€™s seen as glamorous and impressive on this platform will be known as toxic and destructive within 10 years.Â  

Things that are celebrated on this platform as â€œimpressiveâ€:

-Raising tons of money
-Hacking the algorithm for likes and followersÂ 
-Bragging about your MRR or metrics to look â€œsuccessfulâ€Â 
-Pretending to be generous by giving away your e-book or AI workflow when youâ€™re actually manipulating peopleÂ 
-Grinding for 80+ hours a week chasing external validation
-Getting rich while bankrupting your health, relationships, creativity, and peace of mind

Things that are actually impressive: 

-Showing up with pure intentions
-Waking up every day and genuinely loving your lifeÂ 
-Holding empowering beliefs about yourself and othersÂ 
-Knowing who you are and following that authenticallyÂ 
-Doing â€œworkâ€ that fuels you instead of drains youÂ 
-Building on your terms, from clarity instead of control and urgency
-Trusting your intuition and doing whatâ€™s right for you 

__

In the 1950s, cigarettes were seen as stylish and glamorous. Every Hollywood star and celebrity was lighting up. Now we know better.

The things this platform celebrates as glamorous are just as destructive, but now itâ€™s your mental health, your purpose, and your freedom that are at risk.

I had to learn these lessons the hard way. You donâ€™t have to. 

Donâ€™t mistake whatâ€™s â€œpopularâ€ for whatâ€™s right.

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Here are the top AI tools for marketers right now

Personally, my list only has ONE tool and it's because 99.9% of my time is spent with my friend Cha
text:
Here are the top AI tools for marketers right now

Personally, my list only has ONE tool and it's because 99.9% of my time is spent with my friend ChatGPT. Just strolling through the woods in Vermont talking to my little robot. I know, I know.

But we happen to run the top community for a huge group of marketing professionals, so I took to the streets (aka the message boards) to ask the Exit Five community their most used AI tools right now.

No affiliations with any of these companies, not getting paid to post this; truly a finger on the pulse type of thing - here are the 15 tools that come up the most in Exit Five right now.

1. ChatGPT / Custom GPTs

The catch-all workhorse. Campaign names. Research. Outlines. Internal playbooks.Â If you havenâ€™t already: build a brand-trained GPT that gives you 20 campaign name options in seconds. Helps me go from 0 to 1 faster. Get the bad ideas out of the system.

2. Claude

They say it's better for long documents and repurposing. Drop in your last year of content and get a pattern analysis you definitely werenâ€™t going to do manually. I just like the name. Claude.

3. Canva Magic Studio

Canva rocks. When you need designer-level outputâ€¦ without a designer. Spin up carousels, ads, and visuals in minutes. Even makes me look good.

4. Descript

Edit video like a doc. Cut filler. Pull clips. Export. Done in a fraction of the time.

5. Perplexity

Your research intern. Competitor tracking. Trend scans. Summary + sources.
Great when someone Slacks you â€œquick questionâ€ and you need to look prepared. Do you all like this better than Google? Than ChatGPT? It's different? How

6. SurferSEO

SEO briefs and optimization that make ranking feel less like a gamble. Great name btw.

7. Ahrefs + Frase

Find old posts losing traffic. Patch the gaps. Win back rankings.

8. Make

Lead routing and follow-up workflows that run while you sleep.

9. Zapier (+ Agents)

Reporting, notifications, cross-tool workflows. Everything that used to require ops help.

10. Clay

List building and enrichment on autopilot.
Find contacts. Pull data. Build prospect lists that would've taken days.

11. ElevenLabs

Voice cloning for audio versions of your content. You type. â€œYouâ€ talks. I want to use this for our podcast ads but I think the real mean sounds more authentic?

12. Vercel V0

Landing pages that practically build themselves, with auto A/B tests baked in.

13. Flourish

Data visuals and interactive maps that make your spreadsheet look like a crime scene. Uh. OK? Is that a good thing?

14. GenSpark

Upload data. Get insights and a deck. No more begging for analytics support.

15. NotebookLM

Drop in transcripts, internal docs, and case studies. Get messaging ideas, customer language, objections, topics - all from your own data.

Leave me a comment if you have a favorite tool on this list (or a use case we didnâ€™t put down here or want to answer one of my Qs)

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Remote work requires an incredible amount of discipline. Not for everyone.

I think that the "back to the office" crowd often has a narrative that rem
text:
Remote work requires an incredible amount of discipline. Not for everyone.

I think that the "back to the office" crowd often has a narrative that remote work is easier.

That remote workers are slacking off while the "real professionals" are grinding it out in the office.

But I think there's another angle to this:

Working from home exposes everything. No boss watching over your shoulder. No colleague pressure. No artificial energy from office chaos. Heck, you could be ripping the vape pen all day at work if you wanted to.

Remote work makes it more about the results (and I like that, btw)

You can't hide behind being the office social butterfly who everyone loves but whose output is average. Maybe you're fun, funny, amazing to get a coffee with - but not actually doing any real work??

Remote you can't mask weak skills with great small talk or being the person who always organizes the lunch order. But he's so nice! So fun to be around! 

Well as it turns out Todd sucks at his job...

Remote work kills the performance theater, which was always one of my biggest beefs of office culture.

Don't get me wrong - there's value in being together. I feel it every time we get our team together and there are times that I wish we all DID work together in an office.

But let's be honest about what also happens in offices: 

â€¢ People spending three hours looking busy instead of productive. 
â€¢ People hang around the office until a certain time vs going home when the work is done for the day
â€¢ People getting promoted (or hanging around at a company longer than they should) because they're likable, not because they are delivering results.

The truth? Both can work. But they demand different skills.

Remote rewards discipline. Focus. I need to take a shower and put on real clothes to remind myself that this is work - even though it's remote.

I don't think the remote work is for everyone. 

It requires a certain level of self starter, get shit done, can you show up and make things happen on a day when you don't have any motivation.

Editor's Note: I am also extremely biased toward remote work during this phase of my life (in my 30s, with young kids, etc.) 

The office was the absolute best place to be in my 20s and I am sure a few years from now when my kids don't need me as much and aren't around as much, I'll be making my way back to an office of some kind.

Remote work. With great power (the ability to work remotely, be flexible) comes great responsibility.

author: Chris Walker
hook: In early 2019, I started calling out how badly the â€œlead genâ€ Marketing model was working. Tons of smart, experienced people argued with me and told m
text:
In early 2019, I started calling out how badly the â€œlead genâ€ Marketing model was working. Tons of smart, experienced people argued with me and told me I was an idiot. 

5 years later, itâ€™s common knowledge that most high-volume lead gen Marketing models are ineffective, inefficient, and not financially viable. 

I knew for sure it wasnâ€™t working because I had analyzed 20+ B2B companyâ€™s CRM data and saw the same consistent pattern at every one:

1. 90%+ of Marketing program budgets spent on Lead Generation strategiesÂ 
2. Marketing gets thousands of MQLs and celebrates $100 cost per â€œleadâ€Â 
3. â€œLeadsâ€ convert to customers at 0.1%Â 
4. 1,000 SDR follow up cadences to Close 1 dealÂ 
5. 5-10+ year CAC payback periods 

IT WAS OBVIOUS. 

But nobody had taken the time and critical thinking to look at the data this way across a broad range of companies to see the clear, obvious pattern. 

It took YEARS for smart people to understand the nuances of my message. Thousands of people changed their careers and lives by recognizing the opportunity early and taking action. Others lagged behind for years. And now 5 years later everyone sees it as common knowledge.

____

And at this moment right now, the same thing is happening. 

At Passetto, weâ€™ve analyzed 50+ B2B companies' CRM, revenue, and financial data. 

The traditional GTM model is broken - super inefficient and entirely unsustainable. But the METRICS companies use blind them to this reality. And the METRICS companies use unknowingly keep them handcuffed to this broken model - decimating growth rate, GTM Efficiency, and enterprise value creation. 

And again, smart, experienced people are criticizing my message and disparaging me for it without taking the 30 minutes to understand my message and all of the supporting data. 

ITâ€™S OBVIOUS. 

The only way to fix it is to change the GTM KPI stack and the Financial Planning process. Which then drives organizational alignment, investment allocation, and department-level accountability downstream. 

Iâ€™ve seen this story before. 

Maybe it will take 6 months, 12 months, or a few years for everyone to see this reality. But in a few short years, this will also be common knowledge :) 

#finance #b2b #gtm #gotomarket #marketing

author: Chris Walker
hook:
B2B Companies have been talking about Sales & Marketing misalignment for more than a decade. Theyâ€™ve tried to solve it with:

-Changing marketing goal
text:
B2B Companies have been talking about Sales & Marketing misalignment for more than a decade. Theyâ€™ve tried to solve it with:

-Changing marketing goals from MQLs to SQLs (didnâ€™t work)
-Putting a Chief Revenue Officer in charge of Marketing (didnâ€™t work) 
-Having a weekly pipeline meeting (didnâ€™t work)
-Buying an ABM platform (didnâ€™t work) 

B2B companies always try to fix GTM at tactical execution (letâ€™s hire a new growth marketer to do SEO for us) or tech & tools (letâ€™s buy an ABM platform and change from MQLs to MQAs). 

They do this because itâ€™s easy but it doesnâ€™t solve the real problem. Itâ€™s superficial & visible. Itâ€™s easy to report back to the board in a powerpoint slide about a new tool or a new tactic.

But the real root cause of these issues is so much more fundamental. Itâ€™s deeply rooted & invisible.

The real root cause is the operating model & data model that companies consciously or subconsciously adopt that drives the mindset of executives, investors, and GTM teams, and influences every decision they make.

Lead -> MQL/MQA -> SAL -> SQL -> SQO -> Closed Won

And here are the core issues:

1. Operates in an assembly line of siloâ€™d departments instead of an allbound integrated revenue team.

2. Evaluation of the ROI and Impact of investments are made in silos by each department (Marketing, Sales, SDRs) instead of within a Unified GTM model.

3. There are no commonly accepted KPIs and "attribution" strategies for Demand Creation, so the entire GTM team doesn't focus or invest here, leaving the entire GTM engine highly imbalanced & inefficient.

4. Most companies use a model that was created between 2012 and 2017, despite how much has changed in the world in the past 6 years.

5. Marketing is optimizing for MQLs/MQAs or a poor definition of â€œpipelineâ€ that doesnâ€™t align to close won revenue. The data is clear in every Salesforce instance that core Marketing KPIs donâ€™t align to closed won revenue, sales velocity, and marketing ROI. 

6. SDRs optimize for SQLs or meetings, not closed won revenue. 

7. All of the technology, tools, and tactical â€œbest practicesâ€ are built around getting leads, MQLs/MQAs, and SQLs, further entrenching companies getting stuck in the model. 

8. GTM teams are stuck in the incremental. How do we improve our outbound connect rates by 1%? How do we reduce our cost per lead by $3? There are no breakthroughs in growth with incremental improvements. Optimizing a broken model is not the solution, itâ€™s changing the model. 

9. No standardized data model so every company reinvents the wheel in RevOps w/o clear, performance-based definitions. Everybody on the GTM team is looking at different metrics & decisions are based on experiences and opinion instead of science & data. 

__

When you are putting together your 2024 plan, use these ideas as a guide. Clearly identify the core issue(s) that are holding you back. Create a solution that actually solves the root cause, instead of treating the symptoms.

#b2b #gtm #revops

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Itâ€™s been 90 days since Iâ€™ve had a drink of alcohol, and I feel superhuman. 

Iâ€™ve tracked my performance and habits for more than 5 years using WHOOP
text:
Itâ€™s been 90 days since Iâ€™ve had a drink of alcohol, and I feel superhuman. 

Iâ€™ve tracked my performance and habits for more than 5 years using WHOOP and in my data itâ€™s super clear:

Alcohol is one of the worst things you can do to limit your performance - both physically and mentally. 

Thereâ€™s a shift happening in Austin, TX and Iâ€™m sure itâ€™s happening in other parts of the World as well, where lots of people are choosing to abstain from alcohol. 

Thereâ€™s starting to be less of a negative stigma around not drinking alcohol, thankfully. It's crazy that for so long it's been socially weird to *not* drink alcohol, despite the clear, obvious data about the negative effects. 

In the business World and in lots of B2B companies Iâ€™ve worked at before, â€œCultureâ€ revolves around alcohol. 

Letâ€™s get everyone drunk at Sales Kickoff so people can bond. 

Letâ€™s have a networking event at a bar. 

Letâ€™s do a happy hour for business development. 

Letâ€™s all go out to the club in Vegas and then be hungover in the tradeshow booth all day tomorrow. 

Hopefully more companies and the business World at large start to shift away from this outdated social norm. 

__

I'm not sure this is a forever thing for me, but it's definitely working for me right now. 

When I make changes in my life and start to feel a lot of positive momentum, I always keep it going. 

Lots of people say the positive effects continue to grow the longer you abstain from alcohol. I'll continue to report back on my own personal experience. 

Anyone else trying this? Seeing this shift? What's been your experience? 

It feels like this is a topic we need more on LinkedIn and in business generally. 

#b2b #alcohol #whoop #performance 

p.s. soda water with lime tastes just as good as a tequila soda lime ðŸ™‚

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Unpopular Opinion: You can clearly determine how well your Marketing is "working" without ever looking at attribution. 

And the way to get there is b
text:
Unpopular Opinion: You can clearly determine how well your Marketing is "working" without ever looking at attribution. 

And the way to get there is by focusing on *business KPIs* 

TTM Growth Rate %
GTM Efficiency % 
Total Pipeline Created
Total Investment to Create Pipe 
Pipeline Opp Win Rate 
Investments to Create Pipe : Total Pipe Created

And boom: you'll get a clear picture that aligns everyone in GTM on the current performance and historical trends. 

Example $100MM ARR SaaS Company:

Growth rate: 24% (decent growth)
GTM Efficiency: 428% (highly inefficient)
Total Pipe Created: $48MM
Total Investment to Create Pipe: $27.6MM
Pipeline Opp Win Rate: 8% (down from 12% YoY)
Pipeline:Spend Ratio : $1.74 (really bad) 

You don't need to build a multi-touch attribution report. Or split the credit between "Inbound" and "Outbound". Or debate how much "brand value" is created from all the trade show booths. None of it. 

This performance is abysmal and unsustainable. If continued for several more years, this company will undoubtedly crash and burn. Alarms should have been going off at the Exec level and Board level for the past 4+ quarters. 

Yet, the Marketing QBR reports show increasing MQL performance, great cost/MQL, and an overly complicated influenced revenue report that shows how well everything is working (yet nobody really understands). 

All of the Marketing reports are built by Managers and Directors who have little to no visibility into the broader business context - that growth is slowing and CAC has inflated by almost 3X in the past 6 quarters. 

__

As a Finance or GTM Executive, you cannot rely on bottoms-up department-level reporting to build and optimize your GTM. Instead, you *must*:

1. Align on a Unified set of GTM KPIs that don't rely on attribution 
2. Start with Investor Level & Financial Level KPIs, particularly growth rate and GTM Efficiency % 
3. Break the investments and performance down across the customer lifecycle (not by the GL / Dept code) 
4. Analyze the performance, historical trends, and unit economics across each core phase of the customer lifecycle. 
5. Rapidly identify the biggest issues and opportunities to unlock growth and ROI.
6. Map and track strategic priorities against BUSINESS KPIs (not attribution)

Then, with all of this BUSINESS CONTEXT. You can start to run custom diagnostics with W-shaped attribution, or linear, or signal-based, or sliced by GEO / segment / vertical or anything else to answer specific questions you have based on the business KPIs. 

Always look at attribution data with a purpose based on business-level KPIs. 

#finance #b2b #sales #marketing #gtm

__

p.s. I know some people will misinterpret this message, so I'm proactively clarifying: I've never told people not to use attribution tools. Instead, I've always been vocal and communicated the clear patterns of problems B2B companies run into based on how they use these tools and data. It's a process problem, not a technology problem.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
What it means to shift from 'spray-and-pray' marketing to a unified, account-based GTM aimed at your exact ICP â¤µ

Last September I featured a story ab
text:
What it means to shift from 'spray-and-pray' marketing to a unified, account-based GTM aimed at your exact ICP â¤µ

Last September I featured a story about how Parabola did all this (a) in under 30 days, (b) without a RevOps team, and (c) with a TON of ðŸ”¥ automation. 

Hereâ€™s the update: pipeline has grown by 717% since September. All with the same size marketing team ðŸ¤¯ 

How they rapidly built a scaled ABX motion from scratch:

1ï¸âƒ£ Identified

- ICP-fit accounts & contacts are sourced using Clay, Sales Nav, Cargo ðŸ§± and ChatGPT
- All data gets pushed to Salesforce

2ï¸âƒ£ Aware

- Accounts get warmed up with LinkedIn paid ads, scaled email, LinkedIn connections and referrals â€“ in addition to other bespoke tactics and campaigns
- They are flagged as aware if buyers start engaging via email (2+ contacts with 2+ email opens), accept LinkedIn connections, visit the website, or engage in the community
- Tools: website tracking (Clearbit, HubSpot), email & LinkedIn automation (Apollo, Outreach, La Growth Machine), community (Slack)

3ï¸âƒ£ Interested

- Accounts progress as they demonstrate more meaningful engagement & intent
- Key signals include visiting high-intent website pages (ex: pricing page), starting a free trial, attending an event, etc.
- Tools: webinar (Sequel.io), trial (Redshift), website tracking, product usage data, ETL

4ï¸âƒ£ Evaluating

- All of the above is meant to generate high intent, ICP pipeline for sales
- Accounts progress here by booking a meeting with sales or requesting a demo
- This is where more manual, high-touch outreach comes into play (aimed at warm accounts)
- Tools: meeting routing & booking (Calendly), marketing automation (HubSpot)

The big learnings over the past 8 months:
Â - Content & offers are everything for getting a response
Â - Not all triggers are created equal when scoring account stages
Â - The data wonâ€™t be perfect, donâ€™t let that stop you
Â - The best GTM plays involve both marketing & BDRs

This is what a focused GTM looks like. Marketing, sales, CS, product and even ops all play a role in building pipeline with the right accounts. Huge shoutout to the Parabola team (Alex Yaseen, Ben Pollack, Adam Reisfield) for taking folks behind-the-scenes!

PS, Parabola just launched a game-changer for anyone interested in automating workflows like ABX stages (think Cursor for Ops teams). You can check it out here: https://parabola.io/

#abx #marketing #automation

author: Chris Walker
hook: â€œWe donâ€™t use agencies or consultants because I had a bad experience with one several years agoâ€. Thatâ€™s what a Director of RevOps told me yesterday.
text:
â€œWe donâ€™t use agencies or consultants because I had a bad experience with one several years agoâ€. Thatâ€™s what a Director of RevOps told me yesterday. 

Itâ€™s like saying youâ€™re never going to a restaurant again because one time you had a bad meal. 

I used to think the same way when I was young, naive and inexperienced. I took so much pride in thinking I knew everything and could do it all myself. 

But then in 2013, despite me arguing against it, the company I worked for hired a Strategic Marketing Consultant named Andy and it fundamentally changed my career. 

Andy taught me all the really important things about Marketing that most people donâ€™t talk about - how to conduct customer interviews, how to create a business case, how to run a beta trial, how to build a differentiated strategy using product, price, distribution, and promotion all together. 

Then again in 2017, the company I worked for hired a Category Design Consultant named Robin who taught me everything about category design, positioning, narrative design and strategic communications. 

Then again in 2018, the company I worked for hired a Creative & Branding agency who totally transformed our website, sales decks, and advertising assets and taught me everything I know about the creative process and how much it matters in properly communicating your message to the market. 

A lot of my skills, experience, and success in entrepreneurship can be directly attributed to these experiences working with external experts that taught me specialized knowledge, processes, and ways of thinking. 

___

External experts (agencies, consultants, fractionals, etc.) have distinct advantages that simply canâ€™t be replicated by in-house employees:

-Theyâ€™ve worked with hundreds or thousands of companies to solve the same problemÂ 
-Theyâ€™ve developed processes, automation, and other forms of intellectual property that accelerate projects and initiativesÂ 
-Theyâ€™ve seen some companies succeed and clearly know what "success" looks like and what it takes
-They've seen many companies fail and know how to help you avoid common mistakes and missteps. 

Not leveraging external experts to complement the skills of your in-house team, accelerate key strategic initiatives, avoid common missteps, and help you identify internal blindspots is simply not smart and is based on a false sense of ego and pride.

I know because I thought that way for a long time and now realize how naive and misguided my thinking was. 

Not using external experts just because you had one bad experience with one is like saying youâ€™re never going to a restaurant again because you had one bad meal. 

Restaurants donâ€™t all suck - you just picked a bad one. 

Pick a better restaurant next time. Or be naive and prideful trying to cook all the meals by yourself - eat a bunch of poorly cooked meals, have it take 10x longer, and waste a bunch of time and money trying to be a self-taught Michelin Star Chef. 

#strategy #b2b #marketing #sales

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Should we publish our pricing on our website?

B2B companies come up with a million excuses and objections about why not to do it:

â€œWe need our rep t
text:
Should we publish our pricing on our website?

B2B companies come up with a million excuses and objections about why not to do it:

â€œWe need our rep to talk to the customer to â€˜provide valueâ€™ first before we tell them the price.â€

â€œIf we publish pricing on our website, our competitors will find out and undercut us.â€ (lol as if your competitors canâ€™t figure out your pricing on their own)

â€œOur pricing is way too complicated. If we publish it, our customers will get confused and wonâ€™t talk to our Sales team.â€

And a million different iterations of these objections and excuses that are all about the company and nothing about the customer. Every excuse has everything to do with what you want and zero to do with what the customer wants.

__

The most black & white way to address this at your company - which is exactly what I did in 2017 - was I ran a survey to all the decision makers at our Tier 1 & Tier 2 accounts.

One of the questions was: When buying XYZ technology, what steps in your buying process would you like to accomplish *before* you talk to a Sales representative?

More than 600 total accounts responded.

93% of the respondents said they want to know the price before they talk with a Sales rep.

There it is. Simple. 600 decision makers at target accounts telling you exactly how they want to buy. Are you going to listen to your customers or are you going to be selfish and only think about what you want?

Itâ€™s black and white. If you ask your target customers the exact same question, you would get the exact same answer.

If youâ€™re customer-centric, itâ€™s obvious you would publish pricing on your website.

#marketingÂ #b2bÂ #salesÂ #gtm

p.s. Bulk procurement companies like Vendr continue to gain market traction because B2B companies are so selfish in their direct Sales motion.

Buyers would rather just go to a company like this than go through the dog & pony show of BANT qualification with a 22-year old, then see a canned demo 2 weeks later, then need to haggle with a rep for 15% off list price. By the time theyâ€™re done, itâ€™s been 10 weeks to buy a $40k/year SaaS tool.

Instead, theyâ€™ll go to Vendr and get the best price w/o any of the nonsense. And the B2B company will take a 30-45% cut on margin between discounting & referral fees, all because they refuse to be customer-centric in their Sales process.

The traditional â€œbest practicesâ€ for B2B go-to-market motions are completely misaligned with what a modern B2B buyer wants today.
