author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
If you donâ€™t enjoy your job, and youâ€™re reading this, there IS a WAY out.

This is my favorite book, the Wisdom of Insecurity by Alan Watts.

I want t
text:
If you donâ€™t enjoy your job, and youâ€™re reading this, there IS a WAY out.

This is my favorite book, the Wisdom of Insecurity by Alan Watts.

I want to be tactical, though, you can create your own luck. You can navigate out of your situation.

But to do so requires some advice from the Shawshank Redemption:

Pressure Over Time

Optionality is built in years and months, not days and weeks.

The best optionality is built by becoming an expert, and itâ€™s usually by combining two things (in my case, customer empathy and data w/ AI). Iâ€™m the best in the world ONLY when you mix those three things. This is a Ben Horowitz concept, and itâ€™s beautiful.

But the way in which you can get everything that you wanted is to find out what you enjoy doing, and just begin.

Begin by working on it, talking to people about it, building little prototypes, working for people or companies for free to learn it. 

When you do that, you subtly convince the other people that love what you love that youâ€™re in it for passion. 

This is the single thing that people want to hire for, a hunger for the work itself. For its own sake.

Weather itâ€™s gardening, or dental hygiene, or making hats, or ice skatingâ€¦ I promise you there are others out there that feel the way you feel.

Then, once you know them, and once they know your only agenda is to find joy in what you doâ€¦ they FIND ways to help you. Because they see the joy, they likely feel the joy, and they want other people to feel the joy.

The people I completely avoid building relationships with are those that are money driven, not because itâ€™s bad (I love money), but just because itâ€™s the outcome they seek not the process they love.

That only gets you so far, because you lose your purpose when you make enough money. All that money ever got me, besides freedom from 9-5, is a ridiculously over priced coffee grinder. 

Start working on the side, finding your community, doing the things you feel drawn toâ€¦ and when you do, youâ€™ll draw in others.

And one day youâ€™ll wake up, and youâ€™ll have so much optionality you wonâ€™t know how to chose.

Thatâ€™s when you really become free, when you get to define your days around your joy, not your job.

Invest daily now, and I promise it will compound over enough time.

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Confession: I changed my mind about something I used to DESPISE.

I hated them.

Their color.

Their fur. The claws. The way they pooped indoors in a
text:
Confession: I changed my mind about something I used to DESPISE.

I hated them.

Their color.

Their fur. The claws. The way they pooped indoors in a bin (still weird).

And they gave me terrible allergies.

When my wife and I started dating she had a cat, and I told her it was either ME or the CAT (she chose me).

But then something weird happened. After the family dog died, my kids asked if we could get kittens. Obviously I'm a sucker and was willing to ignore my own feelings to appease my children, so we got not one but two cats. A bonded pair.

Within days the cats (of course) decided that I was their chosen human. They knew I had spoken ill of their kind. 

And they won me over!

They melted my cold grey heart and at the same time:

My allergies magically disappeared. 

So now I tell everyone that I can: it's OK to change your mind on a deeply held belief. I was once a cat hater. I mean I was deep on Twitter and in sub-Reddits talking shit about cats at every opportunity I had.

And now here I am, confessing my love for cats to the 180,000 people that follow me on LinkedIn.

What a gift!

author: Chris Walker
hook:
We just finished an analysis of $14MM per year spent on global Google paid search campaigns and here are the results:

Spend: $14,240,000
Opportunitie
text:
We just finished an analysis of $14MM per year spent on global Google paid search campaigns and here are the results:

Spend: $14,240,000
Opportunities Created: 1,212
Cost/Opp: $11,749
Advertising CAC Payback (Includes Google Ads Expenses): 23 Months 
Marketing CAC Payback (Include All Other Marketing Expenses): 58 Months
Total CAC Payback (Includes Sales & SDR Expenses): 116 Months 

When it's all said and done with all the costs across their entire GTM, it will take almost 10 YEARS to pay back the cost of acquiring a customer via Google Ads. 

The best campaign? Branded search. $3MM per year. 49 Month total CAC payback. 

-> Branded campaigns should ALWAYS have an Ad CAC payback period less than 2 months and a total CAC payback period less than 6 months. 

The worst campaign? Non-branded search campaign. $3.6MM per year. 193 Month Total CAC payback. 

-> Non-branded campaigns should ALWAYS have an Ad CAC payback period less than 12 months and a total CAC payback period less than 36 months. 

___

We were surprised by the results and wanted to check our work. So we used 4 different attribution models to analyze the spend. The above results are from the **most generous** attribution model. 

Itâ€™s wild for sure, but these types of results arenâ€™t atypical in the analyses we do with companies spending more than $5MM per year on Google Ads. 

Here are some tips to scrutinize the spend properly:

1. Measure your results against REVENUE, not just opportunity count or â€œpipelineâ€ 

2. Scrutinize each individual campaign, especially breaking out results between Branded vs. Non-Branded campaigns 

3. Calculate CAC in 3 dimensions (Ad CAC, Marketing CAC, and Total CAC) 

4. You need to have the discipline to shut off campaigns that do not achieve the appropriate ROI and reallocate the spend to other programs/channels that do. 

___

Google paid search is often by far the largest expense across the entire Marketing budget and simultaneously the lowest performing investment. 

It boggles my mind that CFOs and CEOs are not putting more scrutiny on these massive Marketing expenditures. 

#marketing #advertising #googleads #b2b

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
HIRE MAX AS YOUR GTM ENGINEER... here's why you want candidates like MAX...

First off, I don't know Max, but let me tell you why someone like Max is
text:
HIRE MAX AS YOUR GTM ENGINEER... here's why you want candidates like MAX...

First off, I don't know Max, but let me tell you why someone like Max is the type of person you want:

1. He started with a framework (in this case, my PVP)
2. He took an actual brand and built with modern tools
3. He was focused on the outcome for the END user
4. He may not be the fastest yet, but clearly he's dogged

Building without frameworks is a recipe for disaster.

Here's where I'd improve what Max did
1. Why is THIS PVP relevant for this brand? Is it?

2. Great messages are built on a foundation of data, but also need to be humanized, I don't talk about this enough, but a good PVP is written from a place of confidence and translates your work from the code to value to the customer

3. Talk more about the connection between the theory and the campaign.

This is what real work looks like these days, where real value is built quickly, with a theory, around a data set and taken to maker in days not months.

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
I think one of this most important factors right now is how much you give a shit.

Technology is everywhere. We are swimming in AI slop. It's easier t
text:
I think one of this most important factors right now is how much you give a shit.

Technology is everywhere. We are swimming in AI slop. It's easier than ever to blast 1,000 shitty emails to 1,000 people in your "target market"

Anyone can have a podcast. Anyone pump out content on LinkedIn. You can do webinars and upload videos to absolutely no one. There is almost zero price of admission.

And that is exactly why the opportunity right now is to simply ... care more. Do more. Try harder. Actually give a shit! I know, it's crazy. But that's the best hack there is right now.

Great. I love AI too.

Letâ€™s use AI to help run our business and be more efficient and all that. 

But from a brand perspective- how can we stand out? 

How can we do things that DO NOT SCALE. 

We run a private group of CMOs and I know for a fact that this is what they are talking about right now. 

Itâ€™s both. AI adoption. But how can we stand out? How do we go above and beyond? Somehow in a world where AI makes things more scalable â€” itâ€™s going to be the things that donâ€™t scale that make all of the difference.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Most â€œinboundâ€ leads are not actually inbound. 

They just get tagged that way because they come from Marketing. 

Itâ€™s actually just because you have
text:
Most â€œinboundâ€ leads are not actually inbound. 

They just get tagged that way because they come from Marketing. 

Itâ€™s actually just because you have some data and have been able to architect that data to triggers Sales to reach out to someone that didnâ€™t ask to talk to you. 

An MQL score is not an â€œinboundâ€ lead. 

Neither is an e-book download. 

Neither is a webinar attendee. 

Neither is a PQL. 

And these types of â€œleadsâ€ make up 90% or more of the total â€œinboundâ€ volume. 

___

This distinction of â€œInboundâ€ and â€œOutboundâ€ leads is super outdated for this exact reason. 

Instead, segment how Sales/SDRs follow up by:

(1) Declared Intent - A qualified buyer declares intent to buy by asking to speak with your Sales team about buying (Demo Request, Contact Form, Talk to Sales, Get Pricing, etc.). 

This segment of buyers should entirely bypass the SDR role and go directly to an experienced rep that can truly help the customer and close the deal. 

Figure out what you need to do operationally to create an efficient buying experience for your customer and make it happen for your customer. 

Plus, stop sending your best prospects (declared intent) to your least experienced people (SDRs). 

(2) Not Declared Intent - A qualified buyer doesnâ€™t specifically ask to talk to your Sales team about buying, but we have *signals* that drives Sales to reach out to try to get a meeting. 

This is a massive segment of buyers who have shown some *signals* of intent that should be queued and prioritized for outreach. 

Look at ALL the available signals across the entire GTM and optimize the timing, targeting, channel, message, and offers to this large pool of potentially in-market buyers. 

Build a Pipeline Architecture to track every single signal that drives Sales/SDRs to outreach and the disposition of that outreach all the way through the Sales process to Closed Won/Lost. 

___

Most â€œinboundâ€ leads are not actually inbound. They just get tagged that way because they come from Marketing. 

Itâ€™s time to break down the outdated department-level siloâ€™s that prevent us from seeing the bigger picture and optimizing a holistic GTM strategy. 

The future is an account-based, signal-driven, integrated GTM Team. And that requires an entirely different set of KPIs, terminology, and analytics to plan, report, analyze, diagnose, and optimize the investments and strategy across all the GTM departments. 

#GTM #sales #sdrs #marketing #b2b

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Happy (official) two year Exit Five anniversary to my guy and our COO Dan Murphy.

In the book Traction and the EOS framework, they talk about the ide
text:
Happy (official) two year Exit Five anniversary to my guy and our COO Dan Murphy.

In the book Traction and the EOS framework, they talk about the ideal leadership pairing between the Visionary (founder) and an Integrator (the operator).

That framework is exactly what makes Dan and I work so well together.

Most entrepreneurs fall into the Visionary category: creative, strategic, restless (yep), starting fires everywhere (can confirm), big on ideas, lower on follow-through (my bad).

Integrators:

- Bring structure
- Turn chaos into clarity
- Run the business
- Manage teams
- Keep the trains running on time
- Free the Visionary to do Visionary things

Candidly, Dan can be a complete pain in my ass - but that is exactly what I need. 

Dan pushes me. He sweats every dollar we spend. He questions every late night idea we have. He has even mastered the art of putting out every fire that I start.

This is the the reason Exit Five has become a real business, a real company, and something that has already outgrown my name. It's also a profitable growth machine that is making a real impact on thousands of people around the world (I have the receipts in my Apple Notes; the impact goes well beyond B2B marketing).

Dan will tackle any problem, big or small. He's on calls with my accountant, talking to our lawyer, he's interviewing candidates, he's fixing landing pages, he's coding, he's asking me why I spent $25 on a Jimmy John's sandwich at the airport. 

But more importantly he knows what we *can* be and pushes me to raise the bar. Have a high f-ing bar is one of our core values now.

Before this I used to brag about how little I was working, and now I know why: I did not have a clear purpose. I was alone. 

That has all changed in the last two years and I can confidently say that I'm in the prime of my career and we have a great business with product market fit because this guy took my call two years ago. 

His comp was heavily weighted on performance in that first year too. He took a bet on himself, smashed the goals (turns out we're both competitive) and it's be game on ever since.

He's also a good person (imagine that!) A great Dad. Husband. And the guy I would call in a pinch, for anything.

He's also grown - big time. Maturing. Evolving from a VP Marketing to a true COO. And I know there's more to come. 

Thanks for 2 great years Dan. I hope we don't have a public falling out one day where we're talking shit about each other on Twitter!!! <3

Please go follow him on LinkedIn if you are not already.

PS. We celebrated by playing TPC Scottsdale two weeks ago after the E5 team offsite and had a blast. I think it was $500 per person for 18 holes, but we put it on the Ramp card because it's a write off!

Also: I know someone will ask "where can I find my Dan?" Well - I didnt find him on Indeed ("no offense" as my 8 year old says). I found him because we worked together for 8 years at two companies. That was the secret.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Basically every B2B company is questioning their BDR/SDR strategy right now. 

Because the mass manufacturing strategy of MORE Leads, MORE SDR Headcou
text:
Basically every B2B company is questioning their BDR/SDR strategy right now. 

Because the mass manufacturing strategy of MORE Leads, MORE SDR Headcount, and MORE Spam Cannons have created an inefficiency spiral:

Need More "leads" -> Lower conversion -> Inflated Costs -> Repeat. 

The cycle has spiraled out of control to a level where it now costs a B2B company 2-5X more money to acquire $1 in incremental ARR. 

The "Predictable Revenue" model has become entirely unsustainable.  

__

I'm old enough to remember what â€œBusiness Developmentâ€ used to look like before the Predictable Revenue model came on the scene in the early 2010â€™s. 

Business Development teams were small teams of experienced professionals who:

-Have strong business acumen and executive presence

-Have strong domain expertise and industry experience

-Have strong connections in the industry and are respected in the industry 

-Focused on developing relationships & opportunities in large, strategic accounts (partners, Tier 1 accounts, OEMs, new markets/verticals)

-Leverage an integrated combination of physical events, in person meetings, and inside sales activities to create and close big opportunities 

-Compensated and incentivized based on creating and closing REVENUE

But here we are in 2024, and the Predictable Revenue model that has become an "industry standard" in tech & SaaS is cracking like cheap glass:

-Inexperienced people who donâ€™t have strong business acumen or executive presence

-No domain expertise or industry knowledge

-No connections in the industry or awareness in the industry

-Focused often on chasing around small accounts & small deals where the SDR role just dramatically increases CAC to untenable levels 

-Only leverage inside sales using spam cannon technology to flood buyers with unpersonalized, irrelevant digital messaging asking for meetings 

-Compensated and incentivized to book meetings and hit a volume of â€œactivitiesâ€ 

____

It's pretty simple to see why the current "industry standard" is falling short for B2B companies, and more importantly, for their customers. 

In the future, weâ€™re going to see a big change to how â€œBusiness Developmentâ€ works in B2B companies. 

Weâ€™re going to go back to basics. Back to the fundamentals. 

Where experienced, respected, highly competent people leverage an integrated approach to develop and close new opportunities with high-value accounts. 

And a lot of the low value work done by inexperienced people to low value accounts will be automated and removed by AI. 

Time to go back to basics. 

#marketing #b2b #finance #gtm #sdr

P.s. this isnâ€™t ambulance chasing. I'm not saying every SDR role is going away tomorrow. But what is clear as day across all functions in business is that low value work done by inexperienced people that isnâ€™t customer centric, will over time be removed by AI.

This will be p
text:
Today I am ??finishing?? my AutoClaygent tool for Clay AI Agents... so you never have to click in Clay again to get GREAT AI agents...

This will be part of my next course... this course will be MUCH more tool based... here's what this tool will do...

One of the things I found myself doing a LOT in clay is copying and pasting, and I was sick and tired of being a copy and paste monkey.

What I wanted was this exact process (which DOESN'T need to involve me)...

1. Interview customer as to what they want (this is me)
2. Have customer act as the AI agent and do the work manually for 50 rows
3. Capture their process + NAMED categories (e.g. how they classify things)
4. Turn it into an AI agent 
5. Have that agent judged by their context.
6. Have AI evaluate #5 and rewrite #4.

The course will be $499 I have decided and it will replace Agent 7 (which is STILL useful and STILL good, there's just a way to do it automatically).

I loved the price of Agent 7 at $299 and my other course on PVP and PQS is a seminal work at $999. But both sold about $100k each, so I want to both price maximize WHILE having more people experience my work.

You will also be required to have a $100/mo Claude Code subscription (it's just that good). So I'll be clear about that, too. You -MIGHT- need the $200/mo thing, but I don't think so.

If you want to be notified when it launches, comment below with what you want to learn!

My hope is that you too can vibe like I vibe making stuff in 2026, which is more about distilling and automating knowledge and not clicking and managing fragile workflows.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
How to nail your next big talk ðŸ‘‡

I used to be terrified of public speaking. But I pushed through the nerves (with an assist from Big Pharma) & am abs
text:
How to nail your next big talk ðŸ‘‡

I used to be terrified of public speaking. But I pushed through the nerves (with an assist from Big Pharma) & am absolutely glad I did.

If you're even a little bit like me, you'll want to bookmark this post from Vincent Pierri. He's personally delivered 300+ unique talks over the last 5 years. Now he's sharing his proven framework for a better 30 min keynote.

Read the full story in Growth Unhinged here: https://lnkd.in/eydNVYxG

The framework in four steps:

1ï¸âƒ£ Nail the intro (5 minutes)

Every great talk begins with tension.

Think of your intro as the â€œhook.â€ Itâ€™s where you earn the right to keep peopleâ€™s attention. 

If you lose the first five minutes, youâ€™ll spend the next twenty-five trying to win them back.

2ï¸âƒ£ Build trust (3 minutes)

Trust-building is where you prove youâ€™ve walked the path. And your title isn't enough to get the audience on your side.

Three ways to do it:
 - Experience.Â A quick story of failure, experiment, or success.
 - Research.Â Credible data, case studies, or benchmarks.
 - Relatability.Â A short personal story that shows youâ€™ve been in their shoes.

3ï¸âƒ£ Deliver three main points (3 Ã— 6 minutes)

Three points is the sweet spot. Enough to feel substantial. Not so much that people forget them by lunch.

Each point follows the same mini-framework:
 - One-Liner (1 min)
 - Analogy (2 min)
 - Examples (3 min)

4ï¸âƒ£ Close strong (4 minutes)

Too many talks fizzle at the end. 

Instead, close with a one-two punch:
 - Final Story (2 min)
 - Call to Action (2 min)

---

I can't wait to try out this framework for my next talk. Hope you find it as useful as I did ðŸ™ 

#publicspeaking #keynote

author: Chris Walker
hook: Just like every B2B company ran Hubspotâ€™s SEO content strategy in 2017, every B2B company should be running this dark social content strategy in 2024
text:
Just like every B2B company ran Hubspotâ€™s SEO content strategy in 2017, every B2B company should be running this dark social content strategy in 2024 ðŸ‘‡ 

1. Host a weekly live event where you provide free consulting, advice, or information to your target customers (current & prospective).

2. Convert the recording of that live event to a long-form podcast (Apple Podcast, Spotify) and long-form video podcast (YouTube, Website). 

3. Cut the long-form video for micro-content for social media platforms (LinkedIn, YouTube shorts, Tik Tok, Facebook Reels, etc.)

4. Monitor performance of organic social media posts, and used paid LinkedIn to amplify your best performing posts to your target account list (Tier 1, Tier 2, or both). 

5. Collect quantitative & qualitative insights from all of these activities (Event chat, social media comments, dark social feedback, etc.) that drives future topics & ideas for the next event. 

6. Measure success against Total Pipeline generated and Blended Marketing ROI. 

7. Repeat, Learn, Iterate. 

___

The way B2B buyers research, discover, evaluate, and purchase products has fundamentally shifted. 

Having a presence and strategy for dark social content is no longer optional. Itâ€™s required. 

If you arenâ€™t doing it, youâ€™re missing a lot of opportunity and becoming increasingly vulnerable to competitors that move on it. 

__

High-performing Marketing teams get 10X more revenue for every $1 spent on Marketing, compared to low performers*. 

High performers: $3 in revenue for every $1 spent on Marketing.

Low performers: $0.30 in revenue for every $1 spent on Marketing. 

A core difference? Almost all high performers have a powerful dark social content strategy they've invested in for a long period of time. 

hashtag

#marketing #b2b #darksocial #seo #content 

p.s. This is not a debate like paid sucks and organic rules. It's not an either, or. The correct answer is both - build a high-value content strategy and distribute using organic channels & targeted paid distribution. 

*Passetto proprietary benchmarks of B2B companies $30MM-$300MM in revenue (2023-2024, n = 52)

p.p.s. Stop getting your "benchmarks" from a Survey Monkey form lol. It's wildly inaccurate and misleading. At Passetto, we pull all revenue data directly from CRM and all budget data from financial software to provide the most accurate, objective performance benchmarks for privately held B2B companies.

text:
Read this if you need to learn about AI and SEO:

What's amazing about our view from the balcony with Exit Five is that we see hundreds (maybe thousands) of questions from marketers every year, so I feel like we have a strong sense of what topics are important and top of mind.

There are a million questions about AI, but the loudest one over the last year has been about AI and SEO.

- I am noticing my personal habits changing to use ChatGPT more
- My boss is asking me to look into it and how we rank in AI Search
- Google is just answering questions directly vs. sending traffic
- Our organic traffic has gone down...
- The board has some opinions about AI and SEO and I need to get smart on the topic

So our team has put together a free AI SEO course; 100% free (just with your email) and has a bunch of vides you can flip through.

Now, a lot of this is changing in real-time, so there are no secret timeless hacks here - but if you want to get SMARTER about this topic, this is a great place to start.

In this free course cover:

1. How To Get Featured in AI Search. 

Learn the signals for getting featured in AI-Driven search (ChatGPT, Perplexity, Google AI Overviews). Make sure your organization is easy for AI to recognize, trust, and quote-- so your brand shows up in AI answers.

2. The AI-Driven Research Stack. 

Watch the exact workflow to turn raw research into a focused topic map: who youâ€™re targeting, who youâ€™re up against, and where the gaps are, ending with a ready-to-ship content plan.

3. SERP â†’ Brief â†’ Draft System. 

Turn SERP analysis into production-ready content. Build briefs that capture intent, outline angles, and prompt AI for safe first drafts, without breaking SEO best practices.

4. How to Track AI Traffic in GA4. 

Set up reports to spot AI-generated sessions and measure impact. Attribute which pages, topics, and formats AI engines surface most, and whatâ€™s driving sign-ups and revenue.

5. Plug-and-Play Templates + 30-Day Plan. 

Copy the exact worksheets, briefs, and reporting frameworks the experts use. Follow a 30-day quick-wins plan to improve AI search visibility while building a sustainable long-term strategy.

Here's a link to access this resource now:

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: I asked 195 B2B go-to-market leaders about where they're placing their bets for 2026. The top channel bet: AI discovery aka AEO. Wow, things escalated
text:
I asked 195 B2B go-to-market leaders about where they're placing their bets for 2026. The top channel bet: AI discovery aka AEO. Wow, things escalated quickly...

One company that got a head start on AEO is Webflow, the website building scaleup. Their stats via VP of growth Josh Grant:

1. 10% of signups now come from AI discovery, growing 4x year-on-year. (This is actual LLM-referred traffic, which likely understates things.)
2. 91% of LLM referrals come from ChatGPT alone.
3. ChatGPT traffic converts at 24% (!), 6x higher than Google.
4. For conversions referred by an LLM, two-in-three convert within 7 days.

3 tactics from Webflow you can apply in the next 24 hours (& one to avoid):

Avoid: Add an llms.txt file

 - The Webflow team tried it. They havenâ€™t seen any significant lift.
 - The takeaway: focus on content optimizations instead.

Tactic 1: Automate content refreshing at scale

 - AI reshuffles answers constantly. Refresh velocity can be the difference between staying on top and missing out.
 - Webflow built an AI-driven workflow with AirOps to 5x their refresh frequency.

Tactic 2: Turn every webinar into 10 pieces of expert content

 - Webinars can make great source material. Repurposing makes them fresh, structured, and consistently discoverable by both people and AI.
 - Webflow automates this by transcribing webinars (AirOps), using LLMs to identify themes & soundbites, generating assets & adding an editorial review.

Tactic 3: Automate FAQs and schema content for AI discovery

 - FAQ sections answer long-tail questions and help LLMs get a more granular understanding of the product.Â ChatGPT can essentially "borrow" your FAQ answers in their repsonses.
 - Webflow automates this by scraping what people are asking via Reddit & Google (AirOps), generating new FAQs & answers (GPT-5, Claude), pushing updates into the CMS & then tracking any visibility shifts before/after.

---

The full story is out NOW in Growth Unhinged: https://lnkd.in/eXP-gnFN

Hope you find it useful ðŸ™

#aeo #marketing #chatgpt

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Hereâ€™s the roadmap for the first 90 days as a Marketing leader:

1. Quantitative Business Analysis 

-Identify all the places where marketing investme
text:
Hereâ€™s the roadmap for the first 90 days as a Marketing leader:

1. Quantitative Business Analysis 

-Identify all the places where marketing investments are objectively wasting money (hint: itâ€™s a lot). Give the money back to the company to hit the bottom line or re-allocate to marketing programs that are already clearly working and have scale potential. 

-Close all data & attribution gaps so you have a clean objective view of performance moving forward & start collecting initial data ASAP. Includes things like self-reported attribution, UTM tracking for performance marketing, and full lifecycle tracking using a custom object. 

2. Qualitative Customer Analysis 

-Run qualitative customer interviews with your 10 best customers and 10 worst customers. Identify the nuances in demographics & psychographics. Develop hypotheses. Adjust segmentation strategy. 

-Test the updated segmentation model yourself by running 10+ qualitative customer interviews with *prospective* customers. 

3. Figure out how to drive more revenue within the first 90 days with pipeline acceleration and demand capture (hint: itâ€™s definitely not high volume lead gen) 

-Optimize the messaging & conversion path on the homepage of your website

-Optimize the handoff process so more customers that request a demo actually sit on a demo (crazy that only ~30% of SaaS prospective customers that ask for a demo actually sit on one - so much waste!)

-Build customer stories and/or a reference list to enable Sales to close late stage deals faster and at a higher rate. 

-Run pipeline acceleration events with Sales for key late stage deals 

____

Lots of early stage companies think they need their marketing leader to go out and get tons of MQLs in the first 30 days. This is effectively always a failure and will set you back 3-6 months while losing a lot of credibility in the company. 

These activities like customer research, segmentation, funnel optimization, and sales enablement set the foundation to then go out and CREATE DEMAND in the second/third quarter as a CMO by launching a podcast, organic social content, evangelism, paid social, influencer marketing, etc. 

Set the right order of operations first. Then set the right expectations on what metrics youâ€™re moving and on what timeline. 

1. Customer Insights, Segmentation, and Targeting 
2. Convert More Pipeline
3. Capture More Existing Demand
4. Create More Demand 

^^Execute in this order for the best results ðŸ’ª 

#marketing #b2b #gtm #revenue

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:

1. Intercom's AI agent (Fin) went $1 to $12 million in a year -- a year ago.

text:
The AI growth re-acceleration at Intercom via CEO Eoghan McCabe:

1. Intercom's AI agent (Fin) went $1 to $12 million in a year -- a year ago.
2. Fin is now on track to hit $100 million in 2.5 quarters.
3. Annualized growth is still 393%.
4. New customer NRR has increased from 112% to 146%.
5. Their resolution rate started at 25%. As of today they're guaranteeing 65% or they'll pay $1M (ðŸ¤¯) -- I'll drop the announcement in the comments.

Intercom is THE case study for anyone pivoting from SaaS to AI agents. They went all-in on AI & a disruptive, outcome-based pricing model in early 2023. Now they're adding a 90-day money back guarantee.

My top 5 takeaways from a recent interview with co-founder Des Traynor. Read the full story here: https://lnkd.in/ezrHeUeJ

1. It took a â€˜war timeâ€™ CEO to be the first to go all-in on AI. 

The Monday after OpenAI released ChatGPT, Eoghan made the call that Intercom would be all-in on AI to automate work.

2. Each 1% improvement in Intercomâ€™s resolution rate was hard fought with constant A/B testing. 

With Fin there are 15 different sub-processes involved in answering a customer support question. Most of the good AI tools areÂ *not*Â simply thin ChatGPT wrappers.

3 Competition will no longer be about who has the most features. 

Itâ€™ll be about how well those features work. The winners will be the ones who write the RFP for customers, teaching them how to evaluate and buy AI products.

4. If AI agents are doing the work for you, the pricing model needs to match.  Intercom has outcome-based pricing, only charging for successful resolutions.

5. Users donâ€™t necessarily see whether an AI agent is getting better. Educate them about improvements and empower internal AI champions.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
If I became CMO of a $10M ARR B2B startup, here's what I'd do to kickstart 2026 & 2x ICP pipeline in my first 30 days:

1. Create a list of every targ
text:
If I became CMO of a $10M ARR B2B startup, here's what I'd do to kickstart 2026 & 2x ICP pipeline in my first 30 days:

1. Create a list of every target account in my ICP.

I'd ask sales & CS about which factors make a great account. Then I'd bring in real-life data, analyzing all won/lost deals over the past 18 months to see which factors led to the highest expected ARR per 100 opps (equation: win rate x average ACV x NRR x 100).

These factors would almost certainly include industry, company size, and geo. But I'd look to go a level deeper factoring in tech signals, hiring signals and other indicators of buying intent.

2. Identify all the most relevant contacts at those target accounts.

I'd start with initiator and champion personas. Users, influencers, and exec buyers could come later. This data used to be hard to access, unreliable & expensive -- that has quickly changed.

3. Figure out where those target accounts are in their buying journey.

If there were 1,000 accounts in my ICP, how many were we able to identify & market to? How many are aware of us (i.e. visiting the website, engaging with ads, opening emails, etc.)? How many are interested (i.e. viewing an interactive demo, visiting high-intent pages, starting a free trial)? And how many are considering a purchase (i.e. they're sales pipeline)?

From there, the bottlenecks become obvious to the entire team. It's time to tackle them. 

4. Build a pod around the biggest bottleneck.

I'd spin up 10+ tests in the first week. The variables I'd play with: the account signal, the message, the channel, the offer, and the level of 1:1 personalization. (A manual approach would be fine to start with -- I can automate what works later.)

The lowest hanging fruit is usually to convert aware/interested accounts into pipeline. This might mean warm outbound to convert website visitors, testing personalized video over LinkedIn, offering exec access, etc.

5. Create a ðŸ”¥ content asset that I know will resonate with my target accounts.

My starting hypothesis: a State of X report featuring interviews & quotes from my ICP. I'd start with highly referenceable existing customers for social proof (low-hanging fruit). I'd then use the report as an excuse to message ICP prospects (the side-benefit: account-specific insights to personalize campaigns).

I'd build this report in public -- creating a content <> community flywheel -- to already drum up interest from my ICP well before the report was published. 

--

Why this 30 day plan works: (a) it's focused on the best-fit accounts, (b) it brings tight alignment between marketing <> sales, (c) it creates quick wins -- earning trust to take bigger swings, (d) it's the best possible onboarding, and (e) it's aggressive -- setting the bar high.

And, if it doesn't work, perhaps I'd propose another brand refresh ðŸ™ƒ

---

ðŸŽ For more GTM & growth insights, join 81k+ folks who subscribe to my weekly newsletter, Growth Unhinged: https://lnkd.in/exTbjKaM

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Even the Top 1% of Go-To-Market (GTM) teams I interact with make this simple, massively painful mistake ðŸ‘‡ 

Planning and measuring GTM based on which
text:
Even the Top 1% of Go-To-Market (GTM) teams I interact with make this simple, massively painful mistake ðŸ‘‡ 

Planning and measuring GTM based on which *department* sourced the lead. 

Most SaaS companies are trying to implement a â€œFour Funnelâ€ MQL Waterfall Model and it 100% will not fix their GTM. 

â€œMarketing Sourcedâ€ vs. â€œSDR Sourcedâ€ vs. â€œSales Sourcedâ€ vs â€œPartner Sourcedâ€

It sounds great and easy in theory, so they can divide lead source credit between Marketing, Sales, SDRs, and Partners. And then put together the most BASIC, INADEQUATE revenue model that looks great in an Excel spreadsheet, but will 100% fail in real life. 

Itâ€™s even being taught at the most popular â€œschoolsâ€ for CMOs & CROs. 

This model is considered a best practice in the industry and meanwhile is the main cause of Go-To-Market Dysfunction leading to Slowed Growth, GTM Team Misalignment and Inflated CAC. 

Itâ€™s the equivalent of a Car Factory trying to decide which department made the car:

"30% of the cars got made by the people who put the wheels on"

"40% of the cars got made by the people who ordered the supplies and raw materials"
Â 
"10% of the cars got made by the people who do incoming inspection on the raw materials"
Â 
"20% of the cars got made by the people who assemble the dashboard electronics" 

Do you see how stupid this is yet? 

You need everyone in the Car Factory to do their part to build the car. 

And you need everyone in your Revenue Factory to do their part to get every closed won customer and every renewal/expansion. 

Trying to give credit to any department for building the car literally makes no sense. 

And itâ€™s time to bring that common sense into B2B go-to-market. 

Stop using department-level attribution as a replacement to your Strategic & Operational KPIs. Start planning, measuring and optimizing your GTM like a Unified Revenue Factory 

#finance #gtm #gotomarket #sales #marketing

I understand the "Four Funnel MQL Model" deeply, have implemented it many times, and personally recommended it from 2018-2022. But it will 100% fail in todayâ€™s environment because it does not produce SCALABLE UNIT ECONOMICS.

This highly inefficient model makes it â€œeasyâ€ for Finance to do annual planning and try to measure ROI yet basically impossible to scale, plan, forecast, diagnose, and optimize.

For mature companies, billions of dollars in enterprise value are on the line over the next few yearsâ€¦â€¦So be careful where you get your advice from -

All of the â€œbest practicesâ€ and â€œframeworkâ€ B2B companies get from Gartner, Forrester, and Tech Vendors were built for the Growth at All Costs Era and *do not* work in todayâ€™s environment where sound unit economics are fundamentally required.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
4 years ago, I told the 3 main ABM vendors they had a huge problem and none of them cared. 

It was 2021 and their revenue was skyrocketing. NRR was s
text:
4 years ago, I told the 3 main ABM vendors they had a huge problem and none of them cared. 

It was 2021 and their revenue was skyrocketing. NRR was super high. 

They were fat and happy and didnâ€™t want the meal I was offering. 

â€œWhat does little agency boy know anyway?â€ They thought. 

One of those vendors even sent me a threat of litigation for trying to help them. 

So what was the problem? 

None of their customers were using the product or getting value from it. 

It wasn't operationalized properly in Salesforce. 

Their customersâ€™ executive teams werenâ€™t aligned on an ABM strategy

BDRs barely used the intent company-level data, if at all. 

Their customers were paying $100k+/year for software and all they were doing was running like $5k/month of display advertising through it.Â  

I saw this pattern 50+ times in 2021.

Now, it sounds like their churn is through the roof. Thatâ€™s the pattern Iâ€™ve seen consulting with 100+ companies in the past 18 months, at least. Thereâ€™s other data that supports this. 

So Iâ€™ll tell all of you the same strategy lessons and insights I tried to tell them 4 years ago: 

1. You *NEED* to offer Strategic Professional Services if you sell a software solution that requires executive transformational change.

A Customer Success Manager (CSM) ainâ€™t gonna cut it when the long-term success of your product relies on multiple Executives changing their mindset and operating framework and aligning on new metrics & objectives. 

You must bring high-value, expert consulting that helps your customersâ€™ leadership team make the transformations required to have success with your product. 

2. You *NEED* to properly Operationalize your solution within the tech stack. 

Outsourcing the true technical implementation of your product to an agency, or worse, leaving it up to your customers' internal Ops team to figure out, is a clear losing strategy. 

Most legacy SaaS companies wonâ€™t do it because their investors expect 80+% gross margin and this would compromise it. But youâ€™ll pay for it later in GRR % which is a ton more costly and painful. 

3. You canâ€™t just sell a product and collect your MRR anymore. You *NEED* to do whatever it takes to get your customer the RESULTS you promise them. 

Tech buyers now constantly need to measure and communicate the ROI of their investments (in technology and everything else) - this is incredibly different than it was in 2021. Back then, CMOs could buy an ABM technology and barely use it just so they could be part of the Cool Kids Club. 

Now, if you arenâ€™t getting your customers REAL RESULTS and helping them communicate the ROI and impact of your solution, you will be incredibly vulnerable. 

___

These principles are simple, but not easy. Ignore them at your own peril.

#strategy #gtm #gotomarket #marketing #sales

author: Chris Walker
hook:
We are not in the â€œMarketing needs to do more with less eraâ€.Â This narrative is toxic and flat out wrong. 

The real problem is UNIT ECONOMICS. 

---
text:
We are not in the â€œMarketing needs to do more with less eraâ€.Â This narrative is toxic and flat out wrong. 

The real problem is UNIT ECONOMICS. 

---

To achieve proper unit economics, B2B companies must create approximately $10 in pipeline for every $1 they spend on Marketing and SDRs combined. 

Yet, the median performance across 50+ mid-market companies weâ€™ve analyzed is only $3 in pipeline for every $1 in spend. 

That means Marketing needs 3X more budget to hit the desired pipeline goal. And companies need 3X more SDR headcount. 

So, instead of spending $10MM to produce $100MM in pipeline, theyâ€™d need to spend $33MM to produce the same $100MM in pipeline. 

This seemingly subtle difference cascades across the GTM machine and changes total CAC payback periods from approximately 18 months all the way to 50+ months - a crippling blocker to business growth and scalability. 

And even with the inflated spend, they likely still wouldnâ€™t get to the goal since unit economics degrade with scale, especially when executed on accelerated timelines rather than measured and methodically. 

---

TLDR: Marketing doesnâ€™t need more budget to hit the 2025 plan. 

What really needs to happen is for your GTM machine to create pipeline with proper unit economics that lead to profitable efficient growth and target sales quota attainment. 

Spending more money isnâ€™t the answer. Making your existing spend work 2X-3X harder to achieve proper unit economics through smart, focused, disciplined execution is the real solution. 

#gtm #gotomarket #marketing #sales #finance #b2b 

p.s. you can calculate all these KPIs and draw these important conclusions without ever discussing or looking at â€œattributionâ€ ;)

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
I have stopped an experiment that gave people a ton of value before a sale, and here's why...

So it's VERY fast for me to build a PVP or PQS list, li
text:
I have stopped an experiment that gave people a ton of value before a sale, and here's why...

So it's VERY fast for me to build a PVP or PQS list, like 30 mins -> 1 hr. 

Now this list isn't like ALWAYS production ready, but it's usually good enough for a test. So I tried just giving these things to prospects after a first call, in addition to my standard vibe coded proposal.

This was A TERRIBLE idea and probably lost me over $120k, and here's why...

People actually don't want to buy results... and hear me out.

Results are ephemeral, this is why every lead generation agency is always on the razor's edge. When I ran a lead gen agency, people said, "sure this year I made $2M in closed/won deals and paid you $120k, BUT WHAT HAVE YOU DONE FOR ME THIS MONTH."

This isn't true with Google or Facebook, because they have a monopoly and you have no choice, so they can enforce rules (you pay for clicks).

People would take these lists, sometimes even execute on them, and then I suspect they didn't get good results and said, "THAT GUY SUCKS!"

This reaction is totally normal.

What people really want to buy (from me) is organizational change, they want to be able to do what I do. And I want that, too. I sort of design myself to be fired (I'm working on what a longer term engagement looks like).

Most lists fail, and that's okay, the real change that people need is to be able to launch 1 campaign every week, hopefully every few days. 

Taking a single list, that's 100% vibe coded, and thinking this represents the value was a bad idea because there's invariably a problem that neither of us could have forecasted.

The value was in the process to do it in an hour, not the output of any one hour.

I now know what I am selling, organizational change and education, not pipeline. 

The ability for YOU to generate more TESTS faster so YOU can eliminate the garbage faster and find what works.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
We just finished an analysis of $14MM per year spent on global Google paid search campaigns and here are the results:

Spend: $14,240,000
Opportunitie
text:
We just finished an analysis of $14MM per year spent on global Google paid search campaigns and here are the results:

Spend: $14,240,000
Opportunities Created: 1,212
Cost/Opp: $11,749
Advertising CAC Payback (Includes Google Ads Expenses): 23 Months 
Marketing CAC Payback (Include All Other Marketing Expenses): 58 Months
Total CAC Payback (Includes Sales & SDR Expenses): 116 Months 

When it's all said and done with all the costs across their entire GTM, it will take almost 10 YEARS to pay back the cost of acquiring a customer via Google Ads. 

The best campaign? Branded search. $3MM per year. 49 Month total CAC payback. 

-> Branded campaigns should ALWAYS have an Ad CAC payback period less than 2 months and a total CAC payback period less than 6 months. 

The worst campaign? Non-branded search campaign. $3.6MM per year. 193 Month Total CAC payback. 

-> Non-branded campaigns should ALWAYS have an Ad CAC payback period less than 12 months and a total CAC payback period less than 36 months. 

___

We were surprised by the results and wanted to check our work. So we used 4 different attribution models to analyze the spend. The above results are from the **most generous** attribution model. 

Itâ€™s wild for sure, but these types of results arenâ€™t atypical in the analyses we do with companies spending more than $5MM per year on Google Ads. 

Here are some tips to scrutinize the spend properly:

1. Measure your results against REVENUE, not just opportunity count or â€œpipelineâ€ 

2. Scrutinize each individual campaign, especially breaking out results between Branded vs. Non-Branded campaigns 

3. Calculate CAC in 3 dimensions (Ad CAC, Marketing CAC, and Total CAC) 

4. You need to have the discipline to shut off campaigns that do not achieve the appropriate ROI and reallocate the spend to other programs/channels that do. 

___

Google paid search is often by far the largest expense across the entire Marketing budget and simultaneously the lowest performing investment. 

It boggles my mind that CFOs and CEOs are not putting more scrutiny on these massive Marketing expenditures. 

#finance #b2b #marketing #googleads #b2b

author: Chris Walker
hook:
B2B Companies have been talking about Sales & Marketing misalignment for more than a decade. Theyâ€™ve tried to solve it with:

-Changing marketing goal
text:
B2B Companies have been talking about Sales & Marketing misalignment for more than a decade. Theyâ€™ve tried to solve it with:

-Changing marketing goals from MQLs to SQLs (didnâ€™t work)
-Putting a Chief Revenue Officer in charge of Marketing (didnâ€™t work)
-Having a weekly pipeline meeting (didnâ€™t work)
-Buying an ABM platform (didnâ€™t work)

B2B companies always try to fix GTM at tactical execution (letâ€™s hire a new growth marketer to do SEO for us) or tech & tools (letâ€™s buy an ABM platform and change from MQLs to MQAs).

They do this because itâ€™s easy but doesnâ€™t solve the real problem. Itâ€™s superficial & visible. Itâ€™s easy to report back to the board in a powerpoint slide about a new tool or tactic.

But the real root cause of these issues is much more fundamental. Itâ€™s deeply rooted & invisible.

The real root cause is the operating model & data model that companies consciously or subconsciously adopt that drives the mindset of executives, investors, and GTM teams, and influences every decision they make.

Lead -> MQL/MQA -> SAL -> SQL -> SQO -> Closed Won

And here are the core issues:

1. Operates in an assembly line of siloâ€™d departments instead of an allbound integrated revenue team.

2. Evaluation of the ROI and Impact of investments are made in silos by each department (Marketing, Sales, SDRs) instead of within a Unified GTM model.

3. There are no commonly accepted KPIs and "attribution" strategies for Demand Creation, so the entire GTM team doesn't focus or invest here, leaving the entire GTM engine highly imbalanced & inefficient.

4. Most companies use a model that was created between 2012 and 2017, despite how much has changed in the world in the past 6 years.

5. Marketing is optimizing for MQLs/MQAs or a poor definition of â€œpipelineâ€ that doesnâ€™t align to close won revenue. The data is clear in every Salesforce instance that core Marketing KPIs donâ€™t align to closed won revenue, sales velocity, and marketing ROI.

6. SDRs optimize for SQLs or meetings, not closed won revenue.

7. Revenue planning models look great in a spreadsheet & break in real life.

8. All of the technology, tools, and tactical â€œbest practicesâ€ are built around getting leads, MQLs/MQAs, and SQLs, further entrenching companies getting stuck in the model.

9. GTM teams are stuck in the incremental. How do we improve our outbound connect rates by 1%? How do we reduce our cost per lead by $3? There are no breakthroughs in growth with incremental improvements. Optimizing a broken model is not the solution, itâ€™s changing the model.

10. No standardized data model so every company reinvents the wheel in RevOps w/o clear, performance-based definitions. Everybody on the GTM team is looking at different metrics.

__

When you are making adjustments for H2 2024, use these ideas as a guide. Clearly identify the core issue(s) that are holding you back. Create a solution that actually solves the root cause, instead of treating the symptoms.

#gotomarket #gtm #b2b #gtm #revops

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
In just ONE HOUR I did this, with only my voiceâ€¦  this what GTM Engineering looks like in the futureâ€¦

100% in Claude Code and with Apify! 

What We D
text:
In just ONE HOUR I did this, with only my voiceâ€¦  this what GTM Engineering looks like in the futureâ€¦

100% in Claude Code and with Apify! 

What We Did: Review Enrichment & Classification Pipeline

We built a scalable pipeline to pull and analyze Google Maps reviews for 9,732 ********* practicesâ€”every company with 150+ reviews plus all PLATINUM/GOLD tier prospects. Using Apify's Google Maps Reviews Scraper at Scale tier (128 concurrent actors), we collected 201,556 unique reviews across 9,423 locations in under 2 hours. 

Each review was then processed through Claude's Message Batches API for pain signal classification, categorizing reviews into six operational buckets: scheduling issues, communication problems, billing complaints, staff issues, legacy technology mentions, and growth constraints.

 The classification results revealed that detectable pain signals are sparse: only ~1.8% of the 161,379 processed reviews contained identifiable operational complaints (2,787 communication issues, 1,981 billing mentions, 1,930 staff problems, 1,248 scheduling complaints, 1,089 growth signals, and just 453 legacy tech mentions). 

This reinforces the validation findingsâ€”Google reviews aren't a reliable source for identifying "******* in pain." The signal-to-noise ratio is too low, and negative reviews often reflect one-off experiences rather than systemic operational dysfunction that would drive software purchasing decisions.

 Based on this analysis, we've assigned each of the 9,732 companies a recommended product (PRODUCT 1, PRODUCT 2, or PRODUCT 3) and a message hook tailored to their dominant signalâ€”though 69% defaulted to the general value proposition since they lacked detectable pain. The actionable output: focus outreach on ***-change signals and ******* maturity rather than trying to infer pain from reviews. The data supports "you're evolving, here's infrastructure that scales" messaging over "we see you're struggling."

This dog is how youâ€™ll feel like when you start building this wayâ€¦

author: Chris Walker
hook: After a thorough analysis of a $80MM ARR SaaS company, I just recommended an 88% budget cut to Google Ads heading into a H2. Resulting in a $1.7MM ann
text:
After a thorough analysis of a $80MM ARR SaaS company, I just recommended an 88% budget cut to Google Ads heading into a H2. Resulting in a $1.7MM annualized savings to be reallocated to higher performing programs. Hereâ€™s why:

BACKGROUND

1. Company had been spending $2MM per year on Google Ads (12% branded, 88% non-brand / competitor. 

2. CAC payback period on non-branded and competitive terms were > 5 years in both a W-shaped (generous) model and a conversion-only (strict) model. 

3. Total company pipeline production has dropped by 50% over the past 3 quarters. And Sales win rates have dropped from 16% to 10%. 

4. Current strategy to create pipeline is insufficient to hit the FY24 revenue plan and already has the FY25 growth plan at risk. 

5. Changing nothing will result in < 15% YoY growth in both FY24 and FY25. 

RATIONALE

At Passetto, we are *consistently* recommending major (> 75%) cuts to Google Ads / Paid Search investments for the following core reasons:

1. The unit economics simply donâ€™t make sense in most cases for a complex B2B sales motion. 

Sure, you can get this channel to seemingly work when you measure it on "cost per conversion" or "cost per MQL" but the conversion rates from that point forward are awful and full funnel conversion is required to estimate true ROI. 

Cost per click = $18
Landing page conversion rate = 1%Â 
Conversion to Qualified Opp: 30%
Conversion to Closed Won: 12% 

Click to Closed Won = 0.04% (1 closed won for every 2,500 clicks)
Direct Advertising CAC: $50,000
Program CAC: $72,000 (estimate)
Marketing CAC: > $100,000Â 
Total CAC (Marketing, Sales, SDR, Ops, etc.): > $200,000 

Blended CAC payback at $40k ACV = More than 5 years. 

2. Poor unit economics on Google Ads + significant investment allocation (>25% of total budget) put massive pressure on aggregated unit economics - Marketing ROI and Total CAC. 

3. No account-level targeting on Google Ads. You canâ€™t guarantee that the people clicking your ads for $18 per click are even qualified to buy from you (lots of Google Ads traffic and conversions are Spam or unqualified SMB). 

We instead recommended reallocating this budget to LinkedIn Ads, Meta Ads, YouTube, and Connected TV where the targeting capabilities are significantly more accurate and sophisticated so we know the advertising investments are going towards people and accounts that can actually buy from us. 

_____

People follow me on LinkedIn because I see insights, patterns, and trends in real-life years before they become mainstream. Well this one could make a massive difference for you over the next 18 months:

Divest from a majority of Google Ad spend and reallocate to drive more pipeline production and better overall ROI against your go-to-market spend. 

The data is blindly obvious. If CMOs aren't pushing it, it's time for CEOs and CFOs to apply pressure here. 

#gotomarket #b2b #marketing #googleads #sales

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
Be careful that you don't end up in pricing 'no-man's land' ðŸ‘€ 

Nearly every software company I talk to is rethinking their pricing & packaging. Yet r
text:
Be careful that you don't end up in pricing 'no-man's land' ðŸ‘€ 

Nearly every software company I talk to is rethinking their pricing & packaging. Yet rarely is it clear who actually owns the decision -- or the work! -- apart from, perhaps, the Founder/CEO.

The latest data via my new State of B2B Monetization report:

 - <$1M ARR: The founder/CEO owns pricing (71% of the time)
 - $1-5M ARR: The founder/CEO owns pricing (69%) with an assist from sales
 - $5-20M ARR: Pricing is a hot potato between the founder/CEO (38%), product (18%) and sales (12%) -- or nobody (21%)
 - $20-150M ARR: Pricing shifts to product (43%) but becomes a team sport with input from sales, marketing & finance
 - >$150M ARR: Finance & ops play a *much* bigger role as folks focus on pricing as a lever for profitability

My two cents on the data:

1. Expect that you'll need to keep evolving your pricing. AI is simply changing too fast to blindly stick with the status quo.

2. As pricing becomes an increasingly strategic (& complex) decision, it needs to be resourced accordingly. Assign an owner to collect data on costs, competitors & customer value.

3. Involve finance & ops earlier! They can help make sure that new AI feature doesn't sink the profitability of the business.

PS, you can check out the full report here: https://lnkd.in/ePsQJT6X

#pricing #ai #aimonetization

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
I think Iâ€™ve seen the future of software in how I do my workâ€¦ and hereâ€™s what I thinkâ€¦

Software as we know it is doomedâ€¦ and not exactly because of v
text:
I think Iâ€™ve seen the future of software in how I do my workâ€¦ and hereâ€™s what I thinkâ€¦

Software as we know it is doomedâ€¦ and not exactly because of vibe coding. Or those grumpy engineers that hate vibe coding.

Itâ€™s because itâ€™s designed to trap up in their worldview, with their tools, with interfaces we must click on, with subpar voice interfaces, with all of these opinions that make us adjust OUR behavior to their opinions on what we should do.

I think the future of software willl be more bespoke workflows that are hardened and trusted that I can envoke and pay for like an API.

Will people vibe code their own CRMs, I dunno, that kinda stuff seems sticker to me as itâ€™s critical infrastructure.

But most software is not (meeting note takers, watch out) and most software forces us to use it, to learn it, and to horde our work and make it impossible to export our data.

More so than the data is the context tho, prompts, workflows.

Most software has no place to store our intent, what we want to accomplish, who we are, what our goals areâ€¦ they all force us to do it their way.

So the huge divide between software and outcomes will be both our context, integrations with our tools that can act autonomously, and compounding plus siloâ€™d understanding of the tasks we need to do.

While engineers moan that â€œvibe coding will never replace Salesforce because of X, Y, and Zâ€ (true I think), they miss the huge gigantic point that these models:

1. Are amazing at low stakes tasks (daily life)
2. Can capture an understand intent like a person
3. Can build workflows locally to do things that have low risks
4. And that all of the above makes us FASTER at doing TASKS in ONE SHOT.

Thereâ€™s a revolution coming, slowly but surely, and those that will win will think about how custom code can start eliminating tasks for them.

And as it eats away at task, and if youâ€™re on the frontier, you can charge a lot of money for very little workâ€¦ simply by understanding the compound nature of value and working in the future, but taking money from todayâ€™s economy.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Who owns GTM?

This heavily debated topic is now crystal clear.

1. If Marketing reports to the CEO, then the CEO owns GTM by default. 

2. If a CRO o
text:
Who owns GTM?

This heavily debated topic is now crystal clear.

1. If Marketing reports to the CEO, then the CEO owns GTM by default. 

2. If a CRO owns Marketing, Sales, and Expansion/Renewal, then the CRO owns GTM. 

Those are the only 2 real options from my perspective. 

So whatâ€™s the insight? 

Most CEOs and CROs donâ€™t know how to properly judge, analyze, optimize and scale Pipeline Creation (Marketing + SDRs), especially when there is so much pressure on unit economics. 

This blindspot can slow growth, increase CAC, and decimate shareholder value during the Growth and Scale Up phase. 

__

If you want to build your GTM and steer your ship to an eventual IPO or Exit, the first thing you need to do is figure out exactly where you are right now. 

CEOs & CROs know theyâ€™re in North America. 

But they need to know that theyâ€™re in Austin, TX on the corner of 6th and Colorado looking south-west.Â  

They need to precisely know the performance of their Revenue Factory so they can properly align GTM teams, strategic initiatives, and investment allocation to drive the company forward and maximize shareholder value. 

Right now CEOs & CROs sit through a 5 hour board meeting and 120-slide Marketing, Sales, and SDR decks and still donâ€™t really know what's going on. 

Itâ€™s filled with a bunch of data and reports and zero executive-level strategic insights. 

Their only reference point is their own internal goals & planning or what their board/investors say. 

They are missing a *critical* external perspective that helps them see the bigger picture, calibrate and contextualize their performance, and align their GTM teams and investments. 

The only person who can fix your Revenue Factory is the person who has full ownership of GTM. Most of the time, that is the CEO. 

Once you recognize this reality, itâ€™s extremely powerful. 

#finance #b2b #marketing #sales #gtm 

Other times CEOs will tell me their team is failing but when we run their metrics, they are a Top 10% performer across all important KPIs. What a shame.

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
Gun to my head, if I had to build an AI GTM product, hereâ€™s what I would doâ€¦

First off hereâ€™s what I wouldnâ€™t do:
1. No all in one tool, bad idea.
2.
text:
Gun to my head, if I had to build an AI GTM product, hereâ€™s what I would doâ€¦

First off hereâ€™s what I wouldnâ€™t do:
1. No all in one tool, bad idea.
2. 100% no audio recording tools, unless itâ€™s in person like limitless.ai
3. No signals
4. Nothing that involves email or email infra
5. Nothing that tries to write messages
6. No CRM
7. Never lead gen

Hereâ€™s what I would do:
1. A VERY thoughtful CRM cleaner (h/t Anders Krohn).
2. ZoomInfo for you databases.
3. A SDR / AE monitoring tool tied to systems workflow (so monitor their screens and improve their workflows).
4. Message testing framework even virtual responders based on call transcripts.
5. A call transcript connector tool that just constantly extracts the necessary context on your customers for the LLMs.

These are just a few ideas.

But for the love of god, stop building the single app to try and do all GTM. 

Itâ€™s silly and wonâ€™t work.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: In the last 8 years I've surveyed 4,000+ private SaaS companies to figure out what's going on in the industry. Never have I seen benchmarks go out of
text:
In the last 8 years I've surveyed 4,000+ private SaaS companies to figure out what's going on in the industry. Never have I seen benchmarks go out of date so quickly.

Back in 2022 the typical <$1M ARR startup had 13 people. "T2D3" was the name of the game. Hiring a big team was a flex & the highest quartile of <$1M ARR SaaS companies had 38 (!) people. 

As of last year that figure had dropped to 7 people on average. Expectations around ARR per employee are through the roof. AI agent workflows have become the 'thirst trap' of LinkedIn. The new flex is reaching the top of the Lean AI startup leaderboard. 

Let's separate hype from reality & find out what's *really* going on. Take the 9th annual SaaS benchmarks survey here: https://lnkd.in/ga9H2NZ2

This report is super special to me. I'm so excited to continue the journey with my friends at High Alpha (ðŸ‘‹ Scott Dorsey, Kristian Andersen, Blake Koriath & Mollie Kuramoto). The full report will drop in the Fall & all participants will get early access to the data ðŸ‘€

THANK YOU for your support ðŸ™ 
 - Kyle

#saas #benchmarks #finance

author: Chris Walker
hook:
CEOs and CROs know they have a â€œPipeline Problemâ€ but they donâ€™t realize itâ€™s costing them more than $50MM every quarter they donâ€™t fix it. 

At $50MM
text:
CEOs and CROs know they have a â€œPipeline Problemâ€ but they donâ€™t realize itâ€™s costing them more than $50MM every quarter they donâ€™t fix it. 

At $50MM ARR and $15MM per year on Marketing & BDRs (simplification of the core investments to Create Pipeline):

1. [Root Cause] Pipeline Creation ROI drops by 50% from 1Q23 to 3Q24. 

2. [Growth Rate Slows] New Logo revenue growth slows by approximately $5MM/year and slows growth by 9% 

3. [GTM Efficiency Up to > 250%] Cut costs to lower CAC, but CAC is still up by close to 2X 

These combined factors of Growth Rate, GTM Efficiency, and Profitability create a minimum EV difference of 5X revenue multiple = $250MM per year in Enterprise Value. 

Every quarter it doesnâ€™t get fixed, it costs Shareholders and Investors at least $50MM. And delays the time horizon for the compounding power of a SaaS business. 

â€”

And why is it happening? Because B2B companies donâ€™t have a proper Pipeline Creation Methodology. On a $15MM per year budget to Create Pipeline, they have:

-Team of 30 Marketers
-Team of 20 SDRs
-$6MM per year in Marketing programs 

And no clear methodology to Create Pipeline at an appropriate Unit Economics.

__ 

The Marketing department deploys approximately 80% of the Companyâ€™s investments to Creating Pipeline.

And most Marketing Departments arenâ€™t accountable to a proper Unit Economics target. 

And itâ€™s one of the most painful, expensive problems in the entire B2B industry today. 

#finance #b2b #marketing #gtm #sales

B2B Companies don't have a Pipeline Creation Methodology, so they default to the Lead Gen Waterfall from 2012. 

Or they try to implement the Demand Unit Waterfall a la ABM from 2018, with no practical sense of implementation and it breaks down IRL every time. 

So they fall back on the Lead Gen Waterfall from 2012, except now they break it down by which department sourced the lead....

Installing a â€œFour Funnelâ€ model that divides lead source credit between Sales, Marketing, SDRs, and Partners was an appropriate strategy that I personally recommended in 2018-2022. 

But this model will 100% fail in todayâ€™s environment and in the future, because it does not produce SCALABLE UNIT ECONOMICS. This highly inefficient model makes it â€œeasyâ€ for Finance to measure ROI yet basically impossible to scale, plan, forecast, diagnose, and optimize.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Pipeline is the #1 issue for a majority of B2B Companies but most Execs don't understand the true root cause:

The Marketing KPIs are not aligned to B
text:
Pipeline is the #1 issue for a majority of B2B Companies but most Execs don't understand the true root cause:

The Marketing KPIs are not aligned to Business Results. 

__

People on LinkedIn put creativity on a pedestal, but B2B Marketing is the antithesis of Creative. 

B2B Marketing has spent the last 10-15 years running the same outdated, ineffective playbook of:

-Build PDF e-books that hide behind forms
-Run 7-step generic email nurtures
-Scale SDR farms to manage the spam cannons
-Spend millions per year on Google Ads w/o justifiable ROI
-Build 10+ over-priced ineffective trade show booths per year

And hereâ€™s why it happens:

Because the way B2B Marketing has been measured has not changed in the past 10-15 years either.

Itâ€™s built around â€œLeadsâ€ and â€œWeb Trafficâ€ and â€œInfluenced Revenue Reportingâ€ instead of actual business results. And there are no proper targets for achieving scalable unit economics. 

This misalignment between Marketing Metrics and Business Results boxes in Marketing to a very narrow set of traditional tactics, and is the OPPOSITE of Creativity. 

Want to help your Marketing team be dramatically more Creative? Hereâ€™s how:

1. Track Your Current Marketing Metrics and (New) Business Level Metrics Simultaneously. 

2. Prove to Yourself and other Execs that the Business Level Metrics are much better indicators of Marketing success 

3. Shift Marketing accountability from BS to BUSINESS RESULTS. (1) ROI of Create Pipeline Investments, (2) New Logo Efficiency %, (3) Growth Rate 

4. Empower your Marketing team to execute activities that drive the highest ROI (Pipeline & Revenue per $ spent, regardless of attribution). 

5. Leverage attribution and other forms of custom analytics as *secondary* forms of measurement and data to optimize the strategy & investments. 

__

It should be *impossible* for Marketing to hit their targets 2-3 quarters in a row while Sales misses quota and the Company misses growth targets. 

Yet, it literally happens all the time. 

And B2B companies try to fix it with band-aid solutions like:

-Have a CRO-CMO weekly coffee meeting.Â 
-Change National Sales Meeting to "Revenue Kickoff"
-Have a Pipeline meeting on Wednesdays.Â 
-Spend 6 months to build a new attribution system in the CRM
-Try a bunch of random stuff that doesnâ€™t solve the problem. 

But the only real solution is to fix the Marketing KPIs, so they are perfectly aligned to business results. 

If Pipeline Creation is the biggest opportunity in your business (and for many, it definitely is), make sure you fix the real problem!

#finance #marketing #b2b

p.s. Your Marketing strategy and investments are caused by your attribution model and KPIs, not the other way around ðŸ™‚ 

^Once a CMO and Exec Team truly understand this phenomena, everything changes

author: Chris Walker
hook: â€œWe donâ€™t use agencies or consultants because I had a bad experience with one several years agoâ€. Thatâ€™s what a Director of RevOps told me yesterday.
text:
â€œWe donâ€™t use agencies or consultants because I had a bad experience with one several years agoâ€. Thatâ€™s what a Director of RevOps told me yesterday. 

Itâ€™s like saying youâ€™re never going to a restaurant again because one time you had a bad meal. 

I used to think the same way when I was young, naive and inexperienced. I took so much pride in thinking I knew everything and could do it all myself. 

But then in 2013, despite me arguing against it, the company I worked for hired a Strategic Marketing Consultant named Andy and it fundamentally changed my career. 

Andy taught me all the really important things about Marketing that most people donâ€™t talk about - how to conduct customer interviews, how to create a business case, how to run a beta trial, how to build a differentiated strategy using product, price, distribution, and promotion all together. 

Then again in 2017, the company I worked for hired a Category Design Consultant named Robin who taught me everything about category design, positioning, narrative design and strategic communications. 

Then again in 2018, the company I worked for hired a Creative & Branding agency who totally transformed our website, sales decks, and advertising assets and taught me everything I know about the creative process and how much it matters in properly communicating your message to the market. 

A lot of my skills, experience, and success in entrepreneurship can be directly attributed to these experiences working with external experts that taught me specialized knowledge, processes, and ways of thinking. 

___

External experts (agencies, consultants, fractionals, etc.) have distinct advantages that simply canâ€™t be replicated by in-house employees:

-Theyâ€™ve worked with hundreds or thousands of companies to solve the same problem 
-Theyâ€™ve developed processes, automation, and other forms of intellectual property that accelerate projects and initiatives 
-Theyâ€™ve seen some companies succeed and clearly know what "success" looks like and what it takes
-They've seen many companies fail and know how to help you avoid common mistakes and missteps. 

Not leveraging external experts to complement the skills of your in-house team, accelerate key strategic initiatives, avoid common missteps, and help you identify internal blindspots is simply not smart and is based on a false sense of ego and pride.

I know because I thought that way for a long time and now realize how naive and misguided my thinking was. 

Not using external experts just because you had one bad experience with one is like saying youâ€™re never going to a restaurant again because you had one bad meal. 

Restaurants donâ€™t all suck - you just picked a bad one. 

Pick a better restaurant next time. Or be naive and prideful trying to cook all the meals by yourself - eat a bunch of poorly cooked meals, have it take 10x longer, and waste a bunch of time and money trying to be a self-taught Michelin Star Chef. 

#strategy #b2b #marketing #sales

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
Itâ€™s been 60 days since I left VC to become a full-time solopreneur. It feels like itâ€™s been 6 months. An update on how itâ€™s going:

For context, I wr
text:
Itâ€™s been 60 days since I left VC to become a full-time solopreneur. It feels like itâ€™s been 6 months. An update on how itâ€™s going:

For context, I write a newsletter about startup growth and monetization called Growth Unhinged. I also work with tech companies 1:1 as an advisor and consultant.

1. If I had to describe the transition in one word it would be *overstimulated*. 

I see so much opportunity yet everything falls to me. Getting summoned to three weeks of federal jury duty in January certainly doesnâ€™t help (& mightâ€™ve caused a mild panic attack). 

Iâ€™m resolving to make 2026 the year of focus and, hopefully, some delegating.

2. The newsletter became a Business Bestseller on Substack (#47), only two months after introducing the paid tier!

Itâ€™s now doing >$75k in annualized revenue from subscribers! (Ads are a bigger revenue source, although Iâ€™d like the two to be equal by the end of next year.)

3. Iâ€™m working on more premium offers to make paid subscriptions a no brainer without alienating free readers. 

Only 0.6% of readers are on the paid tierâ€¦ not great compared to tech companies.

Whatâ€™s on my mind for 2026: subscriber-only perks on top GTM tools (coming in January ðŸ‘€), special in-depth reports, and ways to bring the community together. Iâ€™m very open to ideas!

4. My best decision yet has been to team up with CJ and Ben to launch the Mostly Growth podcast. 

Itâ€™s a great excuse to have water cooler conversations with â€œcoworkersâ€. And we recently started bringing in guests like Brian Balfour, Emily Kramer, Leah Tharin, Dave Kellogg & Roland Ligtenberg.

Somehow weâ€™re already 20 (!) episodes in, which I hear is better than 90% of podcasts. Hope folks like it as much as I like recording it!

â€”

If you made it this far, consider following along by subscribing to Growth Unhinged: https://lnkd.in/exTbjKaM

#solopreneur #startups #writing
