hook:
This is the most important video Iâ€™ll put out all year ðŸ’¡ 

I sit in meetings where B2B companies waste tens of thousands of hours each year (literally
text:
This is the most important video Iâ€™ll put out all year ðŸ’¡ 

I sit in meetings where B2B companies waste tens of thousands of hours each year (literally) debating which attribution model. Or not making any important strategic changes because they canâ€™t agree on an attribution and planning model. 

Their Pipeline Problem, driven by declining ROI and performance on Marketing & SDR investments, is costing them at least $50MM per quarter. 

And instead of fixing the real problem and creating massive value, we sit and debate changing from first touch to last touch for 6 months and end up changing nothing. 

Internally at the company, they donâ€™t see it. 

But from the outside working with 50+ companies this year, itâ€™s obvious to me that the way B2B companies use this attribution system is the *cause* of their Pipeline Problem, not the solution. 

Every B2B company is trying to build a â€œFour Funnelâ€ attribution model to divide credit between Marketing, SDRs, Partner, and Sales. And itâ€™s literally the worst way to plan, measure, and optimize your GTM in 2024 and beyond. 

Because Marketing, SDRs, and Partners all have different superpowers and objectives in business and revenue generation. So why in the World would we measure them all the same? Make it make sense!! ðŸ˜­ ðŸ˜­ 

This model pushes every department to focus on the same, small part of the customer journey where lead origination source is tracked. Aka everyone is fighting over trackable attribution instead of operating as a Unified Revenue Factory. 

Your GTM strategy and tens of millions of dollars in investments get built to appease the attribution model, not the other way around. 

Itâ€™s an incredibly simplistic financial model. That worked great in 2021 when you had massive market tailwinds, and everyoneâ€™s coming in to buy your stuff, and NRR is through the roof, and none of your investors care about unit economics. 

The â€œFour Funnelâ€ model works great to just divide the credit dy department and pour millions of dollars more in. 

But when you need to be intentional about your investments and achieve proper unit economics to scale, this model fundamentally breaks. 

Which is why I personally recommended this approach from 2018-2022 and Iâ€™m forcefully pushing against it now. 

Because I understand this model deeply, I know its flaws, and I know it will not work in todayâ€™s environment. And weâ€™re never going back to the way it used to be. 

If you try to use this model to scale your company to $100MM+ ARR, you will inevitably run into painful, expensive unit economics problems that will slow down your growth path by multiple years. 

#b2b #finance #gtm #sales #marketing 

p.s. Supply Chain â‰  Customer Journey. Your Supply Chain is a critical 5% of the buyer journey where you build strong, high velocity, predictable flows of pipeline and revenue. 

p.p.s. Know this is a problem at your company and want to change it? Send this video to your CFO.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
B2B Buyers trust their peers more than anything else. More than Google. More than Gartner. More than vendors. 
 
The resulting effect is called â€œDark
text:
B2B Buyers trust their peers more than anything else. More than Google. More than Gartner. More than vendors. 
 
The resulting effect is called â€œDark Socialâ€. 
 
B2B buyers go to certain places to learn & discover with their peers:
 
Social Networks (LinkedIn, Twitter, Instagram, etc.)
 
Content Platforms (Apple Podcasts, Spotify, YouTube)
 
Communities & Groups (Facebook Groups, Slack Communities, etc.)
 
Internal Company Comms (Slack Channels, Zoom, etc.)
 
Direct Word of Mouth (Phone Calls, Text Messages, DMs, etc.)
 
Meet Ups & Events (Weekly Zoom Meet Ups, VC/PE organized events, etc.)
 
Itâ€™s where business priorities get set. Itâ€™s where buyers validate their decisions with peers. Itâ€™s where B2B buying decisions actually happen. 
 
And none of it gets tracked by attribution software. 
 
And because none of it gets tracked, B2B companies canâ€™t keep up. 
 
Go-To-Market Teams canâ€™t capitalize on these MAJOR business opportunities because these channels donâ€™t get measured by their outdated software-based attribution models. 
 
Go-To-Market Teams canâ€™t be in the places buyers spend time and actually help them because those activities donâ€™t fit into their outdated software-based attribution models. 
 
Go-To-Market Teams canâ€™t do the right thing for their customers because doing the right thing doesnâ€™t get credited in their outdated software-based attribution models. 
 
Itâ€™s a real travesty. 
 
Because if you talked to your customers & actually listened to them about where they spend time, where they get information, and how they want to buy, youâ€™d see these insights are SO OBVIOUS. 
 
CUSTOMER INSIGHTS should drive your GTM strategy, not attribution reports.

#gotomarket #marketing #b2b #demand #strategy

Dark Social = Word of mouth channels through the maturity of the internet that scales advocacy, sharing of content, and other forms of word of mouth that *never* get tracked by software-based attribution and don't create intent data.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
A modern outbound playbook for 2025:

Many predicted the demise of outbound. Well, it's alive & kicking. GTM leaders told me that intent-based outboun
text:
A modern outbound playbook for 2025:

Many predicted the demise of outbound. Well, it's alive & kicking. GTM leaders told me that intent-based outbound is the no. 2 channel where they plan to invest more in 2026, just behind AI discovery.

Here's an extremely tactical guide to what's working (and AI workflows you can steal) via Fivos Aresti, co-founder of AI-first growth studio Workflows.io.

ðŸ‘‰ Manual cold outreach for ICP target accounts

Signals are great, but most target accounts aren't in market (yet). Start by mapping out the TAM & then filter down to a list of target accounts.

Fivos found 66,000+ companies, then narrowed it to 5,700 ICP targets. These were split into four tiers:

 - Dream 150 accounts (highly manual)
 - Tier 1 (cold calling & more personalization)
 - Tier 2 (automation via email & LinkedIn)
 - Tier 3 (automation via email only)

ðŸ› ï¸ Key tools: BuiltWith (identify HubSpot users), GetLatka (identify SaaS companies), Exa (crawl websites w/ AI), Crunchbase (identify funding), Apollo (identify firmographic info), Clay (research & qualification).

ðŸ‘‰ Automated, signal-based plays for other ICP accounts

These perform 2x-10x better than cold outreach plays. The five signal-based plays they prioritized:

 - Customer alumni play
 - Website visitor de-anonymization play
 - LinkedIn connections of founders play
 - LinkedIn engagement play
 - Social listening play

LinkedIn connections of founders is performing best. Fivos sees a 25.4% (!) reply rate, although much of this is harvesting demand from 1.5+ years of posting content.

---

Get the full playbook including signal-based workflows you can steal in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/eSsYvxJZ

Hope you find it useful ðŸ™

---

Today's newsletter is supported by Metronome, who's organizing an insanely valuable webinar on AI pricing with THE Elena Verna (link in comments).

#outbound #aigtm #gtmengineering

author: Chris Walker
hook:
7 Trends for B2B Marketing in 2025 that should happen but probably wonâ€™t:

1. Smaller Internal W2 Fixed Cost Marketing Teams 

We will see more 10-per
text:
7 Trends for B2B Marketing in 2025 that should happen but probably wonâ€™t:

1. Smaller Internal W2 Fixed Cost Marketing Teams 

We will see more 10-person Marketing teams at $100MM ARR than we will 100-person teams that many are accustomed to.Â Tons of management layers, reporting workflows, and inflated overhead costs that actually slow you down.

2. Senior leaders will get back into Execution.

No more sitting in Ivory towers with 4 management layers between Strategy and Execution. Smaller teams means senior leaders are in the execution, close to customers, and learn how to use AI to exponentially increase their productivity.

3. Greater usage of Offshoring & AI (more flexible, less costly)

Low level executional roles like video editing, graphic design, (potentially) paid media execution, email prospecting, etc. will be executed by AI and operated/managed by 1 expert in the craft.

4. Greater usage of External experts that bring process, data & automation that augments internal staff & builds competitive advantages.

For almost a decade, B2B companies have taken pride in trying to do everything in-house (see Point 1 above). And they miss out on amazing process, data, automation, insights, and expertise from external experts that simply cannot be replicated in-house.

5. Greater investment and weighted budgeting to program dollars and less to W2 headcount.

The typical budget allocation is 55/45 Programs to Headcount investment in the Marketing budget. Over time, we will see that more weighted to 75/25 Programs to Headcount as companies get more efficient on Headcount strategy, implement AI and offshoring. 

This adjustment creates meaningfully more flexibility for the Revenue Factory.

6. CMOs that donâ€™t own the Prospecting machine (e.g. BDRs) are at a severe disadvantage

Itâ€™s true. Process efficiency & alignment matter. If your BDRs & Marketing team spend most of the time debating â€œInboundâ€ vs. â€œOutboundâ€, you are almost guaranteed to miss your targets.

7. CMOs that arenâ€™t intently focused on unit economics & ROI will be fired by Mid-2026

Boards are about to put the hammer down on Marketing. If they haven't already. CMOs that communicate a clear, simple, financially-driven story to the board around performance, opportunities and future plans will succeed. Those that continue to present â€œmarketing sourced revenue reportsâ€ , â€œnumber of MQLs or demo requestsâ€, â€œinfluenced revenue reportsâ€ and over-complicated, unhelpful touchpoint data wonâ€™t have their job in 12 months.

PE investments that invested 2021-2022 have 2-3 more years left on the hold and they arenâ€™t happy with the current return profile. Growth needs to accelerate and CAC needs to go down big time to get the exit multiple they want.

__

Everything changed in 2022-2023. Most of the traditional Marketing playbook for a CMO is now set up to get you fired, not rewarded. 

It's a new era for CMOs. Are you stuck in the past or paving the way forward? 

#marketing #CMO #GTM #finance #b2b

author: Chris Walker
hook:
The Gartner 2024 CMO Spend Survey. Hereâ€™s the breakdown and what you need to know ðŸ‘‡ 

BACKGROUND

1. Gartner collected a *survey* of 395 CMOs and Mark
text:
The Gartner 2024 CMO Spend Survey. Hereâ€™s the breakdown and what you need to know ðŸ‘‡ 

BACKGROUND

1. Gartner collected a *survey* of 395 CMOs and Marketing leaders about their budgets in 2024 compared to 2023 (conducted in Q1 2024).

2. Survey respondents were from 11 different countries across 10 major industries, including financial services, high tech, manufacturing, healthcare, travel, etc.

3. Median annual revenue from respondents was $5.3 BILLION

4. Respondents were 43% B2B, 21% B2C, and 36% blended B2B and B2C.

KEY FINDINGS

1. In the surveyed sample, Marketing budgets fell by 15% from 2023 to 2024 from 9.1% of total company revenue down to 7.7%.

2. In the survey sample, Marketing allocations changed from 2023 to 2024 with companies spending more on Marketing Programs as a % of total marketing budget, and less on MarTech, Agencies, and Headcount.

3. The publication uses this data to support the narrative of CMOs in the â€œDo More with Less Eraâ€

AND HEREâ€™S MY TAKE

1. Median annual revenue of $5.3 Billion. 

If you are less than $1B-$2B in revenue, this data is not relevant to you.

2. The data from Gartner is collected from **survey responses**.

Itâ€™s highly unlikely the respondents are pulling out their $5B+ P&L from last year, analyzing every line item, properly categorizing each expense, and reporting it accurately on a SurveyMonkey. This data is not standardized, not validated, and not trustworthy from my perspective.

3. Budgeting and benchmarking your Marketing budget as a % of total company revenue is a lazy, inaccurate way to determine how much you should spend on Marketing.

This lazy calculation does not include critical factors such as (1) YoY Revenue Growth Rate, (2) Gross Margin, (3) EBITDA / FCF, (4) S&M % of Net New ARR, (5) NRR %, (6) Sales:Marketing spend ratio.

4. The reported budget allocations are wildly different than what we see at Passetto in our full third-party budget analyses of more than 60 middle-market B2B tech companies in the past 12 months.

Internal Headcount: Garter reports 22%. Passetto typically sees 35%-50%
Programs / Media: Gartner reports 28%. Passetto typically sees 45%-60%
Agencies: Gartner reports 22%. Passetto typically sees 4-8%
MarTech: Gartner reports 24%. Passetto typically sees 2-5%

5. The Marketing needs to â€œDo More With Less Eraâ€ is a toxic narrative and flat-out wrong.

Broadly, the budgets supplied to Marketing in 2024 are sufficient to achieve the tempered business growth goals. The real problem is UNIT ECONOMICS.

CMOs and Marketing leaders need to completely rethink how to deploy budgets to achieve a CAC target thatâ€™s acceptable to the business.

Itâ€™s 100% possible. Companies did it for decades before the COVID-Boom and subsequent COVID-Fallout where budgets inflated & CAC payback periods increased by more than 100% from 2021-2024.

It's time to stop complaining "we don't have enough budget" and get back to core business fundamentals.

#marketing #finance #b2b #sales #budgets

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
Almost all of what I use AI for is collecting and organizing dataâ€¦ almost never writingâ€¦ and Charlie explains why SO WELLâ€¦

Charlie has perfect pitch,
text:
Almost all of what I use AI for is collecting and organizing dataâ€¦ almost never writingâ€¦ and Charlie explains why SO WELLâ€¦

Charlie has perfect pitch, heâ€™s an incredible artist. Even Taylor Swift sang about him, â€œWe declared Charlie Puth should be a bigger artist.â€

The thing about a good message is not that itâ€™s perfect, itâ€™s that itâ€™s authentic.

And the average of many authentic pieces of writing is oddly inauthentic. 

There IS a recipe for authenticity in GTM and itâ€™s petty simpleâ€¦

1. Understand the organizing principle for why your different types of customers buy (industries, use cases, jobs to be done, pain, etc). Youâ€™re looking for what unites buyers besides â€œthey all bought my software.â€

2. Go figure out what insight that group of buyers had, WHY you? If itâ€™s because they trusted who referred them, thatâ€™s hard. Youâ€™re looking for their counter intuitive truth.

3. Use AI to figure out where the data lives where you can find batches of people in this same situation.

Then all you have to do is tell the story you learned in 2 to the customers from the list in 3.

AI wonâ€™t replace our creativity and to use to it send creative messages is weirdly missing the point.

You should use it to find the needles in the haystack and to explain what the last needle did to get out. 

And HOW you do it is the art part. And often, the surface area of intelligence from 1 and 2 is SO low or 1 for horizontal SaaS is SO HARD  that you default to mostly blasting stuff. 

But itâ€™s the sitting on the piano moment that canâ€™t be replicated by AI and I think our buyers will know what authenticity sounds like well into the future.

As the noise has increased a ton, but the signal has always sounded the same. 

And just like pornography, as the Supreme Court is famous for saying (paraphrasing), â€œI canâ€™t define it, but you know it when you see it.â€

author: Chris Walker
hook: I hear the grumblings - many people think Iâ€™m trying to â€œput Marketing downâ€ but in reality Iâ€™m one of the only people trying to save this profession.
text:
I hear the grumblings - many people think Iâ€™m trying to â€œput Marketing downâ€ but in reality Iâ€™m one of the only people trying to save this profession. 

The B2B Marketing profession will slowly die if this doesnâ€™t change. Itâ€™s already happening. 

-Lots of PE firms telling me they are broadly disappointed with Marketing performance and the business acumen within that department

-Lots of CROs telling me they donâ€™t have confidence their Marketing team can fix the pipeline problem.

-Lots of CEOs needing to make changes to Marketing leadership due to continued underperformance (inadequate unit economics that don't scale)

-Revenue Marketing / Demand Gen / ABX is starting to roll into the Chief Revenue Officer (CRO). Some CMOs are trying to give this away from their mandate and focus only on Product Marketing & Comms. 

-Product Marketing teams are starting to roll into Product or Strategy, instead of Marketing. 

Donâ€™t shoot the messenger. 

These are facts about whatâ€™s happening, not my opinion. 

You can get mad at me for telling you the truth, or you can use this information to your advantage. 

___

Unfortunately, just changing who owns the responsibilities that Marketing currently owns isnâ€™t going to fix this problem. It's just yet another superficial band-aid B2B companies use to patch up this problem for a few quarters until the dysfunction resurfaces again. 

___

B2B companies continue to spin around in a circle

1. Hire a New CMO
2. Get measured on the wrong things
3. Do the wrong things
4. Donâ€™t have a story to tell around business impact because there isnâ€™t one
5. CMO asked to resign
6. Repeat every 18 months 

Change how you measure the success of your CMO and magically Marketing strategy changes and the impact of Marketing investments increase dramatically.Â Smart people can achieve clear goals. 

The person in the seat (CMO) isnâ€™t the problem. The process of how we plan, measure, and optimize our Pipeline Creation process is the real problem. 

Stop wasting your time hiring a new CMO that will be set up to fail and FIX THE REAL PROBLEM. 

#marketing #b2b #finance #sales #gtm

hook: The ability to build & manage AI agents is quickly becoming a core skill for everyone. Here are 5 of my favorite marketing use cases for AI agents --
text:
The ability to build & manage AI agents is quickly becoming a core skill for everyone. Here are 5 of my favorite marketing use cases for AI agents -- with templates â¤µï¸ 

1ï¸âƒ£ Lead scoring & qualification

Lead scoring is part art, part science. You want to enrich fields via 3rd party data, but also bring in form data & some human(like) judgement. 

Turns out AI agents are great at this -- and you can add a human-in-the-loop escalation via Slack when the classification isn't clear.

See the workflow here: https://lnkd.in/eeDrZrdv

2ï¸âƒ£ Lifecycle emails

Traditional lifecycle emails are pretty mid (did I say that right?!). But AI agents can track new customers, analyze interesting ones & then automatically draft personalized emails suggesting next steps.

See the workflow here: https://lnkd.in/eeDrZrdv

3ï¸âƒ£ Competitor tracking 

Everyone is racing to write comparative content for AI search. This content needs accurate, real-time info on competitors including features, pricing info, reviews & more (otherwise you'll get penalized).

Turns out that AI is pretty great at scraping text and sending alerts when there are significant updates.

See the workflow here: https://lnkd.in/eeDrZrdv

4ï¸âƒ£ Content research

You need to stay on track with what's trending with your audience & key influencers in your space. But nobody has time to monitor dozens of LinkedIn profiles & Substacks. You can get an AI agent to do the research for you & write a report on the top-performing themes.

See the workflow here: https://lnkd.in/eeDrZrdv

5ï¸âƒ£ LinkedIn coaching

AI models have spiky intelligence. While they struggle with things that seem easy, they're surprisingly brilliant at things like analysis & coaching. You can create your own PhD-level coach to improve your LinkedIn game with tips on what's going well & what to change.

See the workflow here: https://lnkd.in/eeDrZrdv

---

Shoutout to Jacob Bank from Relay.app for sharing his ðŸ”¥insights. 

If you've found other cool use cases for AI agents, please share them in the comments (I'm working on a new piece for Growth Unhinged).

#ai #marketing #aiagents

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Why aren't more people adopting AI tools internally?

I was having a long conversation with our Head of Marketing Jess Lytle about this last week.

An
text:
Why aren't more people adopting AI tools internally?

I was having a long conversation with our Head of Marketing Jess Lytle about this last week.

And she crushed me.

She said: it's the same thing as you telling us to write more on LinkedIn; behavior change is hard. You just have to make it a priority.

She was showing me some amazing stuff she does with NotebookLM and how we can be using this to build a brain for our content flywheel and I was blown away but also frustrated - why aren't we doing this? More? Faster? Better?

Jess said: people are still adverse to change, like "is this really better than ChatGPT?" New tools just feel like another thing to learn on top of everything else -- but once you see how much time it saves you, you will wish you started sooner.

I also am seeing a HUGE GAP with what people are talking about with AI on social media and what people are actually *doing* at work.

PS. Go follow Jess for all things AI in marketing.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
CMO/CRO Average Tenure is 17 months

Average Sales quota attainment is ~40% 

Up to 70% of CEOs donâ€™t believe their Marketing team demonstrates object
text:
CMO/CRO Average Tenure is 17 months

Average Sales quota attainment is ~40% 

Up to 70% of CEOs donâ€™t believe their Marketing team demonstrates objective commercial thinking

Growth Rate has slowed by a median 50%

Median CAC is close to 2X higher than it was in 2021

Is it because all these people suck at their jobs now? No. Itâ€™s obviously not. 

Itâ€™s NOT A TALENT PROBLEM. 

Itâ€™s tough to see this reality when you work inside one company.

I have the privilege of working with 50+ companies per year, with all their CRM and Financial data. So I have lots of confidential conversations & see clear patterns that happen across most orgs that most people would never see. 

Which gives me a unique perspective on the real problem. So here it is:

The way companies plan, measure, and optimize their GTM performance and investments set the GTM Leadership and GTM Teams up to fail.

Read that again.

This is a cross-functional executive and board-level *process* problem, not a talent problem. 

Itâ€™s bigger than any individual C-Level Executive or Department. Hereâ€™s why:

-The Operating Model (e.g. Demand Waterfall, Four Funnel, Double Funnel, etc.) that are overly simplistic, lack practical application and don't account or optimize for unit economics

-The CRM Data Architecture - Companies take this Operating Model & build a homegrown implementation in the CRM using fragmented data & objects across different departments. So thereâ€™s no aligned data strategy across the entire company (itâ€™s true).

-The Financial Data Architecture - The only way expenses are tagged are by GL Code. There is no integrated strategy to optimize for unit economics across the customer lifecycle (No wonder Median CAC is up 2X!) 

-C-Level KPIs - There's often no accountability to a unit economics target at the â€œtop of the funnelâ€, meaning the massive investments in Marketing business development aren't aligned to business performance (No wonder CMO Tenure is 17 Months, theyâ€™re set up to fail with misaligned goals)

-Lack of Centralized Integrated Alignment Process - The Operating Model, company culture, poor data architecture & GTM Planning Model create and facilitate a Decentralized Department Siloâ€™d style of management & operations that lack the coordination required to drive faster growth & better GTM efficiency.

-GTM Operating & Planning Model - The Operating Model built to try to divide the credit by which Department â€œsourcedâ€ the lead has not evolved since the early 2010â€™s and clearly misaligns the GTM teams. Downstream, it drives overly-simplistic, inaccurate â€œROIâ€ calculations by Finance. This planning model gives you ZERO visibility on how to optimize and scale.

____

CEOs - When all of these critical business workflows are not aligned into a highly effective process, you will get poor results and then (often) blame it on talent instead of yourself. 

Are you starting to see why the only people who can fix this are the board and the CEO? 

#finance #b2b #gtm #ceo #leadership

author: Chris Walker
hook:
I talked to 100+ SaaS executives at the Pavilion GTM 2024 conference and here was my #1 takeaway:

~75% of CROs and CEOs know Pipeline is the #1 probl
text:
I talked to 100+ SaaS executives at the Pavilion GTM 2024 conference and here was my #1 takeaway:

~75% of CROs and CEOs know Pipeline is the #1 problem in their Revenue Factory. 

And here are the unspoken undertones:

1. CROs & CEOs donâ€™t have the data to diagnose & fix their pipeline problem. 

2. CROs & CEOs donâ€™t have the expertise to strategize and manage Pipeline Creation the same way they do with Sales process/forecasting. 

3. CROs & CEOs donâ€™t have confidence that their CMO can solve it. 

And when you break down the department-level siloâ€™s and analytics, the TARGET is simple:

For our Revenue Factory to deliver proper unit economics with less than 150% New Logo GTM Efficiency....

We need to deliver $2 in REVENUE for every $1 invested to Create Pipeline (majority of expenses are Marketing, SDRs, Tech/Admin)....

Then add in Sales headcount, operations, commissions, etc. and you still land at or under an 18-month New Logo CAC payback period. 

__

So for a $20MM investment in Creating Pipeline, you need:

$200MM in Pipeline at a projected 10% win rate 

$80MM in Pipeline at a projected 25% win rate. 

But when your Pipeline Creation process in the Revenue Factory is inefficient, you donâ€™t get the appropriate ROI on all of these combined investments. 

So instead of getting $200MM in Pipeline at a 10% win rate, you get $50MM. 

Instead of getting $80MM in Pipeline at a 25% win rate, you get $20MM. 

You miss out on $100MM+ in Pipeline each year, $10MM+ in future revenue, and hundreds of millions in Enterprise Value for founders, employees, and investors. 

And then:

-Sales is starving waiting at the bottom of the funnel with no pipeline coverage
-Your most expensive resources in the Revenue Factory (Sales) start doing low value work in other areas of the Factory (e.g. low quality prospecting)
-You miss pipeline targets by 25% up to 75%Â 
-PRP drops and forces Sales headcount reductionsÂ 
-CAC increases to untenable levels 

And the ONLY way to fix your Pipeline Problem is to improve the blended Unit Economics at the â€œtop of the funnelâ€ 

To do this, you need an INTENTIONAL plan. This metric will never improve on its own by accident. 

____

For SaaS companies > 95% NRR, fix your Pipeline Problem to achieve appropriate unit economics at the â€œTop of the Funnelâ€ i.e. Pipeline Creation in the Revenue Factoryâ€¦..and you become one of the most valuable private SaaS companies in terms of metrics with > 40% Growth Rate and GTM Efficiency < 200%. And command a 10-18X TTM revenue multiple instead of a 3-6X. 

(yes, that impact is usually in the $Billions ;)

___

Companies spend millions of dollars each year to implement, train, and execute against a clear Sales methodology. 

But literally do NOTHING and invest NOTHING in a clear methodology to Create Pipeline. 

^And thatâ€™s the 9-figure to 10-figure problem hiding in plain sight for most CEOs > $50MM ARR. 

#b2b #finance #gotomarket #gtm #marketing

author: Chris Walker
hook:
This data is INSANE. And proves the â€œGrowth at All Costsâ€ era is over. 

Quite literally billions of dollars in enterprise value driven by how cost-ef
text:
This data is INSANE. And proves the â€œGrowth at All Costsâ€ era is over. 

Quite literally billions of dollars in enterprise value driven by how cost-efficient your go-to-market (GTM) is. Letâ€™s check it out ðŸ‘‡ 

First - yes, Growth matters. And has one of the largest impacts on TTM Revenue Multiple and Enterprise Value. 

But now Efficiency also matters - how much it costs to grow. Which is most heavily impacted by the ROI of the entire go-to-market GTM investment (40-60% of total revenue invested in GTM). 

__

So hereâ€™s the metric you need to monitor: GTM EFFICIENCY %

GTM Efficiency % = [TTM Total GTM Expenses] / [TTM Total Net New ARR]  * 100%

Put simply, GTM Efficiency % means how much did you spend on GTM to generate $1 in Net New ARR. 

(The smaller, the better) 

Net New ARR = New Logo + Expansion - Contraction - Churn 

Total GTM Expenses = Sales, Marketing, SDRs, Operations, Leadership, Admin, Training, Technology, Data, etc. 

But this number has been getting a lot bigger since 2021 in both the public markets and private markets.Â And it's decimating enterprise value in the process. 

__

So hereâ€™s the thing you need to know: SaaS companies with better GTM Efficiency are valued significantly higher (as a multiple of TTM Revenue). 

GTM Efficiency > 250% -> 3.6X median revenue multiple
GTM Efficiency 175% - 250% -> 6.4X median revenue multiple
GTM Efficiency < 175% -> 10X median revenue multiple

Wow, companies with *efficient* GTM are valued 2X-3X more than SaaS companies with demonstrably inefficient GTM. 

And that makes a difference of hundreds of millions or billions of dollars to shareholders. 

CEOs, CFOs, and Investors take note!Â 
__

The â€œGrowth at All Costsâ€ era is over. 

Drive hundreds of millions or billions of dollars in increased enterprise value in 2025 by hitting your growth target while also maintaining target GTM Efficiency < 175%. 

#finance #b2b #gtm #gotomarket #sales

*Shout out to David Spitz and BenchSights for this breakthrough data and research. Reference data is attached in the comments.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
CEOs & CROs - Imagine if you ran your 100 person Sales team without a Sales Methodology like Challenger, MEDDIC, MEDDPICC, etc. 

You could have talen
text:
CEOs & CROs - Imagine if you ran your 100 person Sales team without a Sales Methodology like Challenger, MEDDIC, MEDDPICC, etc. 

You could have talented Sales reps, all the best technology in the World, and capable senior leaders.....and it would still be a total disaster. 

-You wouldnâ€™t know what data to collectÂ 
-You wouldnâ€™t be able to plan and forecast the future accurately
-You wouldnâ€™t have insights to diagnose issues or optimize investmentsÂ 
-You wouldnâ€™t have a system to hold people accountable and keep people on trackÂ 
-Your strategy would live and die simply by the talent and training of peopleÂ instead of through *systems* and *data*

But a Sales Methodology becomes the foundational SYSTEM the entire Sales team runs on.

It drives what data we collect. It drives consistency in our process. It gives us data & insights to optimize. It helps us hold people accountable and keep people on track. Our entire company uses the same deal stages, data properties, terminology, etc. It creates the ORDER instead of chaos. 

No matter how good your CRO is, your 100 person Sales team would totally fail without a Sales Methodology adopted across the company. 

And hereâ€™s the wildly non-obvious insight (and why you follow me): 

ZERO B2B companies have a comprehensive Pipeline Creation Methodology. Itâ€™s a Frankenstein, homegrown system evolved from the 2012 MQL Demand Waterfall. 

You can have a super talented CMO, a great team of Marketers & BDRs, adequate budget to hit your goals, and all of the Marketing & Sales tech toolsâ€¦..but if you donâ€™t have a PIPELINE CREATION METHODOLOGY that the whole company agrees to (especially the CEO & CFO), itâ€™s going to be total CHAOS. 

And thatâ€™s exactly what it is. Have you experienced the Marketing portion of the Board meeting at a $50MM company? Nobody is speaking the same language. Investors and executives are looking at the data through a model built in 2012. The financial metrics are off track. Everyone knows it's a pipeline problem. But nobody can figure out why or what to do about it.

You need a PIPELINE CREATION METHODOLOGY. A comprehensive system to Create Pipeline predictably, scalably and at appropriate unit economics. That everyone in the company adopts. Itâ€™s standard practice in Sales (closing deals). It will take a few years but will be standard practice for Pipeline Creation too.

Itâ€™s crystal clear the band-aid solutions of hiring a new CMO or slapping Marketing technology on the problem arenâ€™t working.

#marketing #finance #b2b #gtm #sales

p.s. Installing a â€œFour Funnelâ€ model that divides lead source credit between Sales, Marketing, SDRs, and Partners was an appropriate strategy that I personally recommended in 2020-2022. 

But this model will 100% fail in todayâ€™s environment and in the future, because it does not produce SCALABLE UNIT ECONOMICS.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
The Figma S-1 is finally here, indicating the IPO window might just be re-opening. I read it so you don't have to -- here's the TL;DR:

1. Figma is a
text:
The Figma S-1 is finally here, indicating the IPO window might just be re-opening. I read it so you don't have to -- here's the TL;DR:

1. Figma is a giant w/ ~$750M in revenue in 2024, still growing almost 50% y/y. Very few public co's are anywhere close -- median last 12 month revenue growth was only 14%.

2. PLG & self-serve is a big part of the story. Figma has 450k paying customers. The vast majority are small: Figma only has 11k paying customers spending > $10k ARR & 1k spending >$100k ARR.

3. 76% of Figma's customers use 2+ products. In 2025 Figma doubled the product portfolio from 4 to 8 ðŸ¤¯ w/ the launch of Sites, Make, Buzz & Draw.

4. Net revenue retention is best in class at 132%, I suspect driven by a mix of self-serve > direct sales & multi-product adoption.

5. Perhaps more impressively, gross revenue retention is 96% w/ a big asterisk (Figma only reports GRR & NRR for customers w/ >$10k ARR).

6. The customer base is surprisingly global. 85% of MAUs outside of the US. 53% of revenue from non-US markets.

7. Yes, they still have a seat-based pricing. But there are now 5 (!) different types of seats: viewers, collab seats, content seats, dev seats & full seats.

8. Figma made big pricing changes in March 2025 & the results haven't hit their S-1 numbers. This included moving away from user-driven upgrades (hurts viral expansion, but gives admins more control) & a 20-33% price increase on full seats.

9. Even though Figma is a design product, 2/3 of users are non-designers.

Very cool to see such exceptional performance & metrics.

â€”

ðŸŽ For more SaaS growth insights & playbooks, donâ€™t miss Growth Unhinged â€” my free weekly newsletter (73k+ subscribers): https://lnkd.in/exTbjKaM

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Measuring "Inbound" vs. "Outbound" is probably the #1 reason you're missing your Growth targets. 

Why? Here it is ðŸ‘‡ 

Eventually, youâ€™ll run into uni
text:
Measuring "Inbound" vs. "Outbound" is probably the #1 reason you're missing your Growth targets. 

Why? Here it is ðŸ‘‡ 

Eventually, youâ€™ll run into unit economics challenges and data visibility challenges where you donâ€™t know what to do with your Marketing and SDRs to keep scaling them. 

^^Iâ€™ve talked to more than 100 CEOs & CFOs that express this exact challenge

And here are the problems that come from this old, outdated ineffective way of pipeline measurement & department accountability:

1. Marketing - Forces all Marketing investments into a small part of the Revenue generation process called â€œlead captureâ€. 

-Complete imbalance of Marketing investments caused by the singular attribution model leads to massive diminishing returns where B2B companies way overspend on low quality lead generationÂ 
-Improper measurement of Marketing investments make it incredibly complicated and subjective as to whether Marketing is performing at the level required for business scalability. 

*You should be able to know how well your Marketing is working or not with 2 metrics.Â 
*Marketing performance should be measured on a spectrum. *How well is it working*. Itâ€™s not binary. 

2. SDRs - No visibility to confidently scale or optimize the Prospecting process. 

-The only thing tracked is who books the meeting. But nothing about the WHY and HOW did we win
-The â€œInboundâ€ vs. â€œOutboundâ€ planning and debate distracts everyone from the insights needed for scaling and optimizing Sales Development process

3. Sales - Sales sits at the bottom of the funnel and doesnâ€™t have enough pipeline coverage to hit plan. 

-Lower quota attainment, lower PRP, forces Sales headcount adjustmentsÂ 
-Sales starts doing prospecting and lead generation to make up for poor performance at the top of the funnel and creates an *unscalable* GTM motion with untenable unit economics. 

4. Finance - Poor financial performance and ZERO clarity on what to do to fix it. 

-Slowed growth, increased CAC, lower profitability, lower enterprise valueÂ 
-Strategic decisions are made based on someoneâ€™s opinion (e.g. CMO or CRO) instead of confidently based on data. 

___

â€œInboundâ€ was a Tech Vendorâ€™s (Hubspot) Marketing message in 2013. And somehow 11 years later, itâ€™s still considered a â€œbest practiceâ€ across B2B. 

Meanwhile, the â€œInboundâ€ vs. â€œOutboundâ€ aka Marketing vs. SDRs. vs. Sales vs. Partner Lead-source origination attribution model thatâ€™s widely adopted across B2B is the primary cause of unscalable unit economics and data visibility challenges. 

Stop planning, measuring, and optimizing all your GTM teams on lead source origination - a singular, totally sub-optimal attribution & planning model. 

Start planning, measuring and optimizing your GTM like a Unified Revenue Factory. 

#finance #b2b #marketing #sales #gtm

The department-level view tells you WHO did it. But doesnâ€™t tell you WHAT you did, HOW you did it, or WHY it happenedâ€¦â€¦..no wonder you canâ€™t optimize and scale your Marketing & SDRs

author: Chris Walker
hook: Measuring the ROI of an individual piece of content (like this LinkedIn video, for instance) is not only a huge waste of time, itâ€™s flat out not accur
text:
Measuring the ROI of an individual piece of content (like this LinkedIn video, for instance) is not only a huge waste of time, itâ€™s flat out not accurate. 

Hereâ€™s what to do instead:

1. When it comes to â€œROIâ€, focus on measuring the ROI of the *channel* instead of each individual piece of content. 

You donâ€™t attribute the â€œROIâ€ of your results at the gym all to that 1 set of biceps curls you did 3 months ago. It makes no sense. But thatâ€™s effectively what B2B marketers try to do with content. 

Instead, recognize that the impact is based on the *accumulation* of consistent high quality activities executed over a sustained period of time. 

Itâ€™s easy to see that itâ€™s more appropriate to attribute the â€œROIâ€ of your bicep results to all of the sets of bicep curls youâ€™ve done in life, instead of a single set. 

You can do the same when measuring the success of content - measure the â€œROIâ€ based on the channel/activity. 

For create demand channels, use self-reported attribution. 
For capture demand channels, use software-based attribution. 

Using this method, weâ€™ve attributed $7.3MM ARR to our podcast and $5.1MM ARR to LinkedIn. 

It sounds simple, because it is. 

2. THEN, when it comes to optimizing your content strategy, focus on measuring the *quality* of the activity (e.g. comments, engagement from target customers, DMs received, etc.). 

In the gym, you can measure what type of bicep curl you did, how much weight you used, and how many reps. This isnâ€™t about attribute â€œROIâ€ but instead about measuring the *quality* of the activity. You can do the same with content:

You can read all of the comments & who wrote them (qualitative), you can listen to what people say in the DMs or on Sales calls (qualitative), you can measure engagement like â€œviewsâ€ or â€œlikesâ€. 

These signals help you optimize the activity - what topics resonate with my audience? what is the best time to post? how frequently should I post? Does video or text work better? - You get answers to important questions, but it has nothing to do with proving or measuring â€œROIâ€. 

___

The whole mindset of measuring the â€œROIâ€ of a single piece of content persists from old thinking from the days of blogs and gated e-books in the early 2010s. Thatâ€™s almost a decade ago. When people went into the office, used a desktop computer and consumed content offline in PDF format. 

Things change. 

In todayâ€™s World, itâ€™s time to focus on the bigger picture. 

STOP trying to prove the â€œROIâ€ of each individual piece of content. 

Instead, understand that the results are built through the accumulation of tons of content & touch points over a sustained period of time. 

START measuring the â€œROIâ€ of each channel overall instead of by each individual blog or video. 

#demand #marketing #b2b #sales #content

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Smart B2B companies are FINALLY rethinking their digital advertising strategies.

Why?

Because the traditional playbook of spending $100k/month on Li
text:
Smart B2B companies are FINALLY rethinking their digital advertising strategies.

Why?

Because the traditional playbook of spending $100k/month on LinkedIn ads to promote a gated e-book is clearly not working:

1. UNTENABLE ROI. CAC Payback periods > 60 months on â€œleadsâ€ generated from LinkedIn lead gen campaigns

2. SALES/MARKETING MISALIGNMENT. Sales teams close on average 1 out of 1,000 â€œleadsâ€ from a LinkedIn lead gen campaign. 

3. NO SCALABILITY. The terrible CAC and sales productivity metrics make this advertising strategy absolutely impossible to scale - you burn exponentially more money as you spend more. 

4. GTM BLOAT. The worst symptom of all. GTM costs exponentially inflate because of the low efficiency across the entire GTM engine leading to unprofitable and unsustainable performance. 

So, B2B companies really only have two options:

1. Stop spending money on LinkedIn Ads. Many companies are doing this and cutting $100k/month on LinkedIn ads and moving that money to spend even more on Google Ads. 

For most companies, this isnâ€™t really a solution. The measurable ROI on Google Advertising is also very poor and they are already way past the point of degrading ROI on this channel. 

2. Develop a new strategy for HOW to execute LinkedIn ads. A few smart companies are doing this with massive success, yet the majority of companies canâ€™t do this because of their outdated attribution requirements to deem ROI to a â€œleadâ€. 

__

LinkedIn advertising is the most powerful B2B marketing channel on the planet right now. You can distribute content to the exact decision makers at your target accounts for $0.03 to $0.07 each. 

It's by far the best use of variable marketing dollars compared to alternative investments like building a big tradeshow booth, spending another $100k/month on Google Ads, testing ABM display ads, or all the other large line item expenses on a marketing budget. 

Lots of companies like to blame the channel - "LinkedIn ads don't work." 

When in reality, they need to blame themselves - "Our strategy for LinkedIn ads doesn't work" 

What are you seeing with your LinkedIn ads strategy? How are you measuring success? Let's discuss ðŸ‘‡ 

#marketing #b2b #gtm #linkedinads #advertising

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Hereâ€™s why Iâ€™m confident Exit Five will win (and Iâ€™m not even being arrogant). 

1. We are bootstrapped and profitable. 

I accidentally started this
text:
Hereâ€™s why Iâ€™m confident Exit Five will win (and Iâ€™m not even being arrogant). 

1. We are bootstrapped and profitable. 

I accidentally started this company. It was a â€œcreatorâ€ business first - with my newsletter and podcast in 2019. That was the seed that led to today. Exit Five did $1M in revenue while it was a solo business - which turned out to be the perfect angel investor. I decided to plow the profits into building a team in 2023 so we could build a real company. 

Today we have a full-time team of 6 soon to be 7. Things are growing. But we are in control of our own destiny and can grow at whatever pace I chose as the owner. 

2. We are building a great team. 

The team also gives us optionality here. Anyone whoâ€™s spent enough time in business knows that itâ€™s not a platitude - people are the most improtant ingredient. If you get the team right, you can do anything. 

If our business went to 0 overnight - Iâ€™m confident we could rebuild something new with our team. Iâ€™m also a creator first (since 2014 if you check the receipts) so I like our odds if we ever needed to figure it out. 

3. I donâ€™t give two fucks about the competition. 

Seriously. In all honesty. I like to watch and learn what others are doing - but it does not impact how we move. And thatâ€™s because point number one and two here - we are in control of our destiny, and Iâ€™m bullish on our ability to figure things about. 

But also because itâ€™s not a zero sum game! I see it all the time. People can have multiple memberships to things. I have two gym memberships. I know Exit Five members that have other memberships to professional development groups and communities. 

There is so much freedom in knowing itâ€™s not zero sum. We donâ€™t need to dominate a market. I donâ€™t need to create a new category. Everyone can win and we will too. 

4. We just unlocked something massive over the last year. We are not in the marketing education space. 

Nope. 

We are in the people business. 

We need to have marketing content and education - that is what will bring people in. But we are not out there touting our marketing expertise as being the best or the smartest. So dunk on our marketing takes all you want. 

We are in the business of connecting people who *work in maeketing* and that is the secret sauce. 

We also have thousands of people from around the world who want to share their marketing experience with our community because we have the reach and can amplify their voice in a way they donâ€™t have by writing on their company blog. So we can teach through those experts - and spend our time focused on the people. 

Making IRL (and real online) connections possible - more important than ever today because of AI, slop, and fakes. 

So thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m confident Exit Five will win. 

And I donâ€™t have to work 9-9-6. And my kids will actually know their Dad while I build a great company. 

Plus I do the sauna, cold plunge, ruck, and take creatine so Iâ€™m untouchable as a founder.

author: Adam Robinson
hook: Kyle Poyar just analyzed new data from 6,525 SaaS startups and it's WILD. Only 3.3% reach $1 million ARR in less than a year from first revenue. And j
text:
Kyle Poyar just analyzed new data from 6,525 SaaS startups and it's WILD. Only 3.3% reach $1 million ARR in less than a year from first revenue. And just 1-in-1000 reach $10 million in less than a year!!

Thats not what you'd think if you only listen to VCs on Twitter.

You'd think if you're not at $100M ARR in 6 months you might as well give up.

Kyle partnered with ChartMogul and dug into their dataset on subscription metrics going back 10+ years and here's what he found: 

For startups that reach $1M ARR, it usually takes 2-5 years from monetization. 

1. Only 3.3% of startups reach $1 million in under 1 year
2. 13.4% reach $1 million in under 3 years
3. 25.1% reach that figure within 5 years

You can map yourself onto the curve below (see graphic). 

It takes time to find PMF and move from founder-led sales to repeatable growth. And premature scaling can kill a great business. 

That's why many of the best companies started slow:

- Lovable spent 18 months building before their breakthrough success
- Clay grinded for 6 years before seeing revenue traction
- Bolt spent 7 years to get to $700k ARR before their new product exploded

Tomorrow Kyle (Founder of Growth Unhinged) is joining me on Unf*ck My Startup LIVE to share the realistic playbook for sustainable startup growth.

If you're a founder feeling discouraged by hyper-growth narratives, this session will provide the data-driven clarity and actionable strategies you need to build a long-term, successful startup.

Join us here (3pm ET): https://lnkd.in/gs-Yyc4p

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: I haven't spent real time in the Bay Area since Allbirds were all the rage & T-Swift was still single. Something tells me things are different these d
text:
I haven't spent real time in the Bay Area since Allbirds were all the rage & T-Swift was still single. Something tells me things are different these days.

What brings me back: AI monetization. (Of course.)

I'm still astounded by the rate of change. In only the past few months: 
 - Salesforce introduced a new Flex Credit model for Agentforce
 - OpenAI shifted from seats to pooled credits for their Enterprise plan
 - Cursor introduced a credit-based model
 - Lovable made collaboration free & added rollovers
 - Grok added a $300 per month subscription

But it's hard to know what's really working. And it's unclear what buyers actually want -- aside from, perhaps, more predictability. 

I'm frankly excited to talk about this and learn from the best-of-the-best. I'll be at Monetize 2025 from the crew at Metronome. Pumped to see old friends (ðŸ‘‹ Madhavan, Abde) & online friends (ðŸ‘‹ Scott, Rob, Sam, Chris), plus hopefully make some new friends. 

Let me know if you're in town -- I can't wait to see folks IRL! 

The event is invite-only, but I believe there's some flex capacity. Drop me a DM if you need help getting on the list.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
We are not in the â€œMarketing needs to do more with less eraâ€.Â This narrative is toxic and flat out wrong. 

The real problem is UNIT ECONOMICS. 

---
text:
We are not in the â€œMarketing needs to do more with less eraâ€.Â This narrative is toxic and flat out wrong. 

The real problem is UNIT ECONOMICS. 

---

To achieve proper unit economics, B2B companies must create approximately $10 in pipeline for every $1 they spend on Marketing and SDRs combined. 

Yet, the median performance across 50+ mid-market companies weâ€™ve analyzed is only $3 in pipeline for every $1 in spend. 

That means Marketing needs 3X more budget to hit the desired pipeline goal. And companies need 3X more SDR headcount. 

So, instead of spending $10MM to produce $100MM in pipeline, theyâ€™d need to spend $33MM to produce the same $100MM in pipeline. 

This seemingly subtle difference cascades across the GTM machine and changes total CAC payback periods from approximately 18 months all the way to 50+ months - a crippling blocker to business growth and scalability. 

And even with the inflated spend, they likely still wouldnâ€™t get to the goal since unit economics degrade with scale, especially when executed on accelerated timelines rather than measured and methodically. 

---

TLDR: Marketing doesnâ€™t need more budget to hit the 2025 plan. 

What really needs to happen is for your GTM machine to create pipeline with proper unit economics that lead to scalable efficient growth and target sales quota attainment. 

Spending more money isnâ€™t the answer. Making your existing spend work 2X-3X harder to achieve proper unit economics through smart, focused, disciplined execution is the real solution. 

#gtm #finance #sales #b2b #marketing 

p.s. you can calculate all these KPIs and draw these important conclusions without ever discussing or looking at â€œattributionâ€ ;)

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:

Focus on finding evidence of the problem, then just ask them if that evidence means they a
text:
You canâ€™t personalize your way out of a targeting problem.

Focus on finding evidence of the problem, then just ask them if that evidence means they are struggling with X problem.

This is called a PQS, pain qualified segment, and it will save you from looking like a silly goose trying to personalize a message about a problem your lead doesnâ€™t have or you donâ€™t understand.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
B2B executives donâ€™t realize that department-level source attribution is the *cause* of their pipeline problem, not the solution. 

I sat in yet anoth
text:
B2B executives donâ€™t realize that department-level source attribution is the *cause* of their pipeline problem, not the solution. 

I sat in yet another meeting yesterday where Marketing, Marketing Ops, and Biz Dev leaders debated which attribution model they should useâ€¦..5 minutes in, I wanted to blow my brains out â˜ ï¸ 

I just can't take it anymore. These debates are useless.

The SDR leader wants a first-touch attribution model so SDRs get credit when they load leads into the database, citing that the SDRs get â€œdemoralizedâ€ when they book a meeting that gets tagged as inbound. 

The Marketing team wants it to be â€œMarketing-sourcedâ€ if thereâ€™s any Marketing touch within 45 days. 

The Partner team wants it to get tagged as â€œPartnerâ€ and take precedence over everything when a Partner is involved. 

Every department just fights over credit for sourcing the lead, every department celebrates â€œsourcingâ€ a % of revenue, while the financial planning model breaks down IRL and the company misses growth targets by a mile. 

Then - and this is the hilarious part - they try to fix the problem by changing the attribution model ðŸ˜­ ðŸ˜­ 

Itâ€™s like admitting you have a drug problem, and then deciding to switch from cocaine to meth. 

So, to reinforce the fundamental flaws of this approach: 

1. Using lead source attribution credit by department, regardless of which attribution model you use, is a terribly sub-optimal way to plan, measure, and optimize your GTM when you need to deliver scalable growth aka sustainable unit economics. 

2. Comparing Demand/Marketing (triggers and detects buying signals) with Prospecting (engage buyers 1:1 and book qualified meetings/opps) is like comparing apples to monkeys. They are NOT the same thing and any logical human would arrive at this conclusion with a small amount of critical thinking. 

3. Using this incredibly short-sighted and simplistic planning model forces all Marketing investments to appease the attribution model - skewing investments all to 1 part of the buyer journey (database capture) and causing extreme self-inflicted pain & dysfunction in the Pipeline Creation process. 

4. We should be measuring, comparing and optimizing the effectiveness of our Supply Chain (all of the 1st-party and 3-party signals that enter our Revenue Factory for Prospecting). 

5. We should be measuring, comparing, and optimizing the effectiveness of our Prospecting (all of our efforts to engage buyers 1:1 and create qualified opportunities, including AI, SDRs, and AE prospecting motions). 

___

If you spend just a small amount of time thinking about the current situation, youâ€™ll too see that all of these debates & meetings & tech projects are a total waste of time. 

It's time for C-Level executives to fix the real problem. Stop planning, measuring, and optimizing your GTM like 4 low-quality department-level assembly lines. And start running your GTM like a Unified Revenue Factory. 

#b2b #gtm #marketing #sales #finance

author: Chris Walker
hook:
B2B SaaS revenue growth rates have slowed by over 50% in the past 2 years. 

And CAC Payback periods have skyrocketed by nearly 100% in the same perio
text:
B2B SaaS revenue growth rates have slowed by over 50% in the past 2 years. 

And CAC Payback periods have skyrocketed by nearly 100% in the same period. 

These two effects combined put massive pressure on core financial metrics, business profitability, and enterprise value. 

The root cause of this is Go-To-Market Bloat (GTM Bloat) where B2B companies invest significant money in Sales & Marketing and do not get the appropriate return on investment.

Sales & Marketing is by far the largest expense on a B2B company P&L - on average 40%-60% of total revenue; and 2-3X more than they spend on Product Development, Engineering, and R&D combined.

GTM Bloat occurs across the entire go-to-market, including People, Programs, Process, and Technology.

(1) People - Too many headcount on each GTM team, caused by outdated financial planning models, in addition to the overspecialization of roles on GTM teams (SDR, MDR, Solutions Consultant, AE, Onboarding Manager, CSM, AM, etc.). Or 90-person Marketing team that should actually be 35 people. Average sales quota attainment of ~40% is another clear indicator of headcount bloat.

(2) Programs - This mostly happens in the Marketing budget. B2B companies dramatically overspend on large scale events and digital performance marketing - up to 15% of total revenue - and do not get anywhere close to an appropriate measurable ROI on these significant expenses.

(3) Processes - Teams, meetings, reporting cadences to support programs that donâ€™t work. SDRs to follow up with â€œleadsâ€ and get a meeting less than 1% of the time. Inefficient processes create significant bloat especially when operated at scale.

(4) Technology - Buying an ABM tool for $200k per year and barely using it. So much bloated headcount increases license & seat costs for all SaaS subscriptions by 2-3X. Too many $100k+/year point solutions used by 1 department or team and not integrated or essential to the full GTM.

__

Solving GTM Bloat is the #1 opportunity in a B2B company today to increase enterprise value. This is now a CEO, CFO, and Board Level issue.

Eliminating GTM expenses that do not provide appropriate ROI could increase EBITDA by 20% or more.

Restructuring the existing investments in GTM to deliver the appropriate effectiveness could increase growth rates by up to 2X (e.g. from 18% to 36% YoY).

Or more than likely, the solution is a mix of both of these - eliminating low ROI expenses to improve EBITDA and doubling down on strategies that are already working to create breakthroughs in growth rate.

#gotomarket #gtm #b2b #cfo 

*Benchmarks on public SaaS growth rates and CAC payback periods â„… David Spitz and BenchSights. Shoutout to David for some of the best work in the industry connecting GTM with Business Financial metrics based on actual data (not surveys, anecdotes, or inaccurate aggregated data).

**At Passetto, we see similar, yet more amplified trends in our standardized analyses of CRM and Financial Metrics of private B2B companies.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
What if someone offered you $500 a day to sit in a room filled with a virus?
Would you do it?

What if they added:

-0.05% equity
-10 vacation days
-O
text:
What if someone offered you $500 a day to sit in a room filled with a virus?
Would you do it?

What if they added:

-0.05% equity
-10 vacation days
-One offsite in Florida

Of course not.

But thatâ€™s basically what itâ€™s like to work inside a low-frequency company for $180,000 a year.

The infection just spreads differently.

You donâ€™t catch it through the air.
You catch it through meetings, Slack threads, and investor updates.

You start to absorb it:

-The urgency
-The pressure
-The anxiety
-The constant feeling of not being enough

It spreads on three levels:

Biological: Your body syncs with the stress signals around you.

Behavioral: You mirror the worldviews, emotions, and habits of your environment.

Cultural: The group creates a shared baseline of scarcity, urgency, and pressure.

Thatâ€™s how calm, capable people burn out in a year.
They donâ€™t change overnight. They just adapt to the frequency of the company.

This is a flow of energy that infects the entire ecosystem: 

It starts at the cap table.
Extractive capital pushes for fast growth and quick returns.
The CEO and leaders absorb the pressure.
It flows down to teams who carry it forward.
Vendors, partners, and customers feel it next.

Soon everyone is operating from stress, scarcity, and survival while pretending itâ€™s normal.

It's become "normal" in tech for people to feel this way.
But this is NOT normal.
It's a virus most people don't see (yet).

If you're tired, anxious, or restless even when things look fine on paper, this is why.

You're absorbing the frequency of your work environment, the one you spend most of your life in.

And the cost is far bigger than your paycheck.
It carries with you to your health, well-being, relationships, creativity, confidence, and everything in your life. 

It won't be long until all the best talent flows to high-frequency companies. 

High-frequency companies prioritize impact over external validation. Calm over anxiety. Clarity over urgency. Regeneration over extraction. Originality over comparison. Sustainability over speed. 

They energize and empower everyone (investors, leaders, employees, customers, vendors, partners) in the ecosystem. 

Once top talent feels what it's like to work in a high-frequency environment, they will NEVER work at a low-frequency company again. 

They will become ALLERGIC. And see it for what it really is - Like sitting in a room filled with a virus for $500/day. 

The future belongs to high-frequency companies. 

#frequency #truth #business #leadership

hook:
Steal this upgrade email from Calendly. It's so simple, but so good ðŸ”¥ 

Why I'm digging it:

1. The advantages of upgrading couldn't be more clear

Wi
text:
Steal this upgrade email from Calendly. It's so simple, but so good ðŸ”¥ 

Why I'm digging it:

1. The advantages of upgrading couldn't be more clear

With most products, I don't *really* know the difference between free & paid. Calendly makes it black-and-white. (This would also be very easy to fwd to a manager or anyone who asks "can't you just use the free plan?")

2. They've done the work of recommending a plan

I'm not choosing between 18 permutations of packages and add-ons. "Based on your scheduling needs, the Standard plan seems like a perfect match for you." ðŸ¤Œ

3. They play on loss aversion

Calendly has a reverse trial where new users start with a free 14-day trial, then downgrade to a free forever plan. This gives folks a chance to try things like multiple event types or automated workflows. 

Behavioral psych finds that people value things they own *a lot more* than things they don't.

--

I'm surprised I don't see more upgrade emails like this. Of course, now I probably will...

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook: 17.6 million impressions. The number of times my content showed up on someone's screen in 2025 here on LinkedIn. That is crazy! I'm going to be tellin
text:
17.6 million impressions. The number of times my content showed up on someone's screen in 2025 here on LinkedIn. That is crazy! I'm going to be telling everyone that drunk at our NYE party tonight.

(Kidding, I'll be in bed reading at 9, just wanted to find a good hook for my last post of the year)

2025 was a GREAT year for Exit Five. Took a bunch of lumps along the way, but today I can zoom out and see the whole year and I am proud as hell.

The team rocks, our community is strong, our reach is massive and I genuinely look forward to going to work every week.

We have invested so much in our team, the quality of our products, and the operating system of our company the past year and it shows.

But here's the best part: it's not just vanity metrics. Exit Five has made a meaningful impact on people's careers, professional networks - and as a result their lives (for real! people get jobs through E5, get raises, promotions, realize their boss is crazy and quit their job; they make friends, connections, find customers and more. our impact is very real and I feel it weekly).

Here's to another great year, starting tomorrow.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Results from a Marketing QBR with a $200MM ARR company:

-MQLs: 147% to plan
-Stage 0 Opportunities: 103% to plan
-Qualified Pipeline Creation: 64% to
text:
Results from a Marketing QBR with a $200MM ARR company:

-MQLs: 147% to plan
-Stage 0 Opportunities: 103% to plan
-Qualified Pipeline Creation: 64% to plan
-Sales Quota Attainment: 52% to plan

Marketing crushes their MQL target. Sales misses quota by > 30%.

Why does this happen over and over at B2B companies? Itâ€™s simple.

Because the â€œMQLâ€ marketing metric is not aligned with closed won customers.

And to hit the 4,000 quarterly MQL target, the marketing team needs to do a bunch of stuff that drives high volumes of cheap, low quality leads that donâ€™t buy. All the program budget goes to:

-Content Syndication
-Low Intent Google Ads to drive gated content downloads 
-High volume performance marketing on LinkedIn, Facebook, etc. 
-Pay-per-lead programs 
-Google programmatic display ads and YouTube ads set to optimize for â€œmax conversionsâ€ that drive a bunch of unqualified spam â€œMQLsâ€ into website forms

The solution? Itâ€™s simple.

CHANGE THE GOAL.

The moment the executive team changes the goal from â€œMQLsâ€ to Qualified Pipeline, all of the high volume lead gen tactics that drive significant Sales/Marketing misalignment immediately get thrown out the window.

Why? Because these programs donâ€™t actually drive qualified pipeline. All they do is pump up a made up MQL metric.Â And the data in Salesforce clearly shows this EVERY SINGLE TIME.

Changing the goal to something that actually matters immediately forces a dramatic shift in the Marketing strategy and how investments are deployed.

With many companies facing Marketing budget cuts going into H2, thereâ€™s never been a better time to break the current MQL hamster wheel machine and start building the demand engine that will drive sustainable business growth over the long-haul.

#marketing #b2b #sales #revenue #gtm

author: Chris Walker
hook:
You know something is seriously wrong when a simple statement like â€œCMOs should care about Marketing ROIâ€ is met with extreme resistance. 

â€œBlasphemy
text:
You know something is seriously wrong when a simple statement like â€œCMOs should care about Marketing ROIâ€ is met with extreme resistance. 

â€œBlasphemyâ€ 

â€œClickbaitâ€ 

â€œFocusing on ROI will ruin your Marketingâ€

This is clearly a troublesome reality. 

Especially for CEOs, CFOs, CROs, and PE Investors who understand Finance & Business, and simultaneously recognize that the failure to deliver appropriate Marketing ROI (unit economics) is whatâ€™s stalling growth for their company. 

1. Marketing that doesnâ€™t drive revenue - i.e. create pipeline, increase win rates, or improve retention/expansion - is just arts and crafts. 

You arenâ€™t in Marketing to make a cool video. Or â€œbuild a brandâ€. Or collect a bunch of leads. These are simply intermediate steps en route to deliver the real outcome - revenue growth and enterprise value. We donâ€™t do â€œBrand Marketingâ€ because itâ€™s cool. We do it because, when executed properly, it drives the highest ROI when appropriately balanced with shorter-term strategies and investments. 

Measuring quarterly progress on TTM Marketing ROI is the most objective way to measure this. And you should be making positive strides and continuous improvement every single quarter. 

2. This wild reaction demonstrates that some Marketers are so closed-minded, that they refuse to even consider the validity and importance of this reality. 

Measuring the ROI on your GTM investments is totally different than trying to use attribution to measure the impact of an individual investment or channel. Take a step back and consider how *Business KPIs* differ from *Marketing Attribution*. 

3. It demonstrates that a lot of Marketers donâ€™t really understand how business & finance works. 

SaaS companies that deliver high ROI on their Sales and Marketing investments receive a median 10X TTM Revenue Multiple. While SaaS companies that deliver low ROI receive a median 3.6X TTM Revenue Multiple.

So, delivering high ROI on Sales & Marketing investments makes a potential difference of $640MM in enterprise value for your $100MM ARR company ($360MM at low ROI vs. $1B at high ROI). 

â€”

So, please tell me again that optimizing for appropriate ROI on Sales & Marketing investments doesnâ€™t matter ðŸ™‚ 

#finance #sales #b2b #marketing #gtm 

Any CMO that says they donâ€™t care about ROI should not be a C-Level executive.

Because the â€œCâ€ in CMO means you are a BUSINESS LEADER first and the way you deliver business results is through the strategic execution of Marketing.

Great CMOs inherently understand this. An over-titled VP usually doesnâ€™t. 

And FWIWâ€¦.. Growth = Investment x ROI 

So anyone that cares about â€œGrowthâ€ must fundamentally care about ROI unless they have a never-ending piggy bank to blow money until the end of time.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Signal-based selling is the future of B2B go-to-market. 

The first wave was the movement to account-based (Right Fit). 

And the next wave thatâ€™s com
text:
Signal-based selling is the future of B2B go-to-market. 

The first wave was the movement to account-based (Right Fit). 

And the next wave thatâ€™s coming on strong right now is signal-based (Right Time). 

Signals are signs of intent that our buyers (people and/or accounts) send us that indicate some type of interest. 

Every time your SDR or Sales team takes an action to engage with a prospective customer, there is a â€œsignalâ€ that drives that action. Example signals might be:

Website - Demo Request
MQL Score
Intent Data - First Party - Pricing Page Visit
ZoomInfo - Cold Lead
Webinar Attendee
Intent Data - Third Party - G2
Intent Data - Third Party - UsergemsÂ 
Website - Content Download - XYZ E-Book
LinkedIn - Content Download - Lead Gen Form

And for a mature, developed B2B company, over a year, they would collect literally millions of data points around this.

Signal -> Sales Action -> Disposition (Recycled, Meeting Booked, Qualified Pipe, Closed Won)

And when you analyze those 1 million data points, you see clear patterns around what intent signals lead to high sales productivity, closed won revenue & sales velocity.

Conversely, you quickly see all the signals that Sales & SDRs take action on that are completely unproductive - total waste.

This data & insight are critically important to all GTM leaders. Because Sales resources are the most expensive resources in the entire company. And triggering them to take action on low quality signals means:

-We are wasting significant Marketing program and headcount investments to create buyer signals that donâ€™t drive revenue.

-We have (sometimes extreme) excess of Sales & SDR headcount to take actions that are clearly unproductive and donâ€™t lead to results.

-We likely have serious revenue leak in our early stage sales process because we blend tons of low quality leads with a small amount of high quality ones.

The problem? Most B2B companies, even highly successful ones, donâ€™t track this data!

Hereâ€™s how to fix it in less than 30 days:

1. Every time your Sales team takes an action, automatically log the data of WHY they did it (what was the signal that triggered our Sales team to take an action).

2. Track the OUTCOME of every time your Sales team takes action. And then track it all the way to Recycled / Close.

3. Aggregate and analyze the data and find the patterns.

Once youâ€™ve collected a meaningful amount of data, you will see clear patterns on what buyer intent signals lead to high sales productivity and which signals are entirely a waste of time for Sales to engage.

4. Optimize your entire GTM investments and strategy related to Intent Capture based on this data.

_____

In this new era of EFFICIENT GROWTH, we need to use DATA to optimize processes, identify and cut waste, and adjust investments.

Department-level analytics don't tell the full story. We need to look at the data as a HOLISTIC GTM - not analytics & data silo'd by departments.

#gtm #marketing #sales #b2b #sdr

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
I have a serious question, this is not a bit. Looking for genuine answers: 

Consumer brands (ex: GoRuck, Vuori) just hammer me with emails. Daily. Of
text:
I have a serious question, this is not a bit. Looking for genuine answers: 

Consumer brands (ex: GoRuck, Vuori) just hammer me with emails. Daily. Often more than once. It just is expected. So many emails. So just move them to the trash because I am too lazy to unsubscribe (oh dont roll your eyes at me you know you do that too sometimes; in my mind its quicker to delete it! anyway).

But in B2B. If we send more than two emails a WEEK to someone, Bob is ready to jump through my inbox, grab me around the neck and scream HOW DID I GET ON YOUR STUPID LIST!?!?!

So what is different? Is it just we (me? since Im the crazy got not unsubscribing from emails) expect constant sales emails from consumer products? But not like payroll software?

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Random Sunday LinkedIn bullets:

â€¢ I love when people shit on LinkedIn. This app has made me more connections than X or IG or YouTube or Facebook. Mea
text:
Random Sunday LinkedIn bullets:

â€¢ I love when people shit on LinkedIn. This app has made me more connections than X or IG or YouTube or Facebook. Meaningful connections. Candidates. Partners. Friends. Itâ€™s influenced millions in revenue. I love when people dunk on LinkedIn. 

â€¢ The worst feature ever created on this app is the â€œCongrats on your work anniversary featureâ€ I have 52 DMs right now for my two year anniversary as an investor with GTM fund, so Iâ€™ll miss any meaningful DMs. 

â€¢ I believe in the power of speaking things into existence. Your mind is an incredible tool and you can will yourself into and out of almost anything. Iâ€™m working to pass this onto my children. I tell them how great they are. How smart they are. How capable they are. They will carry this with them forever. They will know Dad was supportive and their biggest fan. I donâ€™t care if you think it makes me soft. 

â€¢ You are nothing without discipline. What do you do when no one is watching? Are you getting up early? Working out? Everyone will make excuses. Few will make it a way of life. 30 minutes a day can change the quality of your life - your mood, your energy, your creativity, your stress. Why would you not make the time for that? 

â€¢ B2B marketing is not boring. Thatâ€™s just a fun clickbait line we like to use to dunk on each other here. I donâ€™t see how selling yet another seltzer online or hoodies is somehow â€œcoolerâ€ than B2B. Weâ€™ve met thousands of entrepreneurs and companies through Exit Five doing legitimately interesting things in B2B. So stop the B2B is not boring stuff. 

â€¢ One of the hardest parts about being a leader is having to sometimes sit back and let others shit on you online because you canâ€™t tell the truth - because it does me no good to expose someone else online, so I just have to sit there and let some guy roast me for something. Or some other guy tell people Iâ€™m an asshole - yet weâ€™ve never met! The best thing to happen to E5 in the last 2 years is in person because I get to look people in the eye, shake hands, and be real people in person. Everyone is smarter than you and better than you on the internet :) 

â€¢ I think most companies are stuck using marketing as defense. When the right way to deploy marketing is as OFFENSE. The Founder / CEO must care deeply about marketing because marketing is sales if you really understand it that way. Use marketing to play offense not defense. And sometimes the best marketing plays are not crazy - sometimes itâ€™s quiet literally going to the side of the street that is not as crowded and selling your product over there. 

â€¢ Copywritijg is Still to this day the number one marketing skill that has paid off the most for me. Communication is the most important skill in business, especially with all the AI SLOP SLOP
SLOP that is out there. Iâ€™ll continue to stand out by writing real words with my thumbs from my iPhone in my own voice. 

Just had a major hip surgery and Iâ€™m all jacked up on meds !!!!!

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: ChatGPT just hit 800 million weekly active users, up from 500 million in March. AI discovery is the fastest-growing channel to reach your customers. B
text:
ChatGPT just hit 800 million weekly active users, up from 500 million in March. AI discovery is the fastest-growing channel to reach your customers. But more than that, it forces us to rethink buyer journeys for AI discovery.

The team at Docebo told me AI discovery now accounts for 12.7% of their high-intent leads, up 429% (!) from last year. They're doing this with one dedicated team member (Valeriia) plus an assist from AI tools like AirOps & XFunnel.

Here's the thing: ChatGPT leads don't look like SEO or referral leads. 

They show up ready to buy, either going to your website directly (*after* they've made a decision) or searching for your brand on Google. Branded search now accounts for 85% (!) of Docebo's search traffic -- meaning 85% who come from Google already know about the company.

â–¶ï¸ The old buyer journey: Problem awareness > feature research > vendor comparison > brand selection. 

â–¶ï¸ The new buyer journey: AI-assisted research > network validation > direct brand search > selection. 

Read more in Growth Unhinged about what this means & how to get more pipeline from AI search: https://lnkd.in/ee2wKTbR

The TL;DR:
1. Measure your AI search performance through self-reportedÂ attribution, branded search traffic, and share-of-voice in AI queries.
2. Late-funnel SEO is the foundation for great answer engine optimization (AEO).
3. The dirty work of AEO has to get done: updating, formatting, and structuring content for LLMs.
4. You can see tangible AEO results with a modern tech stack.

#aeo #ai #seo
