author: Chris Walker
hook:
B2B executives donâ€™t realize that department-level source attribution is the *cause* of their pipeline problem, not the solution. 

I sat in yet anoth
text:
B2B executives donâ€™t realize that department-level source attribution is the *cause* of their pipeline problem, not the solution. 

I sat in yet another meeting yesterday where Marketing, Marketing Ops, and Biz Dev leaders debated which attribution model they should useâ€¦..5 minutes in, I wanted to blow my brains out â˜ ï¸ 

I just can't take it anymore. These debates are useless.

The SDR leader wants a first-touch attribution model so SDRs get credit when they load leads into the database, citing that the SDRs get â€œdemoralizedâ€ when they book a meeting that gets tagged as inbound. 

The Marketing team wants it to be â€œMarketing-sourcedâ€ if thereâ€™s any Marketing touch within 45 days. 

The Partner team wants it to get tagged as â€œPartnerâ€ and take precedence over everything when a Partner is involved. 

Every department just fights over credit for sourcing the lead, every department celebrates â€œsourcingâ€ a % of revenue, while the financial planning model breaks down IRL and the company misses growth targets by a mile. 

Then - and this is the hilarious part - they try to fix the problem by changing the attribution model ðŸ˜­ ðŸ˜­ 

Itâ€™s like admitting you have a drug problem, and then deciding to switch from cocaine to meth. 

So, to reinforce the fundamental flaws of this approach: 

1. Using lead source attribution credit by department, regardless of which attribution model you use, is a terribly sub-optimal way to plan, measure, and optimize your GTM when you need to deliver scalable growth aka sustainable unit economics. 

2. Comparing Demand/Marketing (triggers and detects buying signals) with Prospecting (engage buyers 1:1 and book qualified meetings/opps) is like comparing apples to monkeys. They are NOT the same thing and any logical human would arrive at this conclusion with a small amount of critical thinking. 

3. Using this incredibly short-sighted and simplistic planning model forces all Marketing investments to appease the attribution model - skewing investments all to 1 part of the buyer journey (database capture) and causing extreme self-inflicted pain & dysfunction in the Pipeline Creation process. 

4. We should be measuring, comparing and optimizing the effectiveness of our Supply Chain (all of the 1st-party and 3-party signals that enter our Revenue Factory for Prospecting). 

5. We should be measuring, comparing, and optimizing the effectiveness of our Prospecting (all of our efforts to engage buyers 1:1 and create qualified opportunities, including AI, SDRs, and AE prospecting motions). 

___

If you spend just a small amount of time thinking about the current situation, youâ€™ll too see that all of these debates & meetings & tech projects are a total waste of time. 

It's time for C-Level executives to fix the real problem. Stop planning, measuring, and optimizing your GTM like 4 low-quality department-level assembly lines. And start running your GTM like a Unified Revenue Factory. 

#b2b #gtm #marketing #sales #finance

text:
Your official 2025 SaaS benchmarks cheat sheet is here â¤µ

I started the SaaS benchmarks report at OpenView nine years ago now (!). Since then we've surveyed 5,000+ private B2B software companies including 800+ this year alone. I'm so excited to team up with High Alpha on the 2025 report and it *just* dropped.

Here's what GOOD and GREAT looks like by ARR band:

EARLY STAGE (<$1M ARR)
Â - Growth: 100% (good), 300% (great)
Â - NRR: 100% (good), 116% (great)
Â - ARR per FTE: $55k (good), $100k (great)

^Top quartile growth is up over 2024 & 2023. Gross margins are down by ~5-10pts.

EARLY GROWTH ($1M-$5M ARR)
Â - Growth: 50% (good), 100% (great)
Â - NRR: 104% (good), 110% (great)
Â - ARR per FTE: $135k (good), $200k (great)

GROWTH STAGE ($5M-$20M ARR)
Â - Growth: 30% (good), 70% (great)
Â - NRR: 104% (good), 110% (great)
Â - ARR per FTE: $165k (good), $220k (great)

SCALEUP ($20M-$50M ARR)
Â - Growth: 30% (good), 40% (great)
Â - NRR: 103% (good), 110% (great)
Â - ARR per FTE: $270k (good), $350k (great)

^Later stage companies are growing at about the same rate as last year, but they're doing so with far fewer employees. Best-in-class ARR per employee jumped by 42% for companies with $20M-$50M ARR.

I unpacked my biggest takeaways in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/eWSsZMWX

Read the highlights then don't miss the full report (see the comments ðŸ‘€). Hope you find it useful ðŸ™

THANK YOU for your support & a big shoutout to Scott Dorsey, Blake Koriath & Mollie Kuramoto for doing the heavy lifting!

---

Today's newsletter is supported by Metronome, which just launched three ðŸ”¥ new monetization infrastructure capabilities (link in comments).

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Spending more money â‰  More results. 

The real problem is UNIT ECONOMICS. 

To achieve proper unit economics, B2B companies need to create approx $10
text:
Spending more money â‰  More results. 

The real problem is UNIT ECONOMICS. 

To achieve proper unit economics, B2B companies need to create approx $10 in pipeline for every $1 they spend on Marketing and SDRs combined. 

Yet, the median performance across 50+ mid-market companies weâ€™ve analyzed is approx $3 in pipeline for every $1 in spend. 

That means Marketing needs 3X more budget to hit the desired pipeline goal. And companies need 3X more SDR headcount. 

Instead of spending $10MM to produce $100MM in pipeline, theyâ€™d need to spend $33MM to produce the same $100MM in pipeline. 

And even with the inflated spend, they likely still wouldnâ€™t get there since unit economics degrade with scale, especially when executed on accelerated timelines rather than measured and methodically. 

TLDR: Marketing doesnâ€™t need more budget to hit the 2025 plan. What really needs to happen is for your GTM machine to create pipeline with proper unit economics that lead to profitable efficient growth and target sales quota attainment. 

Spending more money isnâ€™t the answer. Making your existing spend work 2X-3X harder through smart, focused, disciplined execution is the real solution. 

#finance #b2b #gtm #sales #marketing

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
ICYMI: Automation doesnâ€™t need to mean more spray-and-pray. Here are my favorite automated GTM plays youâ€™re not running â¤µï¸

Signal-based plays
1. Warm
text:
ICYMI: Automation doesnâ€™t need to mean more spray-and-pray. Here are my favorite automated GTM plays youâ€™re not running â¤µï¸

Signal-based plays
1. Warm outbound campaign targeting recent (de-anonymized) website visitors
2. Competitor displacement campaign w/ tech stack signals
3. Customers' competitor outbound campaign referencing a use case you believe is relevant to the industry
4. 'Look-a-like' outbound campaign targeting similar companies to recent closed-won customers
5. â€˜Look-a-likeâ€™ LinkedIn ad campaign targeting the same companies & reinforcing the outbound message
6. Outbound campaign targeting former bosses of recent job switchers
7. Outbound campaign targeting companies that have recently posted relevant jobs
8. Geo-specific outbound campaign referencing an upcoming/recent event

Warm outbound plays
9. Prospect re-engagement campaign w/ past prospects who've changed companies
10. Prospect re-engagement campaign w/ closed-lost deals from 9 months ago (referencing what was discussed on the last call)
11. Champion outreach campaign w/ past champions who've changed companies
12. ICP-fit warm intro campaign w/ the prior companies of existing champions
13. ICP-fit warm intro campaign w/ mutual investors
14. 'Alumni' outbound campaign w/ the prior employees of new flagship customers

Personalization plays
15. Prospect research brief ahead of 1st call pulling in recent events and/or competitive intel
16. Account-specific landing pages with personalized copy
17. Outbound campaign including a "1:1 video" (automated) made specifically for that prospect

Social plays
18. LinkedIn connection request campaign referencing past posts
19. Influencer/creator list build based on LinkedIn activity of existing users

Product-led plays
20. Product-led outbound campaign targeting an exec buyer when there are multiple accounts from the same domain (roll-up play)
21. Product-led sales campaign reaching out to non-users within an account that has 1+ existing existing user
22. Product-led sales campaign targeting Admins when a free account reaches an â€˜aha momentâ€™ in the product
23. Product-led sales campaign targeting Admins when a free account visits a high-intent website page (integrations, enterprise landing page, pricing page)

Expansion plays
24. Expansion campaign leveraging product usage data indicating the account is approaching limits (usage, seats, credits)
25. Expansion campaign offering product assistance when an account begins a free trial of an upsell package

The future of automated GTM: 
 - the highly relevant, precise targeting of ABX
 - the efficiency gains from AI & web-scraping
 - the ability to get real-life data from GTM experiments

Shoutout to Brendan Short for the ðŸ”¥ collab. Don't miss the full post here: https://lnkd.in/e2q2B3sn

PS, Growth Unhinged is off this week (OOO ðŸ˜´). Back next Wednesday at 6:50am!

#ai #gtm #gtmengineering

author: Josh Braun
hook: Robert Kiyosaki said that 9 out of 10 businesses fail, so he came up with a foolproof plan - create ten businesses. Similar to his approach, businesse
text:
Robert Kiyosaki said that 9 out of 10 businesses fail, so he came up with a foolproof plan - create ten businesses. Similar to his approach, businesses can hedge against failure, by: 
1) Creating an idea
2) Take it to market and test as quickly as possible
3) If it has traction, learn why and get feedback; if it doesnâ€™t have traction, try something else
4) Once something sticks, improve it and make it better
5) Put your sales force behind it and then go ALL IN

Too many businesses wait until the idea is perfect, get analysis paralysis or they fear failing. By the time they are ready to launch, another competitor has already brought something to market and theyâ€™ve lost the opportunity. 

Be agile, move quickly and sooner or later (maybe by the 10th one) an idea will stick!

author: Chris Walker
hook: B2B Companies spend thousands of collective hours analyzing data and building QBR reports, and still donâ€™t know whether their Marketing is working or
text:
B2B Companies spend thousands of collective hours analyzing data and building QBR reports, and still donâ€™t know whether their Marketing is working or not. 

The CRO thinks they have a pipeline problem and is down-forecasting Q1, but doesnâ€™t know why or how to fix it. 

The CFO sees CAC going up for 3 straight quarters but canâ€™t pinpoint why. 

The CEO sees Growth Rate slowing down and is now getting pressure from investors. 

And the Marketing Team presents a 120-slide QBR report filled with tactical, confusing data that nobody can understand. 

The company spends thousands of hours building these reports and afterward, thereâ€™s still no alignment on what to do next. 

___

At companies > $50MM, this resource drain and lack of strategic clarity is a 9-figure problem hiding in plain sight. 

This leads to either: 

(1) Inaction - Change nothing because itâ€™s not clear what to do. 

(2) Uninformed Investments - to try to keep up growth rate, we spend more money but not intelligently and confidently based on data. The problem compounds 1-2 quarters later and becomes even harder to unwind.  

____

Your Go-To-Market KPI stack should: 

-Quickly, confidently isolate the biggest issue / opportunity in your entire go-to-market.Â 
-Easily, quickly, confidently evaluate the performance of your Marketing investments.Â 
-Tell you exactly how many SDR headcount you need 
-Align your entire executive team on the current performance, historical trends, and biggest opportunities.Â 
-Provide extreme strategic clarity around the fastest path to Growth and increased EV 

____

We have done 50+ of these analyses with middle-market companies in the past 12 months Passetto. 

In less than 2 weeks, the Passetto GTM KPI Stack answers all these questions. 

And the best part?â€¦.it has nothing to do with attribution.Â The data is OBJECTIVE. 

So instead of spending 3 hours debating the attribution model or questioning the data quality, we can spend the 3 hours figuring out the strategic plan and investments for how we move our #1 metric and add hundreds of millions of dollars in value to the business. 

These conclusions are *obvious* when you use ditch the old department-oriented demand waterfall model circa 2012 and instead analyze & optimize your GTM like itâ€™s a revenue factory.

#gotomarket #gtm #finance #marketing #b2b 

p.s. The Marketing team can't fix this. If CEOs, CFOs, and Boards want better performance from their Marketing investments, they need to change the KPI stack for how Marketing and the rest of GTM are evaluated & optimized.

text:
FOLLOW FRIDAY - you remember that? From the early days of Twitter.

I'm bringing it back. I just decided.

Some people for you to follow:

1. Allison Saxon - she runs events on our team at Exit Five; she is responsible for Drive, Marketing Leadership Retreat, and all of our workshops, meet-ups and dinners around the U.S. this year.

2. Anthony Blatner - he runs Speedwork, a LinkedIn Ads agency. We met through Exit Five, and Anthony and his team have been running our LinkedIn ads for the last year and we have seen insane results through the combination of organic + Thought Leader ads.

3. Ding Zheng - he runs Eventshark, a great video production company for B2B. We became friends through work and our love of music and fitness. Now he's texting me from China sending verses at 3 AM or giving me a random idea. Good people, and since 2024 he's become so much more than "the sales rapper."

4. Jess Cook - recently promoted to VP of Marketing at Vector, OG Exit Five member, and we had a great podcast session yesterday. I got to ask Jess about how they are doing influencer marketing, the ROI of having a podcast at work, and her path from content marketer to VP Marketing. Plus some talk about kids and work and managing it all.

5. Louis Grenier - cancer survivor and marketing genius; reminded me why I love marketing in the first place this week after recording a podcast on how to stand out. And yes, you can even stand out in B2B.

6. Erik Jacobson - founder of Hatch (video/podcast production company), and has been my podcast partner for the last ... five years maybe? Yes podcasting "works" yes even in B2B yes you don't need a huge audience to feel something from this. This guy has given me so much wisdom on strategy here, and his company has helped run my podcast for years and i would have quit three times without them. Also just a good person, which means the world.

Those are just some of the people on my mind this week (just looking back at my calendar on this Friday morning and trying to see where the week went)

Feel free to continue this in the comments. I'm always looking for new people to follow here, who had your attention this week?

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
Today I'm roasting your pricing model:

FLAT-FEE SUBSCRIPTIONS ("Don't expect to make $$")
 - Small companies get priced out
 - Large companies pay to
text:
Today I'm roasting your pricing model:

FLAT-FEE SUBSCRIPTIONS ("Don't expect to make $$")
 - Small companies get priced out
 - Large companies pay too little
 - No expansion revenue
 - Highest potential for low/negative margin customers

SEAT-BASED PRICING ("Isn't that a dated relic?")
 - Most product features don't scale naturally w/ seats
 - Not all users are the same
 - Customers aren't necessarily growing headcount, esp w/ AI

USAGE-BASED PRICING ("CFOs hate it")
 - Hard to forecast/predict
 - Not all usage results in ROI
 - Not always a clear usage metric that = value

HYBRID PRICING ("I'm gonna need a PhD to figure out the price")
 - Too much complexity
 - Hard to calculate/understand costs
 - Hard to manage internally

OUTCOME-BASED PRICING ("It's a pipe dream")
 - Measuring outcomes
 - Success attribution
 - Negotiating what the outcomes will be upfront

---

There's no such thing as a perfect pricing model. 

Find the model that allows you to tell the unique story of what you do, who you're for & why you're better. And have a plan to manage the downsides.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: I donâ€™t usually share my LinkedIn hacks, but hereâ€™s what helped me reach 90,000+ followers (up 62% y/y) and 14 million impressions in the past year. (
text:
I donâ€™t usually share my LinkedIn hacks, but hereâ€™s what helped me reach 90,000+ followers (up 62% y/y) and 14 million impressions in the past year. (All of that reach cost me exactly $0.)

Hope this helps more folks tap into the ðŸª„ of the algo. 

1. Your first step on LinkedIn isnâ€™t to post, itâ€™s to comment.

Find 5-10 great thought leaders in your niche. Authentically engage with their posts, esp in the first hour.Â You'd be surprised how helpful this is in the early days -- and how few people do it.

2. Original graphics go a LONG way. 

The best performers for me: original data/research, screenshots that have been marked up. Think infographic-style, even if it's not really an infographic. You want to draw folks in & let them come to their own conclusions. Sankey diagrams are always ðŸ”¥ 

3. Don't worry so much about putting a link in your post.

What matters is that you writeÂ zero-click content, i.e. the post has standalone value and folks donâ€™t need to click on an external link in order to appreciate it. To be honest with you, about 50% of my posts now include links.

4. Keep to a consistent schedule of ideally 2-3+ posts per week. Sunday mornings work best for me (have no idea why!).

But don't worry about trying to post every day. Who has that much new to say, anyway?

5. Find a counterintuitive perspective. 

What's nobody saying that you will go to your grave defending? What's your pet peeve that folks are still doing?Â This doesn't need to be a hot take. Usually it isn't.

6. You can repurpose your greatest hits. Odds are most of your audience didn't see it the first time around.

I waited too long to do this. Now I try to refresh/repost on a ~6-12 month cadence & look for times when the post becomes topical again or for when I think of a better hook.

---

Full deep dive in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/ekvcbV2P

PS, if you've got LinkedIn questions, drop them in the comments & I'll share my two cents!

#linkedin #creator #marketing

We've been running a super secret group for CMOs / VP Marketing doing $10M+ ARR

Started building it out in the spring and we launched the first group over the summer; we have a group of CMOs and marketing leaders doing $10M - $100M+ in revenue.

A CMO friend of mine reached out and wanted something more than the current Exit Five membership; she wanted a group of peers - a truly private place to share, connect, get unstuck.

â€¢ Every member signs an NDA to keep things private (so you can feel comfortable sharing org charts, budgets, venting about the CEO)

â€¢ You give us a list of 1-2 direct competitors that you do not want to be a member in the group, so you don't have to worry about any spies

â€¢ We have proven we can build an amazing community; we'll continue to do that - but now we're carving out a space top CMOs specifically, and the early results have been amazing. I keep asking Matt and Dan why we didn't start this earlier.

A bunch of top CMOs you know already in there. We put you in a group to start so you can quickly meet a bunch of people; we have a few proven formats for calls that you'll actually want to join.

Then you have a private space (Slack) to share ideas, post questions, get feedback. We've already built out a directory of tools, agencies, vendors that our top CMOs are using. Members are meeting on their own to discuss PLG strategy, how to re-design their bloated org chat, and how to set expectations with the board about AI.

I'm super bullish about this smaller group for Exit Five CMOs, and decided to break the plan internally and make a video about it this morning after I dropped my kids off at school.

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook: Great marketers know how to take inspiration from everywhere. They are curious. Creative. Scrappy. They don't need "B2B marketing examples" to underst
text:
Great marketers know how to take inspiration from everywhere. They are curious. Creative. Scrappy. They don't need "B2B marketing examples" to understand what might work in a B2B context.

I think one of the best parts of the job is marketing is that the ingredients are almost always different. Open the fridge and you've got to make a meal with three eggs, half a bagel, and an onion. But then at another company, the fridge is stocked full with fresh produce, grass fed beef, and a freshly tapped keg of kombucha (or something like that).

At each company the ingredients are different. Some companies are well funded. Some have no funding. Some companies have proven CEOs. Some have first-time CEOs. Sometimes you can attract Tier 1 talent (ex: Anthropic right now) and sometimes you can't because of the things i wrote before this; you might have to figure out how to start with Tier 3 talent and make it work. Some companies are in super regulated industries. Some have fewer rules.

But this is what's FUN. There is no formula. It's always different. Channels that worked for one company don't work for another.

This is the craft of marketing.

"Put me anywhere on God's Green Earth, I could triple my worth." - Jay-Z

That is how great marketers think too.

Any company, any stage, any industry - they could figure it out.

author: Chris Walker
hook: In 2019, I was one of the first people to post video content on LinkedIn consistently, and 5 years later, it paid off BIG. Hereâ€™s why I did it (and it
text:
In 2019, I was one of the first people to post video content on LinkedIn consistently, and 5 years later, it paid off BIG. Hereâ€™s why I did it (and itâ€™s not the reason you might think): 

Many people think I had some grand plan about video content. That it would be the future of LinkedIn and I saw something that other people didnâ€™t see. 

But thatâ€™s not the case.Â In reality, it was so much more simple than that. 

I started posting mostly video content in August 2019 because tons of people plagiarized all my written content. 

Iâ€™d post content and wake up the next day to a half dozen people copying verbatim my exact post. Someone in the UK would just straight copy and paste it. Someone in Germany would translate it to German and write the same thing. Lots of people called it out but LinkedIn did nothing about it. 

So I thought to myself, they canâ€™t copy a video. My face. My voice. My depth of understanding.Â So that's what I did. 

Video content created a whole new level of trust and credibility for me on LinkedIn because you can see and feel my understanding of the topics, my ability to explain them down to the exact metrics and root cause, and my conviction in the ideas based on tons of large-scale data. 

___

Lots of people still copy my content today. But now itâ€™s happening differently for me and many other companies and thought leaders. 

Now people are copying my messaging. They trademark my language. They steal my ideas. 

But put most people to the test - put them in front of a crowd for a live Q&A. Theyâ€™ll get detailed questions and break like cheap glass. 

Because itâ€™s easy to copy words that someone else said. Itâ€™s not easy to fake truly understanding the market, the metrics, the concepts. 

Be warned: this already happens a lot in product marketing / messaging and will continue to accelerate. Everyone copies each other. Itâ€™s never been easier to change the copy on your homepage. 

One day theyâ€™re an ABM tool. The next day they sell intent data. The next day they are Sales Automation AI. They can keep jumping from messaging trend to messaging trend, copying whatever seems to be sticking as the flavor of the week. 

Because of this, there will be (itâ€™s already happening) a huge shift in how product marketing works. In the future, the only things that matter are:

1. What your actual customers say about you to your prospective customersÂ 
2. What your content consumers and community members say about you to your target market 

People will look at your website. But most people arenâ€™t going to believe what youâ€™re saying there. People will talk to your Sales rep (since they have to in most cases), but most arenâ€™t going to believe them either.Â Or your fancy messaging deck. 

They will get the real information from your customers, content consumers, and community members. 

Because thatâ€™s one of the only trustworthy, believable sources of information left in B2B SaaS/Tech industry. 

#marketing #productmarketing #b2b

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Everything in Marketing â€œworksâ€ to some extent. The real question is what is the impact relative to the investment (ROI). 

When evaluating Marketing
text:
Everything in Marketing â€œworksâ€ to some extent. The real question is what is the impact relative to the investment (ROI). 

When evaluating Marketing & Sales programs, itâ€™s not a binary decision of whether this thing â€œworksâ€ or not.

Itâ€™s actually a spectrum - how well does it work? Or perhaps better framed as what is the ROI on this particular investment? 

You can see these binary statements of "works" and "doesn't work" all over LinkedIn and in Marketing QBR decks. A few examples:

1. â€œOutbound is deadâ€. 

No, outbound sales prospecting isnâ€™t dead. The average B2B company we analyze captures in-market demand via Outbound to deliver 24% of new business revenue. The real problem is that companies are way over-invested in these programs and the ROI is poor. 

The real solution is to reduce investments in the Outbound programs relative to the results to improve ROI in the short-term. Then, adjust the Outbound strategy to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the program over time - continuously increasing ROI. 

2. â€œPaid search works for usâ€ 

Sure, paid search delivers attributed pipeline & revenue for most B2B companies that invest there. But the measurable ROI of this channel is usually super low. Most B2B companies we analyze get less than $0.50 in new business revenue for every $1 spent on Google paid search (> 2 year Marketing CAC payback, > 4 year total CAC payback). 

With that type of ROI performance, itâ€™s simply inaccurate to just say â€œpaid search worksâ€. The reality is most companies are losing money for every transaction via paid search. 

3. â€œPodcasting doesnâ€™t workâ€

B2B companies donâ€™t see Podcast showing up for leads in Attribution software and therefore make the binary call that Podcasting doesnâ€™t work. The real problem is how itâ€™s measured. Podcasting is a relatively low investment compared to programs like Paid Search or Tradeshow Booths, and therefore can deliver outsized ROI. 

One major issue is that Attribution does not factor in the cost/investment and therefore cannot make an informed decision of how well the programs are actually working. 

___

The days of deeming a GTM program â€œworkingâ€ just because you closed a few deals attributed to it are over. All GTM programs now need to deliver results at the appropriate ROI relative to the investment. 

___

Iâ€™m excited for the evolution from Attribution to GTM Investment Analytics. You should be evaluating GTM investments through multiple lenses and data sets to make strategic decisions. Digital touchpoint attribution should weigh like 20% but most companies still weigh it 100% leading to strategic decisions and investment allocations that are often ineffective and donâ€™t align to what customers do or want. 

#GTM #B2B #Marketing #Sales #Attribution

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Contrary to popular belief, having a GTM team offsite will not fix your go-to-market problem. 

Neither will a pipeline meeting on Wednesdays. 

Neith
text:
Contrary to popular belief, having a GTM team offsite will not fix your go-to-market problem. 

Neither will a pipeline meeting on Wednesdays. 

Neither will a CMO-CRO bi-weekly coffee meeting. 

Neither will firing your CMO and trying to hire a unicorn marketing leader. 

Itâ€™s a Band-Aid. 

It might make it easier for people to work together. 

It might patch up the problem for a while that will come back to you in 3 months when youâ€™re missing your pipeline for Q4. 

Itâ€™s a Band-Aid. 

The real solution? 

Redesign your GTM (aka the Factory that produces your revenue) - Starting with Financial Planning, Modeling, and Budgeting, and then working across the rest of GTM team to Sales, Marketing, Sales Dev, Ops, Post-Sale, etc. 

1. Build a Unified View of GTM with Financial Data & GTM Data that measures both performance (effectiveness) and unit economics (efficiency)

2. Align the entire GTM leadership team on a core KPI stack that has *nothing* to do with attribution by department or channel 

3. Categorize and evaluate GTM investment portfolio allocation by customer lifecycle stage, NOT DEPARTMENT. 

4. Methodically break down compound metrics to isolate the biggest issues / risks / opportunities by customer lifecycle stage

5. Build and align on cross-functional initiatives to solve the biggest issues in your Revenue Factory 

6. Monitor and evaluate impact against the core KPI stack that has nothing to do with attribution by department or channel. 

#finance #gtm #gotomarket #sales #b2b

p.s. Just to drive home the message - you should be able to *clearly* understand how your GTM is performing and isolate the biggest issues/opportunities without ever discussing or using attribution by channel or department ðŸ™‚

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Made a ton of changes to Exit Five last 365 days: 

1. More in person stuff. Big events. Medium events. Dinners. Hikes. Rage rooms. 30+ small events h
text:
Made a ton of changes to Exit Five last 365 days: 

1. More in person stuff. Big events. Medium events. Dinners. Hikes. Rage rooms. 30+ small events happening this year, available to members in different cities. 

2. Local chapters. Related to number one. Now have members in a dozen places leading other members online and offline. Amazing way to scale this community in a meaningful way. We didnâ€™t invent local chapters - but we damn sure are using them. 

3. Marketing is more then SaaS. That was my background, so lot of early stuff skewed toward SaaS. Today we see the world is MARKETING. And some people work in SaaS. Just like some work in hardware. We now have industry specific groups and discussions that go well beyond SaaS. 

4. Matchmaking. Many people join to build a network. We help by connecting members 1:1 each month to help build their peer group. 

5. Roundtables / therapy sessions / all kinds of training - videos and live sessions available to anyone with a membership. 

6. AI trained on all of our stuff to help get you better answers and be a thought partner if you need it. Different than ChatGPT. 

7. A real team of six full time humans that care A LOT about delivering value and helping the people that work in marketing do better work and make connections.

I see it as this: 

We are not in the marketing hot takes business. We are in the people business. 
We can help you meet peers, get inspired, get unstuck, maybe even make some work friends. 

There are other communities and platforms you can join too - it doesnâ€™t have to be a zero sum game. 

Iâ€™m not competing with anyone. And you should start a rival community if you think you can do better; let the market decide. Also I know today even a bunch of our members have multiple memberships to things. 

But weâ€™ve been going now for three years, built on 15 years of my own personal experience and receipts - and I donâ€™t plan on slowing down soon. 

We have product market fit + a team that gives a shit â€” and thatâ€™s an amazing tailwind to have. 

Learn more about Exit Five here: tinyurl.com/mwn9revk

âœŒï¸

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Marketing measurement and attribution is a total mess and everybody knows it. 

The ROI of marketing investments is (often) really bad, yet gets defen
text:
Marketing measurement and attribution is a total mess and everybody knows it. 

The ROI of marketing investments is (often) really bad, yet gets defended by BS reports. 

Marketing measurement is flawed and totally disconnected from business financial results. 

The data collected around which department â€œsourcedâ€ the opportunity provides ZERO insights for optimizing the strategy and investments. All you can do with it is figure out where to point the finger about which department to blame when you miss your pipeline target (useless and unnecessary). 

Now they want to add PhD level statistics on top of incomplete, inaccurate touchpoint and impression data and think thatâ€™s gonna solve it lol. 

Or build an AI-Analyst to sift through the incomplete, inaccurate data in their data warehouse and think thatâ€™s going to get you accurate reporting and conclusions (hint: itâ€™s not going to work and nobody at the C-Level or Board is going to trust it). 

And none of this helps you as a C-Level executive to align teams, drive strategy, allocate investments, and make confident decisions. 

Everyone is making this WAY more complicated than it needs to be. 

___

So, while everyone else goes more and more complicated to a level that nobody on the Exec Team or Board can understandâ€¦.the real solution is to SIMPLIFY. 

1. Marketing is a Portfolio of Investments. 

If you break it down, there are LOTS of investments in the Marketing budget (see the video for all the examples), usually hundreds of individual line items. Itâ€™s not like you just need to babysit 3 investments. 

2. Just like a wealth investment portfolio, the Investments in the Marketing Portfolio have different purposes. 

You canâ€™t measure the entire portfolio of Marketing and Sales Development investments in the same way, though that is what almost everyone is doing right now (with seriously underwhelming and confusing results). 

3. You optimize the portfolio of investments exactly the same as you would a wealth portfolio. 

4. Categorize the investments based on the GOAL/OBJECTIVE of the investment. 

5. Based on the OBJECTIVE, apply a consistent and specific measurement model to each category. 

6. Estimate the impact of each investment using the above methodology. 

7. Sort the performance top to bottom. 

8. With intelligence and thought and benchmark data, cut the losers, max out the winners, and test out new investments. 

9. Measure your top-level success and progress on the BLENDED impact of all investments. 

10. Wash, rinse, repeat every quarter using TTM and QoQ performance data. 

__

SIMPLE! Stop overcomplicating it. 

#finance #marketing #b2b #sales #gtm

p.s. you need touchpoint data and statistics to make this happen. But the process for *how* this data is used in companies is totally broken and causing losses of hundreds of millions of dollars for shareholders & investors. The stakes are HIGH. Time for smart executives to think differently and pave the way.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
It's 2024 and smart B2B companies are FINALLY rethinking their digital advertising strategies.

Why?

Because the traditional playbook of spending $10
text:
It's 2024 and smart B2B companies are FINALLY rethinking their digital advertising strategies.

Why?

Because the traditional playbook of spending $100k/month on LinkedIn ads to promote a gated e-book is clearly not working:

1. UNTENABLE ROI. CAC Payback periods > 60 months on â€œleadsâ€ generated from LinkedIn lead gen campaigns

2. SALES/MARKETING MISALIGNMENT. Sales teams close on average 1 out of 1,000 â€œleadsâ€ from a LinkedIn lead gen campaign. 

3. NO SCALABILITY. The terrible CAC and sales productivity metrics make this advertising strategy absolutely impossible to scale - you burn exponentially more money as you spend more. 

So, B2B companies really only have two options:

1. Stop spending money on LinkedIn Ads. Many companies are doing this and cutting $100k/month on LinkedIn ads and moving that money to spend even more on Google Ads. 

For most companies, this isnâ€™t really a solution. The measurable ROI on Google Advertising is also very poor and they are already way past the point of degrading ROI on this channel. 

2. Develop a new strategy for HOW to execute LinkedIn ads. A few smart companies are doing this with massive success, yet the majority of companies canâ€™t do this because of their outdated attribution requirements to deem ROI to a â€œleadâ€. 

__

LinkedIn advertising is the most powerful B2B marketing channel on the planet right now. You can distribute content to the exact decision makers at your target accounts for $0.03 to $0.07 each. 

It's by far the best use of variable marketing dollars compared to alternative investments like building a big tradeshow booth, spending another $100k/month on Google Ads, testing ABM display ads, or all the other large line item expenses on a marketing budget. 

Lots of companies like to blame the channel - "LinkedIn ads don't work." 

When in reality, they need to blame themselves - "Our strategy for LinkedIn ads doesn't work" 

What are you seeing with your LinkedIn ads strategy? How are you measuring success? Let's discuss ðŸ‘‡ 

#marketing #b2b #gtm #linkedinads #advertising

author: Chris Walker
hook:
ABM / ABX is an account tiering and prioritization strategy, itâ€™s not a go-to-market motion. 

So instead of trying to track the value of â€œABMâ€ as a m
text:
ABM / ABX is an account tiering and prioritization strategy, itâ€™s not a go-to-market motion. 

So instead of trying to track the value of â€œABMâ€ as a motion, we should be tracking our accounts (and account tiers) that run through our integrated GTM motions:

-Partner
-Website
-Events
-Independent Sales Prospecting 
-3rd Party Lead Generation
-Product / PLG

Then you can rapidly understand how each Tier of accounts flow through the hybrid GTM motions. Tier 1 accounts will surely flow through differently than Tier 3 accounts. 

But you'll never see these insights if you track "ABM" as a motion. 

#ABM #ABX #marketing #b2b #sales 

p.s. You may have different prioritization and investments within these motions for Tier 1 accounts vs. Tier 3 accounts, but the motions remain the same.

If my wife sends me a TikTok or IG video, I go right to the comment section.

Half of the
text:
The comment section. It's always about the comment section.

If my wife sends me a TikTok or IG video, I go right to the comment section.

Half of the jokes in our friend group IG DM channel where you share videos is about what people say in the comments.

So on the whole "Founder Brand" create content online thing.

You can't just post on your page, or have someone ghostwrite for you on your page.

You have to work the comments! Your own comments. Commenting on other people's stuff. I don't even care if you write your own posts on LinkedIn in 2026; just be active in the comments. Make jokes. Add an insight. 

Observe human behavior: we all go to the comments in our personal lives!!!

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Wrapping up the last few days of 2025.

I love my job; I love our company. And I'm also excited to chill out for bit and come back ready to go again i
text:
Wrapping up the last few days of 2025.

I love my job; I love our company. And I'm also excited to chill out for bit and come back ready to go again in January. Both things can be true!

Some notes:

âž¡ï¸ We doubled in revenue again this year; third year in a row we have doubled. Double-double-double. Not bad.

âž¡ï¸ Added three new teammates. It's almost always a "Who not Now" problem now. People continue to be the most important thing to get right.

âž¡ï¸ Got on a bunch of flights; did events in five major cities. Totally worth it. In-person is much different than online in the best way. Also gives me hope for humanity. We are better to each other in-person.

âž¡ï¸ Big sigh. Made a bunch of mistakes of course. Wasted time and money. Burnt some social capital. Hurt some feelings. Inevitable. But still sucks. I tell myself that nothing bothers me but of course that's a lie. And I know there will only be more of it if the growth curve of success continues to accelerate. Also: business is just hard. You're doing business with people. People are complicated. So it's hard to chalk it up to "it's just business."

âž¡ï¸ Much more positive note: realized that community is an incredible moat right now. Super bullish on the future with Exit Five and professional networks/community businesses. Feel very fortunate to be in the business we're in right now. Also the brand name, awareness, and recognition shift over the last year has been real. It feels different. In the best way.

âž¡ï¸ Still bootstrapped, no outside funding, and profitable. And just went double-double-double. Who's mad at that?

All around just having a good time too; was saying to Dan (E5 CEO) the other night on the phone -- I never got my MBA. But the amount we're learning about business through building Exit Five has been a completely unexpected benefit.  The fact that we get to make money from the business is a bonus.

OK that's not completely true; I don't have a trust fund unfortunately so I *do* need to make money through work. But my point is that we are learning so much beyond what we knew about marketing and it's super rewarding.

author: Dave Gerhardt

School is closed
text:
I donâ€™t want to make any of the other Thought Leader Boys feel inadequate. But...

Iâ€™ve been solo parenting for the last 72 hours. 

School is closed here Thursday and Friday so both kids are home with me.

While I'm running my MULTIPLE SEVEN FIGURE BUSINESS, from my home office, in Vermont, USA.

*And* I only put the TV on once for 1 hour while I needed to be on a call that couldnâ€™t be interrupted (we did play an additional hour of Mario Kart last night but that was after hours, the office was closed so I'm not counting it)

! 

And I really hope this makes it onto the LinkedIn Lunatics sub Reddit (which is also good for LLM discovery and AEO I've heard, so maybe worth it for the Exit Five search increase).

I wrote this post last night and scheduled it for early this morning so thereâ€™s no turning back now.

But I donâ€™t care.

I couldnâ€™t help myself. I had to post this.

Sometimes you have to flex. 

It feels so good.

â¤ï¸

PS. we are hiring at Exit Five if you want to work with a team who believes in building a great business and being present for your family at the same time letâ€™s go.

I've always wanted to say some obscure revenue number like "MULTIPLE SEVEN FIGURES" without disclosing the actual number, but just know it's somewhere between $2M and $9M but how good does MULTIPLE SEVEN FIGURES (all caps) sound? 

PS. I also am solo parenting because my wife and her parents are across the country visiting family and we flew them all there first class because I have so many AmEx points because Iâ€™m a baller Founder.

I was on the phone with her last night and told her I was going to post this and she said "you should say you were 'babysitting' the kids just to really get everyone fired up and angry at you"

Also: my team told me it would be OK to post this, and this entire thing (me being the MVP) would not be possible without them.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
High Frequency Company vs. Low Frequency Company

Understanding this truth will change your life ðŸ‘‡ 

Every team, group, and company has a resonant fre
text:
High Frequency Company vs. Low Frequency Company

Understanding this truth will change your life ðŸ‘‡ 

Every team, group, and company has a resonant frequency. 

Frequency is the composite of beliefs, emotions, actions, and intentions. 

It starts with the capital stack.
Flows to the CEO.
Cascades to the leadership team.Â 
And ripples across the entire organization. 

Frequency is highly contagious. 

If you donâ€™t assimilate to the same frequency as the organization, youâ€™ll either leave voluntarily or be kicked out. 

__

CHARACTERISTICS OF A **LOW-FREQUENCY COMPANY**

Core Energy: ScarcityÂ 
Leadership: Control + Micromanage
Pace: Constant Urgency + Burnout CyclesÂ 
Culture: Competition + Zero Sum GameÂ 
Motivation: External Validation
Success = Short Term Growth / ProfitÂ 
Energy: Draining Work + Constant Reactivity
People: Replaceable ResourcesÂ 
Partnerships: Transactional + Extractive 

CHARACTERISTICS OF A **HIGH-FREQUENCY COMPANY**

Core Energy: AbundanceÂ 
Leadership: Empowerment + TrustÂ 
Pace: Rhythmic, Spacious, Right on TimeÂ 
Culture: Collaborative + Win-WinÂ 
Motivation: Purpose + ContributionÂ 
Success = Integrity + Sustainable ImpactÂ 
Energy: Regenerative + InspiredÂ 
People: Irreplaceable ContributorsÂ 
Partnerships: Mutually Elevating + Values Aligned 

__ 

If you feel scarcity, urgency, pressure, burnout, like youâ€™re â€œnot enoughâ€ or that youâ€™re â€œfalling behindâ€... 

Look at your environment.Â 
Both physical and digital organizations carry a contagious frequency. 

And to realize itâ€™s likely your work environment is causing that to you. 

If you stay in a low frequency company, youâ€™re absorbing that energy. 

And you donâ€™t just feel drained, confused and â€œnot enoughâ€ at work. You carry that energy everywhere. 

Into your health.Â 
Into your finances.
Into your relationships, your creativity, your confidence, your clarity.Â  

Thatâ€™s the cost. And sadly, many tech companies are quietly taxing their people like this every day. 

Protect your frequency. Nothing is worth trading it for.

#leadership #frequency #life

author: Chris Walker
hook:
For the first time ever, lots of companies and executives are challenging the SDR model. 

And I think itâ€™s smart. 

Itâ€™s the first time the â€œPredicta
text:
For the first time ever, lots of companies and executives are challenging the SDR model. 

And I think itâ€™s smart. 

Itâ€™s the first time the â€œPredictable Revenueâ€ model has been challenged since companies started doing it 12-15 years ago. 

Those of you who have followed me for a long time, know Iâ€™ve been challenging the SDR model since 2017. Because I looked at the data in 2017 and even back then it was clear this function does not perform when scrutinized against REVENUE. 

But back then, we were in the growth at all costs era and nobody cared. Executives and investors didnâ€™t care if their SDR team had a CAC payback of 4 years. And to be direct, many executives I interacted with didnâ€™t even calculate metrics like this. 

They just chalked it up to â€œthis is how we do B2B Salesâ€ and accepted it. Similar to how B2B companies build trade show booths every year, rarely get appropriate ROI from those investments, but still go every year because â€œwe have to be thereâ€. 

Now, weâ€™re in the era of profitable, efficient growth, and companies need to rethink their entire GTM strategy, operating model, and cost structures. 

Finally, there is the pressure pushing down that forces companies to scrutinize all the things they do in GTM that theyâ€™ve accepted as â€œbest practicesâ€ for 10+ years. 

For the SDR model specifically, I donâ€™t think the right conversation is whether or not we should do outbound prospecting. And Iâ€™m not sure that will ever be the right conversation. 

Instead, I suggest GTM executives and companies start with a blank sheet of paper. Forget everything youâ€™ve done in the past and workshop this topic together:

We need to do â€œbusiness developmentâ€. How do we do business development in 2024? 

And if you had the discussion as a team of executives, you wouldnâ€™t end up with a strategy where you have 22 year olds with auto-dialers calling CFOs and CISOs. 

As you iterate on your 2024 GTM plan, try starting with a blank sheet of paper. Start with first principles. Think about your customer and what they want. 

If you did, youâ€™d certainly end up with an entirely different GTM strategy than whatâ€™s in place today. 

#marketing #sales #b2b #gtm #sdr

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: We're shifting away from charging for access to software and toward charging for the *work delivered* by software & AI agents. But this doesn't mean e
text:
We're shifting away from charging for access to software and toward charging for the *work delivered* by software & AI agents. But this doesn't mean everything will become pay-as-you-go overnight!

If you're thinking about charging for work, consider these 8 ways to structure your pricing. (I like #6 the best.)

1ï¸âƒ£ Pay-as-you-go (PAYG)

 - No commit, totally flexible 
 - Enterprise procurement usually *hates* this!
 - Works best when your customers can bill-back the expense or bake it into an operating budget
 - Otherwise, beware of the taximeter effect

2ï¸âƒ£ PAYG with a cap

 - Caps the usage/spend to offer buyers peace of mind
 - Increasingly seen with outcome-based models where outcomes are unknown

3ï¸âƒ£ & 4ï¸âƒ£Usage-based tiers

 - Customers commit to a certain level of usage or tier (ex: up to 5,000 API calls per month); this is typically "use it or lose it"
 - Two sub-flavors: high watermark (if usage exceeds the plan, folks immediately go into overages) or annual drawdown* (usage can be consumed flexibly, like a gift card)
 - Fear of overages + usage fluctuations encourages sales to over-sell & customers to over-buy

*I personally like the drawdown model. It gives the customer plenty of time to monitor adoption & plan for an early renewal/upgrade if usage is trending above their commit!

5ï¸âƒ£ Platform fee + usage

 - Small level of commit helps 'lock customers in' and give them access to advanced features, support, etc.
 - Works well when the usage metric is getting commoditized (ex: SMS messages, compute, storage) -- you can advertise a low usage fee & make up for it with the subscription fee

6ï¸âƒ£ Platform fee (includes usage) + usage, aka three-part tariff

 - Similar to the above, but with a larger subscription fee that includes some level of usage "included"
 - Folks usually advertise the initial usage as a gift ("get your first 500 SMS messages for free!")
 - Including a min level of usage helps get the customer hooked & usually incentivizes more overall consumption

7ï¸âƒ£ Adaptive flat rate

 - The customer commits to a usage-based subscription, but can use the product as much as they want with no overages/upgrades during that period
 - Their tier resets up/down at renewal based on their actual usage behavior
 - Much more predictable for customers while encouraging them to increase consumption (downside is that you could be stuck with the costs!)

8ï¸âƒ£ Platform plus success bonus

 - Communicate price as a subscription
 - If the customer gets a better ROI than expected, they pay a bonus
 - Works best if success = a hard ROI (ideally tied to extra revenue!)

--

I suspect most folks will offer multiple options as they seek to balance lands, expands & tough procurement convos. The downside: complexity.

#ai #pricing #aimonetization

author: Chris Walker
hook:
B2B SaaS revenue growth rates have slowed by over 50% in the past 2 years. 

And CAC Payback periods have skyrocketed by nearly 100% in the same perio
text:
B2B SaaS revenue growth rates have slowed by over 50% in the past 2 years. 

And CAC Payback periods have skyrocketed by nearly 100% in the same period. 

These two effects combined put massive pressure on core financial metrics, business profitability, and enterprise value. 

The root cause of this is Go-To-Market Bloat (GTM Bloat) where B2B companies invest significant money in Sales & Marketing and do not get the appropriate return on investment.

Sales & Marketing is by far the largest expense on a B2B company P&L - on average 40%-60% of total revenue; and 2-3X more than they spend on Product Development, Engineering, and R&D combined.

GTM Bloat occurs across the entire go-to-market, including People, Programs, Process, and Technology.

(1) People - Too many headcount on each GTM team, caused by outdated financial planning models, in addition to the overspecialization of roles on GTM teams (SDR, MDR, Solutions Consultant, AE, Onboarding Manager, CSM, AM, etc.). Or 90-person Marketing team that should be 35 people. Average sales quota attainment of ~40% is another clear indicator of headcount bloat.

(2) Programs - This mostly happens in the Marketing budget. B2B companies dramatically overspend on large scale events and digital performance marketing - up to 15% of total revenue - and do not get anywhere close to an appropriate measurable ROI on these significant expenses.

(3) Processes - Teams, meetings, reporting cadences to support programs that donâ€™t work. SDRs to follow up with â€œleadsâ€ and get a meeting less than 1% of the time. Inefficient processes create significant bloat especially when operated at scale.

(4) Technology - Buying an ABM tool for $200k per year and barely using it. So much bloated headcount increases license & seat costs for all SaaS subscriptions by 2-3X. Too many $100k+/year point solutions used by 1 department or team and not integrated or essential to the full GTM.

__

Solving GTM Bloat is the #1 opportunity in a B2B company today to increase enterprise value. This is now a CEO, CFO, and Board Level issue.

Eliminating GTM expenses that do not provide appropriate ROI could increase EBITDA by 20% or more.

Restructuring the existing investments in GTM to deliver the appropriate effectiveness could increase growth rates by up to 2X (e.g. from 18% to 36% YoY).

Or more than likely, the solution is a mix of both of these - eliminating low ROI expenses to improve EBITDA and doubling down on strategies that are already working to create breakthroughs in growth rate.

#gtm #gotomarket #finance #b2b #sales

*Benchmarks on public SaaS growth rates and CAC payback periods â„… David Spitz and BenchSights. Shoutout to David for some of the best work in the industry connecting GTM with Business Financial metrics based on actual data (not surveys or inaccurate aggregated data).

**At Passetto, we see similar, yet more amplified trends in our standardized analyses of CRM & Financial Metrics of private middle-market B2B companies

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Beware of the idea guy.

The "I had that idea years ago" guy.

The "Hey, that was my idea!" guy.

The "I've got three business ideas that I'm going to
text:
Beware of the idea guy.

The "I had that idea years ago" guy.

The "Hey, that was my idea!" guy.

The "I've got three business ideas that I'm going to do one day" guy.

You know that guy.

But you also know that ideas don't pay the bills.

In fact, every great idea is probably already out there.

The difference between you and the idea guy though is that you will actually go and do it.

You'll set a deadline. You'll create a plan. You will go and make progress. You will start the feedback loop.

The idea guy will see your (actual) work and say "hey! I had that idea too."

And he'll probably also tell you three reasons why your project won't work while he's at it.

But he'll still be the "idea guy."

Beware of the idea guy.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Here are the outcomes of the last 10 Sales opportunities at Passetto:

$25MM ARR SaaS - CEO - Closed Won
$250MM ARR SaaS - COO - Closed Won
$50MM ARR
text:
Here are the outcomes of the last 10 Sales opportunities at Passetto:

$25MM ARR SaaS - CEO - Closed Won
$250MM ARR SaaS - COO - Closed Won
$50MM ARR SaaS - CEO - Closed Won
$40MM ARR SaaS - CEO - Closed Won
$60MM ARR SaaS - CFO/CEO - Closed Won

$120MM ARR SaaS - CMO - Closed Lost
$60MM ARR SaaS - CMO - Closed Lost
$30MM ARR SaaS - VP Marketing - Closed Lost
$20MM ARR SaaS - CMO - Closed LostÂ 
$300MM ARR SaaS - CMO - Closed Lost
$180MM ARR SaaS - VP Demand Gen - Closed Lost 

See the pattern? 

Marketing isn't going to fix your GTM problem. 

Marketing Leaders are responsible for deploying Marketing budget against Marketing objectives. 

But donâ€™t expect CMOs (or any GTM Department Leader) to deploy their department budget to fix other departments' issues or cross-functional GTM problems. 

Even though Marketing Leaders see the problem. And they *feel* the problem. They wonâ€™t allocate their Marketing budget to fix cross-functional problems. And itâ€™s no fault to Marketing leaders, thatâ€™s how it should be. 

This is a massive insight for every GTM leadership team:

When CEOs arenâ€™t committed to personally owning holistic GTM, and instead delegate it down to GTM Leadership, transformational initiatives that get you to the next level of growth stall out and donâ€™t get funded. Itâ€™s often too â€œriskyâ€ for a department leader to authorize them. Instead all their investments, time, and effort are spent to achieve the short-term department-level KPIs. 

The CEO, supported by the CFO, needs to take full ownership of designing and optimizing their Revenue Factory so that GTM Leadership and Departments are aligned and set up for success. 

They must own and drive the long-term strategic cross-functional roadmap for their Revenue Factory.Â Just like they have a Product Roadmap for the next 2+ years. 

They are the only ones who can set and deploy investments outside of department-level budgets to solve cross-functional problems. 

They are the only ones who can authorize a $2MM investment to a new strategic initiative that may fail, but if it succeeds, it lowers CAC by 50% and adds $500MM in enterprise value to the company. 

Department leaders most often canâ€™t and wonâ€™t make these calls. 

If you want to take your GTM to the next level, you *need* the CEO and CFO to own and drive it, supported by GTM leadership and RevOps. 

#finance #b2b #gtm #marketing #sales

author: Chris Walker
hook:
B2B go-to-market teams have a massive analytics problem: survivorship bias. 

Every report, technology, team, and department are only looking at the d
text:
B2B go-to-market teams have a massive analytics problem: survivorship bias. 

Every report, technology, team, and department are only looking at the data around the times that they win. 

The bottoms-up reporting framework has every single team and budget holder across the GTM focused on "proving the ROI" of what they're doing, so executives only see reports about how well everything is working. 

This is a behavior pattern built during the growth-at-all-costs era. Where it didnâ€™t matter about efficiency. If we could get 1 more customer, it didnâ€™t matter how much it cost. 

But those days are over. Now weâ€™re in the era of profitable efficient growth. And B2B go-to-market strategy and investment analytics need a transformational makeover. 

So, whatâ€™s the fastest way to optimize your go-to-market strategy and investments? 

Flip the paradigm completely. Instead of looking at only the times you win, look at all the data around all the times that you lose and start to systematically eliminate them. 

B2B Sales & Sales Development resources - the most expensive resources in the entire company - will take action and LOSE more than 99% of the time. 

Significant Marketing investments are made to create â€œleadsâ€ that lose 99.9% of the time. 

SDRs arm the spam cannons to follow up with those shitty leads and lose > 99% of the time. 

So much money spent to create pipeline and nowhere close to the appropriate return on investments. 

Then thereâ€™s over bloated Sales headcount sitting at the bottom of the funnel with nowhere close to enough pipeline opportunities to hit the plan. Which is why average Sales rep quota attainments sits around 35-45%. 

The financial dynamics within a B2B company have fundamentally shifted. We need to follow suit with:

1. New go-to-market financial planning models built on efficiency
2. New analytics strategies focused on optimizing the holistic GTM, not â€œproving the ROIâ€
3. Significantly more discipline and balance around how we deploy investments across the entire GTM (create pipeline, close in-market accounts, and renewal/expansion). 

The fastest way to get there is look at all the times that you LOSE and start cutting those investments and tactics out of the mix. 

#gtm #sales #b2b #marketing

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Whatâ€™s the biggest problem with planning, measuring, and optimizing your GTM based on â€œInboundâ€ vs. â€œOutboundâ€ vs. â€œPartnerâ€ ?

Here it is ðŸ‘‡ 

Eventua
text:
Whatâ€™s the biggest problem with planning, measuring, and optimizing your GTM based on â€œInboundâ€ vs. â€œOutboundâ€ vs. â€œPartnerâ€ ?

Here it is ðŸ‘‡ 

Eventually, youâ€™ll run into unit economics challenges and data visibility challenges where you donâ€™t know what to do with your Marketing and SDRs to keep scaling them.

^^Iâ€™ve talked to more than 100 CEOs & CFOs that express this exact challenge

And here are the problems the â€œFour Funnelâ€ department-level lead source attribution & planning model causes across the revenue factory:

1. Marketing - Forces all Marketing investments into a small part of the Revenue generation process called â€œlead captureâ€. 

-Complete imbalance of Marketing investments caused by the singular attribution model leads to massive diminishing returns where B2B companies way overspend on low-quality lead generation

-Improper measurement of Marketing investments make it incredibly complicated & subjective as to whether Marketing is performing

*You should be able to know how well your Marketing is working or not with 2 metrics.Â 
*Marketing performance should be measured on a spectrum. *How well is it working*. Itâ€™s not binary. 

2. SDRs - No visibility to confidently scale or optimize the Prospecting process

-The only thing tracked is who books the meeting. But nothing about the WHY and HOW did we win
-The â€œInboundâ€ vs. â€œOutboundâ€ planning and debate distracts everyone from the insights needed for scaling and optimizing Sales Development process

3. Sales - Sales sits at the bottom of the funnel and doesnâ€™t have enough pipeline coverage to hit plan

-Lower quota attainment, lower PRP, forces Sales headcount adjustments
-Sales starts doing prospecting and lead generation to make up for poor performance at the top of the funnel and creates an *unscalable* GTM motion with untenable unit economics

4. Finance - Poor financial performance and ZERO clarity on what to do to fix it

-Degrading financial metrics - Slowed growth, increased CAC, lower profitability, lower enterprise value
-Strategic decisions are made based on someoneâ€™s opinion (e.g. CMO or CRO) because we don't have the right data

__

â€œInboundâ€ was a Tech Vendorâ€™s (Hubspot) Marketing message in 2013. And somehow 11 years later, itâ€™s still considered a â€œbest practiceâ€ across B2B.

Meanwhile, the â€œInboundâ€ vs. â€œOutboundâ€ aka Marketing vs. SDRs. vs. Sales vs. Partner lead-source origination attribution model thatâ€™s widely adopted across B2B is the primary cause of unscalable unit economics and data visibility challenges.

Stop planning, measuring, and optimizing all your GTM teams on lead source origination - a singular, totally sub-optimal attribution & planning model.

Start planning, measuring & optimizing your GTM like a Unified Revenue Factory.

#finance #b2b #marketing #sales #gtm

The department-level view tells you WHO did it. But doesnâ€™t tell you WHAT you did, HOW you did it, or WHY it happenedâ€¦â€¦..no wonder you canâ€™t optimize and scale your Marketing & SDRs.

Itâ€™s seen as the most â€œ
text:
Some (unsolicited) GTM predictions for 2026:

1. What ChatGPT says about your product becomes the top product marketing KPI. 

Itâ€™s seen as the most â€œobjectiveâ€ source about why youâ€™re better (or worse) than alternatives. Exec teams obsess over it.

2. Tech companies go on a buying spree for media & community assets. 

We saw a wave of this in 2021-2022. HubSpot & The Hustle. Pendo & Mind the Product. Semrush & Backlinko. 

The rationale back then was SEO. The rationale now will be AEO. (Plus media brands have always been >> than software at building an organic audience. Software is >> at monetizing an audience.)

3. PLG loses its appeal (again) as AI companies shift attention upmarket to bigger deals & stickier customers. 

The retention rates on <$50/month AI products areâ€¦ not great. (Iâ€™m trying to be polite.)

4. People stop using automation as a ðŸ’ª and prioritize AI that improves *quality* (conversion, CSAT, accuracy). 

Everyone knows AI can make companies more efficient. But can it improve performance?

5. Direct mail/gifting comes back in style as a way to reach buyers.

People are back in the office. A thoughtful gift gets opened & remembered more than 10 automated emails. 

6. Competitive differentiation becomes the top Board level priority. 

This might not have mattered much when there was so much market pull for AI. But deals will increasingly become a knife fight. Too many AI products still sound & look the same, and buyers donâ€™t know how to decide.

â€”

Curious to hear what yâ€™all think ðŸ”®

ðŸŽ For more GTM & growth insights, join 81k+ folks who subscribe to my weekly newsletter, Growth Unhinged: https://lnkd.in/exTbjKaM

#ai #startups #predictions

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
Churn isn't a Customer Success problem. Itâ€™s a *business* problem.Â And it might be why you miss the 2026 plan. 

Just look at the 3-year ARR impact of
text:
Churn isn't a Customer Success problem. Itâ€™s a *business* problem.Â And it might be why you miss the 2026 plan. 

Just look at the 3-year ARR impact of different growth initiatives^ for a typical $10M ARR SaaS co:

 - Increase prices by 50% for existing customers: +$1.7M ARR ðŸ™‚ 
 - Increase prices by 50% for *new* customers: +$5.4M ARR ðŸ˜ƒ 
 - Increase acquisition by 50%: +$5.4M ARR ðŸ˜ƒ
 - Increase prices by 50% for both: +$7.1M ARR ðŸ˜ 
 - Reduce churn by 50%: +$8.9M ARR ðŸ¤¯

Of course, CS teams are on the front lines working with customers. But there's only so much they can do & they're busy creating value in a bunch of other ways: CSAT & referrals, identifying expansion opps, customer insights.

What *can* prevent churn:

1ï¸âƒ£ Sell to the right customer.

I've seen products where annualized retention can range from 50% to 90%+ across different types of customers. Selling to the right ICP who values your product is often the top change that moves the needle.

2ï¸âƒ£ Stop overselling on the 1st deal.

It's usually better to start smaller, prove value quickly, and then unlock growth opportunities in the future. This also leads to faster sales cycles.

3ï¸âƒ£ Market to your customers.

Marketing isn't only for prospects. Your existing customers should hear about the latest features, learn best practices and get connected to a peer community.

4ï¸âƒ£ Nail onboarding.

A surprising % of folks who churn never really effectively launched in the first place. (This is especially true for PLG/self-serve).

5ï¸âƒ£ Set up integrations.

When your product is embedded in the customer's workflow & other systems, it's hard to rip-and-replace. Three reasons why: (a) connected data, (b) easier user adoption, (c) use case expansion.

6ï¸âƒ£ Solve more problems.

By broadening use cases for your product, you get more champions who'll go to bat for you at renewal (which is especially important if your original buyer leaves). 

7ï¸âƒ£ Give yourself more time.

Moving from monthly to annual (or multi-year) plans can be controversial. But IMO you're usually better off because you have more time to impress the customer & the customer is more motivated to implement the product.

---

Every team has a role to play in preventing churn.

^Data comes from the ChartMogul Scenarios feature and is based on a median $10M ARR SaaS company. Check out the full growth levers report here: https://lnkd.in/entFSeJ8

#customersuccess #churn #startup

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Not focusing on or being accountable to Marketing ROI is the #1 reason why I would fire a CMO. 

Because when your ROI is 2x (super low performing), y
text:
Not focusing on or being accountable to Marketing ROI is the #1 reason why I would fire a CMO. 

Because when your ROI is 2x (super low performing), you spend $10MM on Marketing & SDRs and get $20MM in pipeline. 

And when your ROI is 10x (high performing), you spend the same $10MM on Marketing & SDRs and get $100MM in pipeline. 

This difference fundamentally solves the growth challenges for a mature company. It fixes pipeline coverage, sales quota attainment, growth rate, unit economics - Everything that matters. 

But lots of CMOs donâ€™t track it and sadly donâ€™t care about it. 

This is why lots of CEOs, CFOs, CROs, and PE Investors everywhere are increasingly questioning and underwhelmed by the performance of the Marketing department. 

And here are the excuses you hear from CMOs that miss pipeline targets and get poor ROI from their Marketing budget: 

â€œMarketing takes timeâ€Â 
â€œWe need to measure the time lagâ€Â 
â€œWeâ€™re doing it for brandâ€Â 
â€œCheck the multi-touch attribution report for how everything is working"
â€œOur Marketing investments wonâ€™t pay off until next year and 2026â€ 

Wrong. 

A CMO must be able to implement strategic changes to investment allocation, core KPIs, cross-functional processes, and Marketing strategy to grow pipeline, improve unit economics, and make an impact on short-term business metrics. 

And Marketing investments MUST deliver appropriate ROI in period (TTM). 

Itâ€™s the CMOâ€™s responsibility to deploy the investments appropriately to balance the short-term and long-term return. 

#finance #gtm #gotomarket #marketing #b2b 

p.s. Lots of CMOs will say they donâ€™t care about ROI. They deploy a $30MM/year budget, get an awful return on the investments, miss their pipeline and revenue targets by a mile. And then after a terrible 2024 performance, they plan on doing same things with the same budget for 2025 (insanity). 

Any CMO that says they donâ€™t care about ROI should not be a C-Level executive. 

Because the â€œCâ€ in CMO means you are a BUSINESS LEADER first and the way you deliver business results is through the strategic execution of Marketing. 

And FWIWâ€¦.. Growth = Investment x ROI ;) 

So you have two options: 

1. Keep increasing the budget with terrible unit economics until the model breaks and your company is worth less than the amount of money youâ€™ve raised.Â 
2. Keep the budget the same (or lower) and improve the blended ROI of all of the investments. 

It's not complicated. 

Being more *efficient* in your go-to-market doesnâ€™t mean you grow slower. Itâ€™s actually the opposite.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
The AI growth re-acceleration at Intercom is wild: 

1. Fin went $1 to $12 million in a year -- more than a year ago.
2. On track to cross 30k paying
text:
The AI growth re-acceleration at Intercom is wild: 

1. Fin went $1 to $12 million in a year -- more than a year ago.
2. On track to cross 30k paying customers by end of year.
3. Annualized growth is 393% (as of Jun '25).
4. New customer NRR increased from 112% to 146%.
5. AI resolution rates increased from 23% (May '23) to 67% (Nov '25).

Intercom is THE case study for anyone pivoting from SaaS to AI agents. Co-founder Des Traynor just joined the Mostly Growth podcast to share what he's learned.

My top five takeaways from Des. Listen to the full podcast here: https://lnkd.in/edWkdZgV

1. Every marketing channel that would've worked in the early days of Intercom has gotten harder.

Most things are a lot easier now, except for getting attention. My favorite quote: "Every legitimate channel has been growth hacked to shit."

2. There's a classic pattern: People will expand marketing channels until they become slop.

All else being equal, the extra blog post or extra email gets more visits. But at the silent cost of degrading your brand and eroding trust.

3. Marketing is shifting to IRL events like dinners and meetups.

"We find ourselves looking for things that are obviously authentic and aren't hackable." Events are one of the rare channels that can't be easily faked.

4. Everyone's AI product has the same messaging. And the UI looks the same, too. Competitive differentiation is the next battlefield.

The real test is how many customers (a) discovered the product organically, (b) are happy with the decision, & (c) are seeing real business impact.

5. Pricing is a type of marketing. Startups always need to leave something on the table.

Every pricing model is imperfect. Intercom optimized for something that was explainable, digestible & worked in most parts of the market.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Grindcore = 9 a.m. to 9 p.m., six days a week.
San Francisco & VCs glamorize it. Employees get exploited by it.

You sacrifice your health, creativity
text:
Grindcore = 9 a.m. to 9 p.m., six days a week.
San Francisco & VCs glamorize it. Employees get exploited by it.

You sacrifice your health, creativity, and life for the illusion of freedom.
But the promised land never arrives.

ðŸ‘‰ People who work like robots will be replaced by robots.

By 2027, the cracks will be obvious:
-Burnout waves
-Stagnating employees
-â€œWinningâ€ companies propped up only by VC money

Itâ€™s a mirage, not a sustainable advantage.

â€”

Weâ€™ve seen this story before:

ðŸš– Uber & Taxi Drivers

-Lured in drivers with promises of freedom, flexible income and better pay.Â 
-Once supply flooded the market, they slashed driver pay to maximize margins.
-Now moving to automation with Waymo and self-driving fleets, cutting drivers out completely.

ðŸ“¦ Amazon & Warehouse Workers 

-Scaled on the back of human warehouse workers - brutal shifts, quotas, and exhaustion.
-Over time, they layered in robots, automation, and AI logistics to improve profitability. 
-Now, the workers who endured the grind are being phased out by machines. 

Grindcore is not new. Itâ€™s a recurring extraction model:

1. Lure people in with promises.
2. Grind them down for profit.
3. Replace them with machines.

â€”

Itâ€™s ironic this post is landing on Labor Day.

Labor Day was created in 1894 because society recognized the cost of overwork and exploitation.

Back then: factory workers were being worked 12+ hours a day, 6â€“7 days a week, with little pay and no protection. Strikes and protests erupted across the country.

Congress rushed to make Labor Day a federal holiday, a gesture to honor workers and acknowledge the abuse.

Back then: factory workers.Â 
Today: knowledge workers are being brainwashed into Grindcore.

Same dynamic. Just digitized.

Work should serve your life, not consume it.

The future belongs to high-frequency work:
Regenerative. Purpose-driven. Human.

Don't fall for the illusion. There's nothing noble or glamorous about being a modern-day slave.

#life #frequencyera #frequency

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: I expected GTM teams to embrace a bunch of specialized AI tools for different jobs. What I didnâ€™t expect was this much consolidation around a single w
text:
I expected GTM teams to embrace a bunch of specialized AI tools for different jobs. What I didnâ€™t expect was this much consolidation around a single winner: ChatGPT.

It's the #1 tool people are obsessed with and the #2 most essential in their stack (just behind HubSpot) via a new survey from Emily Kramer.

That made me wonder:Â what exactly are GTM teams doing with ChatGPT that makes it so indispensable?

I asked readers ofÂ Growth UnhingedÂ to share their favorite ChatGPT use cases. Here are the top 12, categorized by function & complexity.

Get the prompts & step-by-step workflows here (no need to comment!): https://lnkd.in/eipiemhC

1. Persona research to fill knowledge gaps (via Francesca Krihely-Price)
Complexity: Beginner

2. New AI product positioning to create a differentiated narrative (via Jarod Greene)
Complexity: Intermediate

3. Product messaging grader/audit and re-write for a CISO audience (via Nathan Burke)
Complexity: Advanced

4. Producing detailed outlines from primary source material (via Gail Axelrod)
Complexity: Beginner

5. Localizing content into multiple languages w/o an agency (via Thibaut Davoult)
Complexity: Intermediate

6. Programmatic landing pages based on community feedback (via Jesus Requena)
Complexity: Advanced

7. Paid spend analysis correlating the impact to organic/direct sign-ups when paid search spend is on (via Andrea Kayal)
Complexity: Beginner

8. Employee social posts w/ custom voice profiles (via Ryan McCready)
Complexity: Intermediate

9. Prioritizing growth experiments from PostHog and Mixpanel data (via Sibi M.)
Complexity: Advanced

10. Personalizing events including selecting seat assignments & topics for intimate dinners (via Andrea Kayal)
Complexity: Beginner

11. Prep for initial sales calls combing through websites, press releases, content, and LinkedIn profiles (via Laura MacGregor)
Complexity: Intermediate 

12. Use Gong sales call recordings to define patterns for the R&D team (via Elena Luneva)
Complexity: Advanced

Hope this inspires how you can get more from your fave GTM tool. And if you have any other ðŸ”¥ workflows, drop 'em in the comments!

#chatgpt #ai #genai

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
I'm borderline paranoid about making my writing sound like it's not AI generated. Here's how I'm trying to do it (feel free to steal it):

1. Ban â€œItâ€™
text:
I'm borderline paranoid about making my writing sound like it's not AI generated. Here's how I'm trying to do it (feel free to steal it):

1. Ban â€œItâ€™s not X, itâ€™s Yâ€.

Itâ€™s not personal, itâ€™s AI slop.

2. Avoid big vocabulary words.

The tapestry of human experience shall endure this affront. 

3. Write stream of consciousness.

Itâ€™s Dublin circa 1914 over here (IYKYK).

4. Kill the em-dash.

Sorry â€” not sorry.

5. Minimize copy-editing.

Readers are OK w/ less Polish if the message is clear.

6. Keep it concise.

I donâ€™t know about you, but I find AI generated slop reads like it was written by a high schooler trying to get their essay to clear the minimum page requirement.

7. Apply a consistent visual style.

The visuals show that the newsletter took real time to make.

8. Become less predictable.

You donâ€™t know what to expect next. Look over there!

9. Find alternatives for AI tells.

Delve. Showcase. Underscore. Highlight. Adept. Absolutely. You get it.

---

And honestly? This is all making me a better writer. 

But I do miss the em dash (RIP ðŸ˜­).
