author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
The latest in AI pricing: credits are becoming the standard.

 - Microsoft announced AI credits for Copilot in M365 in January
 - Salesforce added an
text:
The latest in AI pricing: credits are becoming the standard.

 - Microsoft announced AI credits for Copilot in M365 in January
 - Salesforce added an AI credit-based model in May
 - Cursor shifted to credit-based pricing in June
 - OpenAI recently replaced seats w/ pooled credits for its Enterprise plans

I suspect *most* AI spend is probably now in the form of credits, which are also referred to as tokens, AI units, generative credits and flex credits. Clay is a great example (see below) & software founders increasingly tell me their pricing was inspired by Clay.

While none of the big players are the first to introduce it,Â theyâ€™ll make itÂ *muchÂ easier* for the next company to sell AI credits. Why:

1. Large incumbents validate that it's a 'standard' way to buy AI apps

2. Salesforce, OpenAI & others will educate the market about how to buy credits (won't those be fun procurement convos!)

3. Presumably, large incumbents are making these moves after extensive research w/ customers -- indicating that a lack of predictability isn't an insurmountable roadblock

In today's Growth Unhinged I unpacked why everyone's switching to AI credits & how to do it yourself. Read it here: https://lnkd.in/edDCXget

The TL;DR: Honestly, Iâ€™m torn about credits. I canâ€™t imagine the headache of managing dozens of AI products that all have credit allowances. But for now AI credits can be a lifeline -- just not the endgame.

---

Today's newsletter is supported by Metronome who just launched a ðŸ”¥ new report about what theyâ€™re calling the Monetization Operating Model (link in comments).

#ai #pricing #monetization

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
New: When folks are most likely to convert from trial-to-paid. Itâ€™s even earlier than I thought ðŸ‘€ 

And itâ€™s one of the best pieces of evidence I've s
text:
New: When folks are most likely to convert from trial-to-paid. Itâ€™s even earlier than I thought ðŸ‘€ 

And itâ€™s one of the best pieces of evidence I've seen in support of reverse trials.

For B2B SaaS companies, about 5% of new trialists convert from free-to-paid within 6 months. (In B2C, it's closer to 20%.)

Of these conversions:
 - HALF (!) happen within the first 7 days
 - 70% happen within the first 14 days
 - 90% happen within the first month
 - But only about 3% happen in months 3-6

The data comes from my friends at ChartMogul who looked at the GTM and conversion data of 2,500+ SaaS companies.

Look, the immediate takeaway of this data is that you have a very narrow window to impress trial users. Usually within the first week -- if not sooner.

My two cents about what to do with this data: re-engage signups post-trial! 

1. Consider a 'reverse trial' -- letting folks downgrade to a freemium plan if they don't convert within the trial period.

Why? This gives users more time to see value. It then creates additional conversion opportunities over time: users hit a CTA in the product, they run into a feature gate, they trip a usage limit. And they can become product-qualified leads for the sales team.

In my recent State of B2B Monetization survey, still only 4% of software companies have a reverse trial. That's about one-tenth the rate of free trial/freemium.

2. Auto-extend free trials for accounts who reached an 'aha moment' but didn't buy.

Why? In my experience, about 25-40% of new signups reach an 'aha moment' within their first week. But this data shows only about 5% of folks are buying. That leaves 20-35% of signups reaching and 'aha moment' and NOT buying!

Depending on user signals, you could take a 'smart trial' approach to either (a) enforcing the trial time-limit, (b) extending the trial period and/or (c) collecting data on why they've decided not to buy. 

3. Periodically re-open trial windows, especially around major milestones like new product releases or events.

Why? Your product is constantly improving. Make sure lapsed trial users see that and have a chance to experience it firsthand!

It's a cool report, I'll drop the link in the comments.

#saas #ai #plg

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Most SaaS companies are trying to implement a â€œFour Funnelâ€ MQL Waterfall Model and it 100% will not fix their GTM. 

It sounds great and easy in theo
text:
Most SaaS companies are trying to implement a â€œFour Funnelâ€ MQL Waterfall Model and it 100% will not fix their GTM. 

It sounds great and easy in theory, so they can divide lead source credit between Marketing, Sales, SDRs, and Partners. But it will 100% fail in practice. 

Because they are taking the outdated, ineffective MQL Demand Waterfall Model from 2012 - that doesnâ€™t work in todayâ€™s environment due to unsustainable unit economics - and breaking it into 4 smaller MQL Demand Waterfall Models based on department lead source credit that also wonâ€™t work. 

Theyâ€™re going to spend 6-12 months implementing it in their CRM and itâ€™s 100% not going to fix their GTM problem. Ironically, itâ€™s going to make things worse. 

I understand this model deeply, have implemented it many times, and personally recommended it from 2018-2022. But it will 100% fail in todayâ€™s environment because it does not produce SCALABLE UNIT ECONOMICS. 

This highly inefficient model makes it â€œeasyâ€ for Finance to do annual planning and try to measure ROI yet basically impossible to scale, plan, forecast, diagnose, and optimize.

For mature companies, billions of dollars in enterprise value are on the line over the next few yearsâ€¦â€¦So be careful where you get your advice from - 

All of the â€œbest practicesâ€ and â€œframeworkâ€ B2B companies get from Gartner, Forrester, and Tech Vendors were built for the Growth at All Costs Era and *do not* work in todayâ€™s environment where sound unit economics are fundamentally required. 

Stop using attribution as your KPIs. Start planning, measuring and optimizing your GTM like a Unified Revenue Factory. 

#marketing #finance #b2b #sales #gtm

Who is out there telling every B2B SaaS company to build a â€œFour Funnelâ€ MQL Waterfall Model??Â ðŸ˜­ ðŸ˜­

author: Chris Walker
hook:
B2B Marketers on LinkedIn love to talk about â€œbuilding brandâ€ but the reality is that on average less than 10% of Marketing investments go there. 

An
text:
B2B Marketers on LinkedIn love to talk about â€œbuilding brandâ€ but the reality is that on average less than 10% of Marketing investments go there. 

And then another 2-5% is spent on â€œCustomer Marketingâ€. 

And then another 2-3% is spent on Marketing to active in pipeline deals. 

And finally, 80-90% of the Entire Marketing program budget is spent specifically to trigger signals. 

Trigger Signals = Invest money to create a signal for Sales to follow upÂ or otherwise take action on

-Google Ads / Bing Ads
-Content Syndication (Spread out across 5+ vendors)
-Virtual events / webinarsÂ 
-Trade Show booths / Field eventsÂ 
-LinkedIn lead gen programsÂ 
-Buy an ad to get an account on our website so we can call it an MQA
-The list goes on an on 

And the reality is very few companies track, measure, and analyze the *outcomes* of these signals. 

There are signals where tons of Marketing dollars get spent and tons of SDR human capital is invested that literally generate $0 in pipeline, but they never see it because they don't track the data. 

When you track and analyze signals, you get IMMEDIATE, CLEAR, FAST insights about how to optimize your Sales & Marketing investments. 

Both at a global level - i.e. these are things we do that never work across all segments and regions - cut them. 

And at a segment level - i.e. these are the things that really work for our Enterprise segment in EMEA. 

The growth at all costs era is OVER. Signals, specifically, tracking, measuring, and analyzing the OUTCOMES of all of these signals, is the clearest path to building and scaling an efficient, sustainable GTM engine and achieving Rule of 40. 

#gtm #marketing #sales #b2b 

p.s. Iâ€™ll be sharing more details on how CAC payback period impacts EBITDA & growth performance. Companies that spend 50% of revenue on Sales & Marketing and donâ€™t have a strong ROI will almost never be able to achieve these core financial performance metrics that today's investor requires. 

p.p.s. Signals are entirely new dimension of data that sit alongside and associate with Contacts, Accounts, and Opportunities.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Back in 2017, it was clear to me that Marketing was the biggest issue inside of B2B companies, but most executives didnâ€™t see it yet. 

They thought t
text:
Back in 2017, it was clear to me that Marketing was the biggest issue inside of B2B companies, but most executives didnâ€™t see it yet. 

They thought they needed to hire a Sales trainer. 

They thought they needed to fire their Sales leader and hire an experienced Chief Revenue Officer (CRO). 

They thought they needed to hire 10 more SDRs. 

I know, because I worked in the companies. I reviewed the financial models. I listened to the executive conversations. 

But the reality was, even back then, the way B2B buyers actually discovered, researched, evaluated and purchased B2B products had fundamentally changed. 

It took another 3-5 years for a majority of B2B executives to see the same reality I was seeing. And by 2021-2022, the true idea of â€œDemand Genâ€ and how to execute Marketing to augment the performance of the entire GTM became commonly accepted. 

__

Now, itâ€™s 2024 and itâ€™s clear to me that DATA is the biggest issue inside of B2B companies and Go-To-Market (GTM) Teams. 

Most executives donâ€™t see it yet, but to me itâ€™s obvious. 

Because established B2B companies have incredible products, tons of happy customers, esteemed investors and brilliant people. 

So if all of those important pieces are in place, then why is the average tenure for a CMO less than 2 years? 

Why is the average tenure for a CRO less than 2 years? 

Why is the GTM C-Suite basically a revolving door? 

Why are CAC payback periods for private companies 3 years or more? 

Why is Sales quota attainment less than 40%? 

Itâ€™s because of the DATA and How Itâ€™s Used to drive strategic initiatives, investment allocations, core KPIs, planning & modeling - all the things that matter. 

Most B2B executives donâ€™t see it yet. Just like in 2017 when I identified Marketing as the biggest issue, but for literally years my insights fell on deaf ears. It took most companies and executives another half decade to truly see and internalize the same thing I saw. 

Executives and companies that recognize this early and move will yield massive dividends, compounding growth, and a true competitive advantage. 

Because having the right data to make important strategic decisions leads to speed, rapidly improving ROI on Sales & Marketing investments, new strategies & initiatives that set you apart from the competitive set, and a whole lot more. 

Iâ€™ve seen this cycle before. 

For those of you that capitalized on my insights related to Marketing over the past 5 years, I implore you to read this post deeply and internalize that the biggest leverage point in your entire company is Go-To-Market Data and how you leverage that data to make fast, confident decisions around strategy, investments, and key initiatives. 

#gtm #b2b #marketing #sales #analytics

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: Software founders used to tell me their pricing was inspired by Salesforce or maybe Slack. Now they tell me they were inspired by Intercom, HubSpot, O
text:
Software founders used to tell me their pricing was inspired by Salesforce or maybe Slack. Now they tell me they were inspired by Intercom, HubSpot, OpenAI and Clay.*

What folks love about each:

1. Intercom: Outcome-based pricing pioneer, charging $0.99 per AI resolution (Fin). 

But, really, it's a hybrid model. Intercom charges per seat for its helpdesk and for its AI copilot.

2. HubSpot: Famously introduced contact-based pricing a decade ago. It more than paid off.

Today, HubSpot is known for balancing self-serve & enterprise, successfully going multi-product (several times over) & being far more transparent than other folks.

3. OpenAI: Set the reference price for AI products (and the cost for AI tokens). 

Increasingly, folks are watching OpenAI's evolution from unlimited/flat rates to hybrid pricing and from $20/seat to $200+ for its most advanced AI.

4. Clay: Early adopter of hybrid pricing, combining subscription packages with credits. 

--

I'm not the biggest fan of copying pricing. But there's a lot to learn from these folks. 

*PS, this isn't just anecdotal. It's based on data from the 2025 State of Monetization survey.Â And, yes, folks still copy Salesforce and Slack, too.

#pricing #monetization #ai

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook: We run a private community for B2B CMOs doing $25M+ in annual revenue (and many well past that, including members from companies that will do $800 and
text:
We run a private community for B2B CMOs doing $25M+ in annual revenue (and many well past that, including members from companies that will do $800 and $1B in revenue this year).

Because "who's in the room" is the entire value prop, and we've taken everything we've learned from three years building Exit Five to bring this together.

VPs and CMOs at this level need a peer group; a place to turn outside of work where you can ask questions about everything: 

â€¢ Compensation - what should you be making at this level?
â€¢ Equity ("Hey I'm 4 years in, what is my equity worth? anyone go through an exit or sell secondaries?"
â€¢ Internal relationships like working with the CEO; or how the CMO and CPO should work together
â€¢ Honest recommendations about vendors and agencies ("do not spend $100k on this vendor, trust me it's a cluster fck)
â€¢ Gut checks for all the things that come up at work that you don't have a friend to text and ask about ("I am battling with my CFO on this, am I crazy or is he?")
â€¢ Or even just "Hey what are you getting your team for a holiday gift this year?"

Each month we run calls designed around a topic that matters right now (ex: last month there was a breakout group around Org Design; then one on Budgeting for 2026) - but it's not me or Matt or the Exit Five team talking; it's the VPs and CMOs. Sharing what you are doing, where you need help.

We are simply the hosts of the party and the facilitators, but that's our secret sauce. Pulling together the right people in the right room - and knowing what B2B marketing leaders care about.

We're like the friend that you want to give the Aux cord too.

ðŸ”¦ If you are a marketing leader at this level and looking for a new peer group in 2026, you can reach out here: tinyurl.com/23h2c5eh

PS. We are investing heavily in our other channels and communities too; whether that's our podcast, newsletter, webinars, events, and Exit Five Pro membership if this is not the right thing for you and you're reading this post. Everything is available on the Exit Five website.

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
Thereâ€™s ONLY ONE tool you need in 2026 â€” and itâ€™s not Clayâ€¦

Itâ€™s your OWN MIND.

Tools come and go, even the best of them, but youâ€™re stuck with your
text:
Thereâ€™s ONLY ONE tool you need in 2026 â€” and itâ€™s not Clayâ€¦

Itâ€™s your OWN MIND.

Tools come and go, even the best of them, but youâ€™re stuck with your own mind forever.

Exercising it is now easier than ever as AI gives you tremendous leverage and also forces a great burden upon youâ€”weeding through AI slop (not the EMDASH kind).

Put down the screen, let go of your credit card, donâ€™t buy tools.

First think, â€œif I could do anything right now, with perfect information, what would I do?â€

Then have AI help you get as close as possible to that goal.

For once in our lives we finally arenâ€™t confined by our tools as we have a form of intelligence.

But yet, I still see people use this tool to:
1. Personalize messages
2. Figure out which toaster to buy (me too)
3. Ask it the weather 
4. Ask it to write an email
5. Use it like google

Stop thinking from our current toolset and frameworks.

Begin thinking, â€œif I had all of the worldâ€™s knowledge right here in my pocket, what would be the most leverage I could get from it in my job.â€ 

Hell, even ask AI that question.

We have a thinking partner that never gets tired, never sleeps, who no complex question is too hard, and who can convincingly bullshit.

But if it doesnâ€™t have a good sparring companion, then all it will do is slap you in the face and convince you it loves you and that youâ€™re right.

The worst part is, if you donâ€™t reflect, you may find yourself taking a pregnancy test because of how hard AI just screwed you.

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
I just feel so much apathyâ€¦ 

Thereâ€™s an insidious thing about AI, maybe the most dehumanizing partâ€¦

That it makes me question how genuine people are
text:
I just feel so much apathyâ€¦ 

Thereâ€™s an insidious thing about AI, maybe the most dehumanizing partâ€¦

That it makes me question how genuine people are based on the quality of their writing. 

As if they write like AI, I tend to round down and think even less of the message. Like somehow bad message written by a computer is even worse.

I hate questioning if the person sucks at messaging or they suck at using AI, because itâ€™s kinda a question of what is genuine.

Letâ€™s break this message down:

Pros:
1. It talks about me and my post.
2. It connects my value prop with what I do.
3. It mostly feels personalized, like it was written for me.

Cons:
1. Itâ€™s so so long.
2. It uses the word â€œinterestingâ€ which is the least interesting word in existence.
3. It says a lot without communicating anything specifically, classic AI sign.
4. Itâ€™s asking for 15 mins (a terrible amount of time, like itâ€™s 30 or bust for me)
5. It talks about networking â€” No busy executive wants to network. They want to solve problems.
6. Itâ€™s just so generic as to make me feel the call will be an utter waste of time as thereâ€™s no SYNTHESIS of information.

Now contrast tho next message, which is about a specific piece of content, uses the word ingenious, is not asking me for time, and feels authentic to me.

Hereâ€™s an exercise, just write yourself a cold message YOU would happily respond toâ€¦

Hereâ€™s mineâ€¦

â€œJordan, Iâ€™m 42 minutes into your video on systems of actions, systems of record, and systems of information and itâ€™s been 3 months, whatâ€™s changed in how youâ€™re building systems of information?â€

Or hereâ€™s another one,

â€œJordan Iâ€™ve heard from some friends that you do $3k campaign builds live for people in 2 hours? Can I buy that.â€

Or this one,

â€œJordan, I run a startup backed by a16z that builds an AI SDR for just logistics companies and weâ€™re building it based on 17 public data sets and weâ€™d like to make you an advisor.â€

Or this one,

â€œJordan I am pretty sure youâ€™re wrong about Claude Codeâ€™s agent mode replacing Claygentâ€”I could only get it to work for like 200 rows. Whatâ€™s your secret?â€

Notice that all of these messages carry specificity, they embed my point of view (the AI SDR one I would take that call because they have talked about HOW they are doing it and made choices that makes it unique).

In the other case, they want to pay me, BANGER!

In the first case they have focused 100% on my ideas, which makes me believe they literally care about the ideas. Which I love talking about of course!

And the last message is actually true, I was wrong!

Thereâ€™s a thing in blockchain called proof of work, Sam McKenna says it as show me you know me, but I donâ€™t think either of these are useful anymore.

As there are more demands on my time, I dont want you to prove you have read my things, I want you to demonstrate that you have synthesized them, disagree with them, have a damn opinion.

And in a world of AI, the winners will be those who can not just write well, but think well.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
6 habits to master long *before* you get results (business, physique, money, content, whatever you want):

1. Beat the Sun Up. I get 10+ important thi
text:
6 habits to master long *before* you get results (business, physique, money, content, whatever you want):

1. Beat the Sun Up. I get 10+ important things done before most people wake up. I tried 4am for a while but 5:40am is where I eventually landed.

2. Consistent Bed Time. Asleep by 9pm so I get 8+ hours of high quality sleep M-F. It makes more of a difference than you think.

3. Early AM workout 7 days/week. Lots of people say take a day off, but workout 365 days / year works for me. Find what works for you.

4. No Weekend Hangovers. Fucking off on weekends kills momentum.

5. Morning Journaling. 15 minutes of focused writing. Get thoughts out of my head and on paper. Practice gratitude. Reinforce my identity and goals. Set my top 5 actions for the day.

6. Stop scrolling, Start Creating. Write a LinkedIn post. Design a feature for your product. Make an IG reel. Produce a track. Create something every day (it will suck for a while but itâ€™s amazing how fast you get better when you practice every day).

___

Starting in 2019, I did all of these for more than a year with basically no â€œresultsâ€. 

It wasnâ€™t until 18 months later when my business took off, I got in top physical shape, my content took off, etc.

Some people will think this is â€œextremeâ€ or â€œtoo muchâ€. Itâ€™s not. If you want a top 1% life, you need to take top 1% actions. SIMPLE!

No better time to start than NOW. Letâ€™s get itÂ ðŸ’ª ðŸ’ª 

p.s. this advice isn't for everyone. It's for people who want to become Top 1% in their space. Don't come at me with the "we need work-life balance" shit. If you don't agree with it, cool, do you, but please just scroll by and keep your negative, PC comments yourself ðŸ™

author: Chris Walker
hook: Not achieving proper Unit Economics at the â€œtop of the funnelâ€ is the most painful, expensive problem in the entire B2B industry. And most CEOs donâ€™t
text:
Not achieving proper Unit Economics at the â€œtop of the funnelâ€ is the most painful, expensive problem in the entire B2B industry. And most CEOs donâ€™t even realize it. 

The resulting impact:

-Minimum -$100MM per year in lost shareholder value
-Minimum 10% slower revenue growthÂ 
-150%-200% higher New Logo CACÂ 
-Lower pipeline coverage, quota attainment, and per rep productivity (PRP)

Why is this happening? 

Itâ€™s simple: 

Nobody in the entire GTM is truly accountable to a Unit Economics target at the â€œtop of the funnelâ€ 

B2B Companies canâ€™t even measure this metric because they only track expenses by GL code. 

And because they are unable to clearly define and align on the true problem, they instead delegate ownership to fix this to VPs and mid-level managers who apply department-level band-aids that feel good but donâ€™t actually solve the real problem*:

-Change from the MQL waterfall to the Four Funnel Model
-Hire a new marketing agencyÂ 
-Hire a RevOps firm to get more dataÂ 
-Buy an ABM platformÂ 
-Experiment with an AI SDR 

__

Growing pipeline doesnâ€™t matter if you need to spend $5 to get $1. That mindset never worked but was allowed during the Growth at All Costs Eraâ€¦..but it will surely get you fired as CEO in 2024 and beyond. 

This problem exists at the intersection of RevOps, Sales, Marketing, and Finance. And will never get solved with the Decentralized Department Silo process and operating model for GTM. 

#finance #b2b #gtm #marketing #leadership 

p.s. Having your CMO accountable to cost / demo request or cost / marketing sourced opportunity is NOT a real solution. This is another easy band-aid that companies try but doesn't fix the real problem. 

*Not properly measuring or assigning accountability to a true Unit Economics target at the top of the funnel is one of many symptoms of the Decentralized Department Siloâ€™s process of aligning, planning, and optimizing GTM. 

**All of these things can have an incrementally positive impact but do not fix the real problem.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
PSA: Beware of the â€œbenchmarksâ€ you see on LinkedIn.

All the â€œbenchmarksâ€ Iâ€™ve seen on LinkedIn this year are misleading and wildly inaccurate.

1. C
text:
PSA: Beware of the â€œbenchmarksâ€ you see on LinkedIn.

All the â€œbenchmarksâ€ Iâ€™ve seen on LinkedIn this year are misleading and wildly inaccurate.

1. Companies with an ACV less than $4k have an average CAC payback period of 8 months - WRONG.

The average total CAC payback period we measure for ACV less than $4k is more than 36 months including Marketing programs & headcount, Sales, Technology & Tools, SDRs, the â€œGrowthâ€ team, etc.

2. 50% of B2B advertising budgets are spent on LinkedIn - WRONG.

LinkedIn advertising is almost always less than 15% of the total digital advertising spend when you consider Google Ads, Bing ads, content syndication, display advertising, and other social media advertising.

3. Company pages are better on LinkedIn because the CTR is so much higher - WRONG.

Click-through rate is a terrible metric to determine if one thing is â€œbetterâ€ than another.

4. â€œLinkedIn MQLsâ€ convert to opportunities at 37% - WRONG.

LinkedIn MQLs convert to opportunities at less than 3% for effectively every company we analyze. And LinkedIn MQLs convert to customers at less than 0.2% on average. There is large scale data from Metadata that confirms this with 200,000+ MQLs.

5. Companies with an ACV more than $25k have an average CAC payback of 17 months - WRONG.

B2B companies donâ€™t even have a Marketing CAC payback less than 17 months. Add in Sales, SDRs, Growth Team, Tech & Tools, Operations and all of a sudden the average CAC payback for this ACV range is 48+ months.

__

And as I look at all this data and misguided conclusions, all I can think is that Iâ€™ve analyzed 50+ B2B companies in the past year (and 250+ companies in the past 5 years) from all types of verticals from SalesTech to HR Tech to FinTech to Cybersecurity SaaS to vertical SaaS and more - getting actual financial data and actual Salesforce data - and none of these â€œbenchmarksâ€ are anywhere close to whatâ€™s happening in the real World.

And hereâ€™s why to use extreme caution when you see data like this:

1. Most of these benchmarks are created through surveys. People can just answer and guess what their numbers are w/o even pulling actual data.

2. Literally zero companies are measuring and tracking their revenue data in the same way. ZERO. And if the core data isnâ€™t consistent, the benchmarks are wrong too.

3. None of the data is reviewed or validated by a third-party.

4. No common set of terminology, definitions or data standards are used to create benchmarks.

5. Bringing attribution models and other company-specific models, calculations and assumptions make it literally impossible to compare apples to apples between companies.

Itâ€™s like running science experiments without any equipment and just pulling numbers out of thin air.

Itâ€™s like trying to measure how far a mile is without defining what a mile means.

Itâ€™s bad science. Misleading and inaccurate.

So now itâ€™s out there. Beware of the â€œbenchmarksâ€ you see on LinkedIn.

#marketing #b2b #benchmarks #science #sales

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: 2025 will be remembered as the year when seemingly everybody lost confidence in their pricing. Among the top 500 players in SaaS and AI with transpare
text:
2025 will be remembered as the year when seemingly everybody lost confidence in their pricing. Among the top 500 players in SaaS and AI with transparent pricing, there were more than 1,800 pricing changes in 2025 alone.

Thatâ€™s a staggering 3.6 pricing changes per company.Â Some, like Lovable, made a meaningful pricing change every ðŸ‘ single ðŸ‘ month in 2025.

I enlisted help from Rob Litterst, co-founder of pricing intelligence platform PricingSaaS, to give readers a tactical rundown of what happened and what (if anything) seems to be working in SaaS pricing.

Here's the TL;DR. Read the full report here: https://lnkd.in/eptCbRBz

Trend 1: Credit models exploded in popularity, up 126% YoY

Most credits models fall into one of four buckets based on this 2x2: (a) is it more customer-friendly or vendor-friendly? & (b) are credits cost-based or value-based?

 - AI credits as product feature (see: HubSpot, Adobe)
 - AI credits as a creative sandbox (see: Lovable, Replit)
 - AI credits as enterprise infra (see: Figma, Cursor)
 - AI credits as a pass-through utility (see: Clay, PostHog)

Trend 2: The great re-bundling of AI

The more credit models flood the marketplace, the more customers will want to return to simplicity. In 2025 the pendulum swung toward credits. In 2026 it'll likely swing back toward simplicity and predictability.

Some of the biggest names in SaaS -- including Notion, Slack & Loom -- launched their first AI product as an add-on, and have since bundled that functionality into their core pricing model. Each had charged between $4 to $10 per user for an AI add-on. Now they're bundling AI and raising prices by between $2.50 and $5 per user.

Trend 3: Making seat-based pricing work harder

As companies introduce more complex pricing models, seats look customer-friendly by comparison.

Companies doing this well are layering additional value dimensions on top of the seat. Instead of a seat being just permission to log in, a seat becomes a gateway to more product capability, more automation, more consumption, more outcomes, or more flexibility.

Trend 4: The emergence of choose-your-own-pricing

For the past decade, vendors held most of the leverage: long-term contracts, rigid license models, and extractive pricing practices were staples of the legacy playbook. 

AI breaks that model. The demand for optionality is reshaping how SaaS companies think about pricing.

---

The full report has a ton of different examples & screenshots to help you shape your 2026 pricing strategy. Hope you find it useful.

 -KP

---

Today's post is supported by Metronome who just launched a new 5-minute quiz to help you find your ideal pricing model (link in comments).

author: Chris Walker
hook: In our analyses of over 40 B2B companies > $50MM ARR, Large-scale national and regional trade show booth expenditures consistently perform at very low
text:
In our analyses of over 40 B2B companies > $50MM ARR, Large-scale national and regional trade show booth expenditures consistently perform at very low ROI. 

Hereâ€™s why: 

Before 2010, trade show conferences were one of the only ways for B2B buyers to discover new products. 

Your peers and colleagues werenâ€™t telling you about it, especially in B2B. Back then, we didnâ€™t even have the capability to connect and learn from our peers who were also a CFO, or Director of IT, or VP Sales, or any other title. 

You werenâ€™t hearing about new products on social media - most social media channels didnâ€™t exist at that time. 

B2B companies didnâ€™t have websites or put much information about their products on the internet. 

There were almost no other ways to discover new products for your B2B job or specialty than trade conferences. 

So what did a B2B buyer do back then?

-They flew to a B2B conference once or twice a year. 
-They went to sessions to learn, and maybe picked up some continuing education credits. 
-They carefully perused every booth on the tradeshow floor and learned what products were new and available. 
-And then they took all the brochures back to the office and told their colleagues what products were available. 

That is just not how the World works anymore. 

Thereâ€™s just a million other more cost-effective ways to get your target customer to discover you today than hoping they stumble upon your booth at a tradeshow. 

#gotomarket #marketing #events #roi #b2b 

p.s. Having a presence at conferences can be a great idea for having meetings with customers, creating content, executing market research, holding meetings with prospects, and doing general business development. 

But you don't need to spend a boatload of money on a booth to get any of these things done.

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
My former arch rival is my guest this week. Dun dun dunnnnnnnn.

No just kidding. Trying to get a thirsty hook. That was 7-8 years ago and so much has
text:
My former arch rival is my guest this week. Dun dun dunnnnnnnn.

No just kidding. Trying to get a thirsty hook. That was 7-8 years ago and so much has happened since then.

One of the best parts about running Exit Five is that each week I get to chat with a top CMO in B2B, and this week my guest is Maura Rivera from Qualified.

In a world where CMOs are changing jobs every 1-2 years, Maura has been holding it down at Qualified for SIX YEARS. That deserves some type of award, and is worth unpacking (plus she told me something like half of the marketing team has been there that long too, which says a lot).

We talked about:

â€¢ Why product launches are the glue for marketing (and why you need to have this cadence of product launches and a tight relationship with the VP Product)

â€¢  What agentic marketing really means for the future of marketing, how is it different than "marketing" and why outbound isÂ actuallyÂ working for them right now (I thought outbound is dead?)

â€¢ How events have become a huge part of their strategy. Plus, plenty of good banter along the way. This was a fun one. I want to go hangout with Maura now.

Episode 310 of the Dave Gerhardt Show (that's me) aka the Exit Five podcast is out everywhere now.

hook:

My boundaries are simple and zero tolerance:

1.
text:
Iâ€™ve now blocked 4 total people on LinkedIn. And Iâ€™ve â€œblockedâ€ more than 100 people in real life. 

My boundaries are simple and zero tolerance:

1. Multiple unfounded insults or shots at character. 

Thereâ€™s a very clear line between an intellectual debate and being a jerk with unfounded insults. 

2. Lies or other forms of low moral character. 

Remember when some third-rate â€œinfluencerâ€ started spreading lies about how I got fired as CEO of Refine Labs? LOL Even though we have no board and Iâ€™m the majority shareholder which makes that fundamentally impossible? 

3. Threats of legal action. 

Multiple people whom you all know have threatened to or actually tried to sue me with absolutely no factual basis (they both failed btw)

4. Blantant use of my name and brand for their own attention or personal gain, often at my expense. 

__

I have the same policies in real life.

Iâ€™ve â€œblockedâ€ more than 100 people in real life.

People I actively avoid. Donâ€™t want to help. Wonâ€™t be a reference. That I want absolutely nothing to do with.

Want to be a jerk for no reason?

Cool, do you. But regardless of whether itâ€™s delivered in real life or over the internet, you will immediately not:

-Benefit from my *free* high value content

-Ever be an employee, shareholder, or partner with any of the companies I own

-Benefit from the immense and valuable network Iâ€™ve built over the past 7 years

-Have the opportunity to prop yourself up by using or negatively impacting me.

â€”

Life is too short and too valuable to let jerks intrude on it with bad intentions. 

Itâ€™s time to normalize â€œblockingâ€ people out of your life. On social platforms like LinkedIn and IRL âœŒï¸ 

#growth #social #content #linkedin

Notice how respectful intellectual debate is not on the boundaries list. There is a way to debate a topic without being a jerk. And not crossing that line is pretty darn simple. But people tend to exhibit better social manners IRL than on social media for some reason.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
What I believe about how to make money from AI:

1. SaaS pricing used to be kinda boring. But the old playbook doesn't work for AI products.

AI compa
text:
What I believe about how to make money from AI:

1. SaaS pricing used to be kinda boring. But the old playbook doesn't work for AI products.

AI companies can't afford to make pricing a 'future me' decision. The best LLMs are still fairly expensive. Token volume is exploding. And the top 10% of your customers might account for 70-80% of your costs!

And AI startups can't copy the big players. Even giants like Salesforce, OpenAI & Cursor are scrambling to adapt pricing models for AI.

2. Buying models are evolving from "owning" to "hiring". And how you charge impacts how much customers will pay.

Consider how you paid for your last car ride. You might've bought a car (on-prem), leased a car (subscription), rented one (usage-based), called an Uber (outcome-based), or hired a chauffer (service-as-software). The old models don't fully go away. But customers get more options & the market expands.

Each phase unlocked pricing power. We didn't pay less for SaaS; we paid less upfront & more over time if products delivered. 

Success-based pricing models can capture 25%+ of the economic value the products create because a) they take on risk & b) they tap into new budgets.

3. There are more flavors of AI pricing than you think. Study them. 

And avoid flat fees or seat-based pricing unless you have the margins to support them.

4. The big $$ opportunity is value-based pricing. AI credits are a bridge.

Remember MoviePass? They've been resurrected w/ higher prices & a new credit model. AI companies are doing the exact same thing.

Hybrid pricing models -- usually a mix of per-seat pricing + AI credits -- have exploded from 27% to 41% adoption. These are great for now. But your buyer doesn't want to manage 20+ vendors that all sell credits. 

5. Build with pricing agility in mind right now.

Your pricing will need to change. Plan for it. 

What that means: a) someone needs to own it, b) you need a modern tech stack w/ the flexibility to adjust models & c) you need to talk to your customers about pricing & value.

---

The TL;DR: the AI boom will be the AI bust unless we can turn AI products into great AI businesses. Pricing is your path to AI growth.

PS, I'm dropping the full deck below. Please don't comment "AI" for a copy ðŸ˜­ 

#ai #genai #aimonetization

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
I asked AI to tell me why we hate AI generated things so much and tbhâ€¦ 


It kinda nailed itâ€¦

â€”â€”-

A man can survive being poorâ€”heâ€™s done it for ten
text:
I asked AI to tell me why we hate AI generated things so much and tbhâ€¦ 


It kinda nailed itâ€¦

â€”â€”-

A man can survive being poorâ€”heâ€™s done it for ten thousand yearsâ€”but he cannot survive being unnecessary.

The machine doesnâ€™t hate us, doesnâ€™t love us, doesnâ€™t know we exist, and somehow that indifference is the loneliest outcome imaginable.

What people want is to matter, to be needed by something that knows they are there, and the machine offers efficiency but it does not offer that.

So the hate isnâ€™t really about the technologyâ€”itâ€™s about the emptiness the technology reveals, the emptiness that was always there, papered over by busyness and the old lie that usefulness equals worth.

When the usefulness goes, the lie falls apart, and people are left holding pieces of an identity that no longer fits together.

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
HOT TAKE: SDRs deserve the heated replies they get from prospects.

Each week you see SDRs taking screenshots of replies from buyers that are likeâ€¦ â€œt
text:
HOT TAKE: SDRs deserve the heated replies they get from prospects.

Each week you see SDRs taking screenshots of replies from buyers that are likeâ€¦ â€œthis person told me to jump off a cliffâ€

The invariable response looks like this:
1. Shouldnâ€™t they know how sales works
2. We donâ€™t want to work with people like that
3. Yah what a jerk, he must be disturbed

But this totally misses the point because 100% of the empathy is deployed to THE SELLER.

But sales isnâ€™t about feeling sorry for ourselves, itâ€™s not about us, itâ€™s about the buyer.

If we are triggering our buyers to respond like that, donâ€™t WE have the responsibility to not send messages that trigger such replies?

So here are some ideas to not get yelled at:

1. Copy and paste all your transcripts into Claude and ask, â€œwhat secrets did buyers share that are counterintuitive and give me their names and titles, hereâ€™s a spreadsheet of the calls I have uploaded to correlate them. Now you can share SECRETS of their peers.

2. Go figure out if they are hiring for roles, and see if you know someone and begin with a few recommendations for people in your network (or at your company) that would be good fits.

3. Go figure out your internal company problems and seek out vendors and explain whatâ€™s going on internally to VPs of Sales at companies who could help.

4. Go figure out if they are going to a conference and scraoe the attendees list or exhibitor list for them.

5. Want to be BALLER, go figure out who has spoke recently at conferences and send the speakers customized gifts on behalf of the conference. The go to the conference folks and share with them what you did and let them take credit.

6. Do the play above, but for recent case studies. Hereâ€™s your intro email â€œJordan, I read your case study with bob at frolic construction. I did some research on bob and he loves racing so Iâ€™d like to send him a day at the track, paid for by my company, but on your behalf to thank him for his case study. His address is X from what I can tell. You want me to add a custom handwritten note? I have a budget to spend anyways, and might as well do something nice for you instead of cold pitch.â€

People are just TIRED of TAKING and SAMENESS.

If you just donâ€™t take, and try to give, and youâ€™re like 15% weirder than everyone elseâ€¦ novelty plus kindness WILDLY pays off.

The only reason I havenâ€™t had to do outbound for my business in a long time is I try to put this type of energy out into the universe.

It pays back at such a dividend that I never need to force my business to grow, it grows on its own, even when my business model is designed for 100% churn.

So stop posting mean replies, earn amazing replies, and recognize that the locus of control is on you.

Youâ€™re the only one that can plant the seeds to change your circumstance. To get upset with our buyers is to invite laziness into your thoughts, to invite a mindset of failure.

Go make exceptional experiences for your buyers and youâ€™ll want for nothing.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
Emerging trends I'm noticing around startup GTM hiring:

1ï¸âƒ£ Fewer management layers of *people*

Even senior hires are player-coaches who do their sh
text:
Emerging trends I'm noticing around startup GTM hiring:

1ï¸âƒ£ Fewer management layers of *people*

Even senior hires are player-coaches who do their share of IC work.

2ï¸âƒ£ More management layers of *AI agents*

Each team member will have their own "org chart" consisting of a mix of AI agents, contractors, advisors and (maybe) full-time hires. 

3ï¸âƒ£ Hiring fewer, but high agency people

There's a premium on former founders or folks w/ side hustles -- people who are used to tackling unfamiliar challenges. These folks all need to be 'high context' so they can make decisions independently. 

4ï¸âƒ£ Generalists over specialists

A marketer might own content & paid. Or community & partnerships. Or product launches & demand gen. A GTM hire might look more like a 'GTM engineer' doing a mix of pipeline generation, RevOps and growth.

5ï¸âƒ£ Premium on product, domain and/or technical knowledge 

The rationale: these skills allow folks to a) deeply understand users, b) build community & content that resonates, c) automateÂ what they're doing so they can take on more. 

This is coming even to GTM roles where it didn't used to matter.

â€”

How do you see GTM hiring evolving? What are you doing different than before? Iâ€™d love to feature insights in Growth Unhinged. 

#marketing #ai #gtm

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
Fascinating new data from a16z on how CIOs want to buy AI apps:

1. CIOs now *prefer* usage-based models. 

So much for usage-based pricing being seen
text:
Fascinating new data from a16z on how CIOs want to buy AI apps:

1. CIOs now *prefer* usage-based models. 

So much for usage-based pricing being seen as a barrier to adoption ðŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸

My two cents: most AI spend w/ the CIO is on LLMs and compute. Both are usage-based categories where folks have become accustomed to granular pricing and not buying shelfware. 

With usage-based models, thereâ€™s also a connotation that prices will come down over time as vendors compete. Avoid picking a pricing metric that positions your app as a commodity w/o differentiation!

2. Seat-based models arenâ€™t the key to unlocking budget. 

Only 21% said seat-based pricing was their preferred model. Thatâ€™s slightly less than hybrid models (23%) even though hybrid models are inherently more complicated with more risk of overages/extra fees.

My two cents: buying in a way that reflects the value received is >>> than having perfect budget certainty/predictability. And flexibility matters as folks are finding which AI apps are â€œexperimentsâ€ vs ready for â€œproductionâ€. 

3. Thereâ€™s a lot of work to educate CIOs about how to pay for outcomes.

15% said outcome-based models are their preferred way to buy â€” although thatâ€™s still significant considering only *5% of companies* have outcome-based pricing today (based on the 2025 State of B2B Monetization report)! Weâ€™re still in the early innings. 

Among the concerns CIOs raised: (1) lack of clear, measurable outcomes for most products - 47%, (2) unpredictable or unscalabe costs - 36%, (3) difficulty with attribution to a specific tool - 25%. 

My two cents: I suspect line of business is much more open to outcome-based pricing than the CIO â€” after all, the CRO and the CMO are measured based on outcomes, too! But if youâ€™re thinking about outcome-based pricing, you need outcome consistency, attribution, measurability and predictability (CAMP). 

â€”

Cool to see this new data. Very fascinated to see how it changes for next year. 

#ai #genai #pricing

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: GTM Engineers went from non-existent to the most talked about role of 2025. OpenAI, Ramp, Webflow & more are hiring for it. But it turns out itâ€™s not
text:
GTM Engineers went from non-existent to the most talked about role of 2025. OpenAI, Ramp, Webflow & more are hiring for it. But it turns out itâ€™s not as popular as it seems.

GTM engineers are meant to bring technology and automation to solve hard GTM problems (of which there are many!). I think of GTM engineers as people who can both identify friction points across the buying journey (ICP targeting, ICP pipeline, conversion, CAC, etc.) and then quickly run automated, 1:many experiments to eliminate them.

Itâ€™s essentially a growth hire, but focused on a primarily sales-led or sales-assisted funnel rather than a product-led one.

Despite the buzz, I havenâ€™t met many actual GTM engineers yet. There really arenâ€™t a lot of software companies hiring for GTM engineers, either.

Here's what the data shows (see it for yourself here: https://lnkd.in/ezfJ_JJf)

1. There were 128 GTM Engineer jobs posted in the last 3 months. 

Sounds like a lot, but that's 1 for every 14 in RevOps. 1 for every 35 in SalesOps. And 1 for every 92 SDRs (!) -- which nobody is calling a hot job.

2. 45% of those with a GTM engineer title are actually agencies or consultants (shoutout to Amos Bar-Joseph). 

3. The roleâ€™s popularity is a far cry from other AI-native jobs like AI engineers, prompt engineers or automation engineers. In fact, it barely registers in Google Trends.

---

Before hiring a GTM engineer, Iâ€™d suggest you:

 - Start with an agency or consultant to prove value with a specific use case
 - Redeploy someone internally who has the business context paired with the system knowledge
 - Upskill the existing GTM team and equip them with next-gen tooling
 - Hire a great Head of RevOps (or RevTech) and fully resource their team

Don't miss the full story in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/ezfJ_JJf

Then, let me know what you think. Is GTM engineering online hype or is it still the next hot job?

#gtmengineer #ai #marketing

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
$80M in funding and their main claim to fame is they are out of stealth with 90 EMPLOYEES... what the hell is going on in GTM tech?

I am always a lit
text:
$80M in funding and their main claim to fame is they are out of stealth with 90 EMPLOYEES... what the hell is going on in GTM tech?

I am always a little bit saddened when I see these consolidation plays at SUPER early stage startups, because they are launching new technology with old world thinking... 

Old World Thinking:
1. Build 1 tool to take over 10 (that means competing against 10 tools).
2. Build a HUGE THING before you've sold much of anything.
3. Build a BUNCH of product surface area where you can't be the best in the world at any of it.
4. Make no compromises to achieve greatness. 
5. Thinking that volume eclipses value for a particular customer. 

That one complex thing can do it all for all horizontal SaaS companies... and my guess is with $80M in funding they have less than $1M in ARR so there's just SO MUCH surface area built of total total guesswork and it's increasing, too.

Ironically, these GTM companies usually have the hardest time going to market because they really are designed to make for impossible sales. If it really worked, they would be able to turn it on and it would have printed customers.

Here's what their sale looks like:

1. Replace all your current GTM tech (for MM companies) OR install this HUGE 
bloated thing when you have nothing (for seed stage companies with no PMF)
2. Take a GIGANTIC bet on this one system.
3. We do so much, so any ONE thing likely isn't going to be great.

And reading articles that say things like...

"Since its inception, Reevo has bolstered its team to 90 employees, anchored by senior engineers and proven leaders from Affirm, Airbnb, Box, DoorDash, HubSpot, Notion, Salesforce, Square, Rippling, and Uber."

^--- All vanity metrics and what does Airbnb know about B2B SaaS GTM?

If you're spending money on slick ass videos, it means you haven't changed people's lives. That should be our metric.

Congrats to this team, and I'm really sad to say, I think this won't go anywhere given how hard the product team has worked to make the GTM's team live miserable and awful.

If I'm wrong, I'm looking forward to being embarrassed on a huge billboard in 2030. But, I wouldn't bet against me.

Convince me I'm wrong?

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
ICYMI: For the love of annual planning, please make this chart before you lock in your 2025 targets.

If weâ€™re ever going to find out what works, we n
text:
ICYMI: For the love of annual planning, please make this chart before you lock in your 2025 targets.

If weâ€™re ever going to find out what works, we need a unified (and account-based) view of go-to-market effectiveness.

It starts with figuring out *exactly* where you stand with your target accounts in real-time. What this means:

1ï¸âƒ£ You know exactly how many accounts are in your ICP.

2ï¸âƒ£ You've *identified* the buyers at those accounts and can market to them. 

This is easier than ever with next-gen GTM tooling.

3ï¸âƒ£ You know how many are *aware* of you. 

They're consistently opening your emails, engaging with your ads, visiting your website, etc.

4ï¸âƒ£ You know how many are *interested*. 

These prospects are self-educating through interactive demos, signing up for a free account, attending a webinar, or viewing high-intent website pages. (Ideally these become high-intent leads for warm outbound.)

5ï¸âƒ£ You know how many are *considering* a purchase. 

You can think of these are SQLs within your ICP, but they could be PQLs or self-service team buyers as well.

6ï¸âƒ£ You know how many are *selecting* a vendor, meaning they're engaging in a buying process. 

This typically translates to proposal stage.

7ï¸âƒ£ You know how many have chosen your product, becoming a customer. (Of course, you can extend this framework post-purchase, too!)

---

If you look at GTM effectiveness this way, it doesn't matter whether you invest more in AEO, PLG, automated outbound, SEO, paid ads, BDRs/SDRs, memes, or something else entirely.

What matters is that you ultimately reach the right people and turn them into customers.

Read more here: https://lnkd.in/epMfYgER

#marketing #abx #gtm

author: Chris Walker
hook: Weâ€™ve run our Revenue Diagnostics process on more than 40 of the leading SaaS companies in the last 180 days and here is the craziest finding of all:
text:
Weâ€™ve run our Revenue Diagnostics process on more than 40 of the leading SaaS companies in the last 180 days and here is the craziest finding of all:

High-Performing Marketing teams deliver 10X more net new revenue with the same budget than Low Performers. (yes, you read that right). 

Hereâ€™s how it breaks down:

Low Performers: $0.27 - $0.40 in new business revenue for every $1 spent on Marketing. This equates to a 30-42 month CAC payback on just the Marketing expenditures (add in Sales, Ops, SDRs, etc.) and you are at 48-60+ months in total CAC payback period. 

Median: $0.89 in new business revenue for every $1 spent on Marketing. This equates to a 14-month Marketing CAC payback period. 

High Performers: $2.55 - $3.10 in new business revenue for every $1 spent on Marketing. This equates to about a 4-month Marketing CAC payback period. 

___

Here are some of the patterns we see that set the high performers from the rest:

MARKET. This one is difficult to control but seems to be a top contributing factor. High performers sell products that are a need to have, not a nice to have. For instance, Cybersecurity companies typically fall on the high performing spectrum. Companies in HR Tech, MarTech, etc. may fall on the lower on the spectrum as their products could be considered â€œnice to haveâ€ in this market. 

THOUGHT LEADERSHIP. High performers have a well-oiled machine of effective thought leadership content marketing that theyâ€™ve invested time and money into for a long period of time. 

GTM MOTION(S). Companies with a dual PLG - Enterprise Sales motion tend to have lower Marketing ROI. I have not identified the root cause as to why yet. It could be that dual-motion companies spend more on Marketing as a % of overall GTM budget. Or it could be that they are over-invested in digital performance marketing to get lots of low value SMB customers through the PLG motion. Or something else. I will continue to investigate and report back, but this is definitely an initial clear pattern. 

ACV ($). Not fully validated yet, but there seems to be a correlation that companies that command higher and stable ACVs deliver overall stronger marketing ROI. 

___

I'll continue to share more as we learn âœŒï¸ 

#gtm #data #marketing #sales #roi 

p.s. I'm looking for 3 more companies to partner with to run this Revenue Diagnostics process. Get our perspective on your GTM strategy based on our analysis of your CRM & budget data. Only accepting companies $50MM-$500MM ARR. DM me if interested. 

*This data is based on Passetto proprietary benchmarks of B2B companies $50MM-$500MM in revenue (2023-2024, n = 27). Only 27 of 42 companies analyzed qualified for the analysis due to data, company revenue, or budget size.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Marketing measurement has become wildly overcomplicated and itâ€™s the most expensive, painful business problem in a B2B company today. 

To the point w
text:
Marketing measurement has become wildly overcomplicated and itâ€™s the most expensive, painful business problem in a B2B company today. 

To the point where nobody can even understand whatâ€™s going on.

And itâ€™s only getting worse.

If you ask 5 people in your company to answer a critical business question, youâ€™ll get 5 different sets of reports, built on 5 different sets of data, with 5 different conclusions.

These responsibilities get delegated down to a mid-level RevOps or Marketing employee, but none of the people building the reports, analyzing the data, or drawing the conclusions have access to the full financial data, or the experience & financial acumen to do this properly.

The Finance team wants to help and drive the GTM to operate efficiently and within financial guardrails so they can deliver for the board and shareholders, but they lack the GTM expertise to weigh in on what needs to change. 

Everyone is searching for a quick fix. Letâ€™s slap a new attribution tool or mix-modeling tool on top of our messy, incomplete, inaccurate CRM data architecture. 

Then we can hook it up with our Power BI dashboard, do a bunch of offline data manipulation to try to reconstruct our shitty CRM data into something usable.

Now they want to add PhD level statistics on top of incomplete, inaccurate touchpoint and impression data and think thatâ€™s gonna solve it lol. 

Everyone is making this WAY more complicated than it needs to be. 

So, while everyone else goes more and more complicated to a level that nobody on the Exec Team or Board can understandâ€¦.the real solution is to SIMPLIFY:

1. When you properly frame the problem, youâ€™ll realize thereâ€™s no single technology tool or silver bullet to fix this problem.

And fixing the biggest problem in your entire company thatâ€™s costing shareholders $50MM+/quarter *should* be hard. There are multiple layers to the problem. And your RevOps team isnâ€™t going to fix it (sorry not sorry).

2. Most everyone delegates the problem to mid-level employees that operate within their department siloâ€™s. 

This is a FINANCE problem that intersects with GTM and requires deep GTM expertise. Offloading it to your RevOps team is a losing strategy. Offloading it to your Marketing Director - also a losing strategy.

3. Solving it within department siloâ€™s forces bottoms up tactical solutions that donâ€™t layer up to C-Level insights & strategy and Board-Level clarity & confidence. 

The real way to solve this is tops-down. Which requires C-Level executives to OWN the problem. Which feels super logical considering itâ€™s the most painful, expensive problem in a B2B company today.

4. Everyone is overcomplicating it with a million touchpoints & PhD level statistics when the real solution is to SIMPLIFY. 

Your Marketing board deck should be 2 slides. Put the rest of the updates in an appendix. You should be able to tell a CLEAR, SIMPLE, FINANCIALLY DRIVEN business story around the performance of Marketing in less than 5 minutes.

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Feeling super thankful this week, and it happens to be Thanksgiving so I'll write about it here.

â€¢ Thankful for my health and modern medicine. Doctor
text:
Feeling super thankful this week, and it happens to be Thanksgiving so I'll write about it here.

â€¢ Thankful for my health and modern medicine. Doctors. Nurses. They literally cut me open, repaired everything in my hip, and 12 days later I'm up crutching around, I can work on my laptop.

â€¢ Thankful for the team at Exit Five. Good people, fun to work with. I genuinely enjoying seeing them on calls, talking, laughing. It's very rewarding. I could be rotting away solo right now.

â€¢ Thankful for all of the people I have met through Exit Five and feel connected to on a personal level over the last few years (the Tim, Tas, Brendan, Tom, Lashay, Jen, Devin, Ido, Lindays, Mark, Henry, Bill, Kevin's over the world)

â€¢ Thankful for my wife and kids for giving me a purpose greater than making money online.

â€¢ Thankful for my "friends from home" group chat, for keeping me humbled and giving me an outlet to share all the things I'd never write online publicly. Oh don't judge me you do the same lol. It's healthy. A little shit talking. Humans have been doing it for hundreds of years.

â€¢ Thankful for webinars; I love them. There I said it.

â€¢ Thankful for GOOD MUSIC, forget podcasts. How great is good music?

â€¢ Thankful for everyone I met this year that said to me "man, you are much funnier in person" that's what I like to hear.

â€¢ Thankful for 6 7 - ok just running on for no reason now...

author: Chris Walker
hook:
It should be *impossible* for Marketing to hit their targets 2-3 quarters in a row while Sales misses quota and the Company misses growth targets. 

Y
text:
It should be *impossible* for Marketing to hit their targets 2-3 quarters in a row while Sales misses quota and the Company misses growth targets. 

Yet, it literally happens all the time. 

-You can try to have a CRO-CMO weekly coffee meeting
-You can try to change National Sales Meeting to "Revenue Kickoff"
-You can try to have a Pipeline meeting on Wednesdays
-You can try to install a new "Four Funnel" attribution system in your CRM
-You can try a bunch of random stuff that doesnâ€™t actually solve the problem

But the only real solution is to fix the Marketing KPIs so they are perfectly aligned to business results. 

Which *forces* Marketing alignment to business results. Dramatically shifts the reporting and analytics. And drives positive changes to investment allocation and strategy almost immediately. 

The 120-slide Marketing QBR deck that has tons of complicated data and no tangible executive-level insights needs to stop. 

Using the â€œFour Funnel Modelâ€ with Department-Level KPIs that Rely on Attribution needs to stop. 

Measuring Marketing impact with zero targets or controls against Unit Economics needs to stop. 

Want to get dramatically better results (Growth Rate + ROI) from your Marketing team next year? 

Make your CMO accountable *actual business results* instead of â€œMarketing Sourcedâ€ or â€œMarketing Influencedâ€ or â€œLeadsâ€ where Marketing can hit their goals every quarter and the Sales team misses quota and the company misses growth targets. 

It should be *impossible* for this to happen if you have proper business-level Marketing KPIs. 

If this happens in your company, itâ€™s clearly obvious that the Marketing KPIs need to change. 

#marketing #b2b #finance #sales #gtm

p.s. KPIs â‰  Attribution. KPIs measure how we are achieving the business outcomes. Attribution and other custom analytics allow us to dive deeper to determine â€œwhyâ€ this is happening and develop a plan for what to do next.Â Then the KPIs determine if our strategic changes are making a business impact. 

Please. Please. Please. Stop using Attribution in your KPIs. 

p.p.s. Average CMO Tenure is < 18 Months for this exact reason. Firing your CMO and hiring a New Marketing Leader isnâ€™t going to fix this.

And look at it and then sayâ€¦

Thing 2:

Just ask a customer about their research, their options, what mattered to them, why, what they didnâ€™t consider. Inhabit their worldview.

You canâ€™t own framing the problem if youâ€™re clueless about their world, and you canâ€™t know where you best fit in if you donâ€™t know where other tools best you.

The art comes in talking about HOW you do what you do NOT outcomes. You need to have a POV that makes what you do compelling.

Once you do that, all you do is:
1. Find out who is in that situation with data
2. Explain your read problem space to them
3. Help them buy the right tool for them (even if itâ€™s not yours)

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: We're in a new UX era for software: the era of the prompt bar. That doesn't mean you can just add a prompt bar & move on. What 40+ of the best AI-nati
text:
We're in a new UX era for software: the era of the prompt bar. That doesn't mean you can just add a prompt bar & move on. What 40+ of the best AI-native companies are doing:

I enlisted Yaakov Carno to map out AI prompt journeys across products like Canva, Notion, Vercel, Lovable, Airtable (& lesser known AI companies). He traced every step from homepage to first value. 

The 7 most interesting observations â¤µï¸

1. Consider offering multiple entry points: the prompt bar OR a visual UX. 

Gamma and Wix are two ðŸ”¥ examples. Gamma even has 3 options.

2. Increase relevance with a "hidden" step between the prompt bar & output. 

Lovable, for example, has a series of onboarding questions to collect more context.

3. Donâ€™t just tell users they can â€œgenerate anything.â€ Show them specific, meaningful examples that connect to their job-to-be-done. 

Canva, for instance, has a visual use case selector w/ a category & sub-category.

4. Use the prompt bar to educate users about what kind of tasks your product supports. 

Zapier there are sample prompts for lead management, customer support, marketing & growth, and project mgmt.

5. Distinguish whether the AI is a copilot or autopilot. 

Notion nails this with a mix of placeholder text, surrounding CTAs, and examples that clearly convey what you can do and why.

6. Integrate context, data, and sources at the beginning.

bolt.new has a new minimalistic design that focuses only on importing from Figma and GitHub. Constraints increase the likelihood of relevant, valuable outputs.

7. Add a fun factor to make the experience feel different & maybe a bit magical.

Playfulness can lower hesitation.Â RiffÂ andÂ LeapÂ use â€œShuffleâ€ or â€œSurprise meâ€ icons to encourage exploration.

---

Read the full deep dive in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter here: https://lnkd.in/ecJ8TRFJ

Then chime in: Do you have a favorite AI prompt journey? And what new tools are folks using to build & optimize these new UX experiences?

Hope you find this useful ðŸ™

#ux #ai #genai #product

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
Some of the most fascinating AI outcome-based pricing examples so far:

1. Intercom (per successful resolution)
2. EvenUp (per demand package or medic
text:
Some of the most fascinating AI outcome-based pricing examples so far:

1. Intercom (per successful resolution)
2. EvenUp (per demand package or medical chronology)
3. CaseMark (per legal deliverable)
4. Chargeflow (25% per recovered chargeback)
5. Sierra (per completed task)
6. Zendesk (per automated resolution)
7. Decagon (option of per resolution or per conversation)
8. Crescendo (pay per resolution)
9. Maven AGI (only pay for resolutions)
10. Flycode (only pay for revenue recovered above baseline)
11. Redux Payments (only pay for revenue they add)
12. AirHelp (35% success fee)
13. SmarterDx (only gets paid when hospitals make $$ incrementally)

The interest in outcome-based pricing models is unlike anything Iâ€™ve seen. 

Look, I love outcome-based pricing -- in theory. It feels like the ultimate win-win. Will we get there? There's a (big) elephant in the room, which Iâ€™m calling the CAMP framework. 

To pull off outcome-based pricing, you need four things:
- Consistency of outcomes across customer types
- Attribution for those outcomes
- Measurability, ideally in real-time
- Predictability of outcomes

Without CAMP, outcome-based pricing is just hype. I'll be following along to see how the first-movers navigate this ðŸ‘€

#genai #aimonetization #pricing

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
THOUGHT LEADER DOWN

Breaking News

Exit Five Founder & CEO Dave Gerhardt hits the injured list for the next 8-12 weeks after successful surgery to fi
text:
THOUGHT LEADER DOWN

Breaking News

Exit Five Founder & CEO Dave Gerhardt hits the injured list for the next 8-12 weeks after successful surgery to fix femoroacetabular impingement and labral tear in his right hip.

Despite the pain he is currently in, Gerhardt - an eternal optimist - remains positive given the extreme privilege of his situation.

"My job requires sending Slack messages, posting on LinkedIn, and taking phone calls. I'm very lucky. I will get through this and I'm looking forward to the mental challenge of recovery."

In an interview with Forbes, Gerhardt also comment that he would have been "absolutely fucked" if he stuck to his ways as a solopreneur. 

Now with a full-time team of 7 people working on Exit Five, Gerhardt will be able to recover in peace while his business continues to grow and he can stick to writing witty comments on LinkedIn and giving feedback in Slack over the next few months.

"Before you know it, I will be back running, lifting, rucking, cross country skiing, and doing all the necessary things I need to do to calm my inner thoughts and demons, but for now this is mostly going to be a battle of me vs. myself."

Please do not send any flowers or edible arrangements. 

Instead, tell as many people that work in marketing as possible about the amazing company that is known as Exit Five and make sure to join the email list on the website.

Note: I don't want your sympathy, I am fine and very lucky. I just knew this is the perfect type of thing to post on LinkedIn and it will help grow our business.

We will 100% turn this into a Thought Leader ad too.

PS. Who is more charming - Real Dave or AI Dave? 

#youseeme

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
Introducing the 2025 GTM scorecard, just in time for annual planning â¤µï¸ 

Maja and I surveyed 195 B2B leaders about which GTM channels are working rig
text:
Introducing the 2025 GTM scorecard, just in time for annual planning â¤µï¸ 

Maja and I surveyed 195 B2B leaders about which GTM channels are working right now. We then mapped how popular different GTM channels are (x-axis) versus how likely they are to be impactful among adopters (y-axis).

The shorthand for interpreting this two-by-two:
1. Tried-and-true (upper right)
2. Oversaturated (lower right)
3. The next big thing (upper left)
4. Figuring it out (lower left)

I then cut the data for startups (<$10M ARR) vs. scaleups (>$10M ARR) & it's fascinating to see how the channels shift.

The best channels for startups*:
 - LinkedIn (#1)
 - Founder brand (#2)
 - Warm outbound (#3)
 - Intent-based outbound (#4)
 - Intimate events (#5)

*The magic tends to happen when you can combine these channels into a cohesive strategy, i.e. founder brand + LinkedIn + warm outbound & intimate events for those who engage.

The best channels for scaleups*:
 - Large conferences (#1)
 - SEO (#2)
 - Intimate events (#3)
 - Big product launches (#4)
 - Ecosystem marketing (#5)

*Scaleups are still seeing returns from their years of SEO investments. The question is whether they can translate their SEO into AI discovery or if they'll be leap-frogged by new entrants.

The TL;DR: No matter what stage you're at, you might want to plan for more intimate events (dinners, happy hours, etc.) next year. They're not the most scalable, but they're one of the few things that seems to work.

PS, the full report is available here: https://lnkd.in/ea_zYUzB

#marketing #gtm #startups

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Just so you know, hiring a new marketing agency isnâ€™t going to fix your GTM problem.

All youâ€™re doing is changing the pit crew for your race car.Â Sur
text:
Just so you know, hiring a new marketing agency isnâ€™t going to fix your GTM problem.

All youâ€™re doing is changing the pit crew for your race car.Â Sure they may change the wheels better (and thatâ€™s a good thing), but itâ€™s not going to be why you win the race.Â And it's not going to help much if your race car sucks.

And hereâ€™s the key insight: Even though many resources to fix this problem come from Marketing, the Marketing department canâ€™t fix this on their own. 

This is truly a GTM problem, not a Marketing problem. And the only people who can truly solve this are the CEO and CFO. 

Because the GTM planning model, governed by finance and monitored by the board, is likely the reason your Marketing is under-delivering in the first place. 

Itâ€™s not due to lack of talent, technology, or resources.

Itâ€™s because our GTM planning and attribution model drives all of the wrong behaviors with our $15MM per year on Marketing and SDRs. And totally fails to give us proper insights to build a confident go-forward plan to accelerate growth.

There are only 2 things that happen when you change your marketing agency in hopes they come and save the day, but fail to change the KPIs that determine success of Marketing overall and the agency:

1. The Marketing agency succumbs to your outdated attribution model and runs ineffective campaigns because they appease your attribution model. In 6 months, you see no â€œresultsâ€ and give up. You waste 6 months and a lot of money and go nowhere.

2. The Marketing agency runs their more effective Marketing strategies aligned to business results, but since you didnâ€™t change your planning and attribution models, at the exec level, it looks like the agency isnâ€™t working. After 6 months, you unknowingly cut bait on a strategy thatâ€™s working because you measure the wrong things to determine success.

No wonder companies change marketing agencies every 12 months.....and then they blame the problem on the agency or fire the CMO.

When a Marketing agency fails, itâ€™s YOUR FAULT. Itâ€™s your fault for not setting them up for success, aligning their activities to growth rate and ROI, and setting clear guardrails around performance.

In fact, it doesnâ€™t matter who runs your demand gen program - whether itâ€™s an agency or an in-house team.

If the CEO and CFO donâ€™t change their GTM planning and attribution modeling, youâ€™re very unlikely to see a tangible impact on business results just by changing internal or external talent for campaign execution.

I imagine this isnâ€™t a â€œpopular opinionâ€ but donâ€™t shoot the messenger. Iâ€™m just here telling you what you need to hear instead of what you want to hear ðŸ™‚ 

Nothing changes if nothing changes. CEOs, CFOs, and Boards need to fix the real problem. 

#marketing #b2b #gtm #sales #finance

Yes, I own an 8-figure marketing agency. The companies that see overwhelming success are the ones who change their KPIs to focus on how Marketing investments deliver high ROI, lower CAC, and accelerate growth rate.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: Fyxer was a sleepy virtual EA firm from 2016-2022. Then they pivoted to AI, aspiring to be Cursor for email. And growth has since *exploded* â€” from $1
text:
Fyxer was a sleepy virtual EA firm from 2016-2022. Then they pivoted to AI, aspiring to be Cursor for email. And growth has since *exploded* â€” from $1 to $17M ARR in the last 8 months.

Some quick stats on Fyxer AI:
ðŸ‘‰ Founded & run by two brothers, Archie and Richard.
ðŸ‘‰ Raised a $10M Series A led by Harry at 20VC with backing from Marc Benioff & Lenny. Then raised a $30M Series B led by Madrona only 6 months later.
ðŸ‘‰ This is real ARR -- 90% of paying users stick around >3 months & net revenue retention (NRR) is 150%+ in most cohorts (ðŸ¤¯).

Today's Growth Unhinged unpacks how they did it. Read the story here: https://lnkd.in/ejF7Vxte

Fyxer's consumer to enterprise AI expansion playbook in 5 steps:

Step 1: Make the product dead simple for everyday people.

The onboarding process feels almost non-existent; once youâ€™ve integrated your calendar, it's essentially ready to go. 

There are no complicated shortcuts. But you can easily adapt it to your preferences by toggling a slider or adding a few extra sentences to the style prompt.

Step 2: Turn to influencers to get initial traction.

From zero to $1M ARR, Fyxerâ€™s biggest growth lever was definitively non-sexy. It was Archie sliding into DMs and begging people to post on LinkedIn. 

Each influencer post attracted about 20-30 new signups. (Btw, there wasnâ€™t much correlation between an influencerâ€™s size and their impact.)

Step 3: Go big with consumer performance marketing.

Performance marketing now drives about half of Fyxerâ€™s new growth. 

Their ad cadence is relentless. Two-week sprints, 200+ ads live at any given moment, 100-150 new creative variations every sprint. This is powered by (lots) of AI tools incl. ChatGPT, Claude, ReelFarm, Arcads AI, ElevenLabs, HeyGen, Synthesia, Motion & Getdot.ai. 

Step 4: Refine GTM around business users and enterprise expansion.

Work email signups are worth 10x more than personal emails.Â The top KPI for performance marketing: cost-per-work-email.

Step 5: Continuously improve AI and reactivate users along the way.

One of the biggest reasons why initial Fyxer signups didnâ€™t convert was that the AI wasnâ€™tÂ quiteÂ good enough yet.Â The next unlock is re-activating these users. They're doing it with trial re-starts & a human-seeming email â€œfromâ€ a founder (Archie in particular).

Hope you find this useful ðŸ™

---

Today's newsletter is supported by Metronome. They're running a ðŸ”¥ webinar on how Snowflake built their Monetization Operating Model (link in comments).

#ai #genai #startup

author: Jordan Crawford
hook:
â€œCongrats on scaling Blueprintâ€ <â€” NEVER try to scale a compliment and hereâ€™s whyâ€¦

The whole purpose of a compliment is that itâ€™s from the heart, gen
text:
â€œCongrats on scaling Blueprintâ€ <â€” NEVER try to scale a compliment and hereâ€™s whyâ€¦

The whole purpose of a compliment is that itâ€™s from the heart, genuine. 

Also, the whole purpose of automation for sales is to open up conversations.

But how you begin impacts where and if you get to end. 

This is why I have only two frameworks for messaging:

PQS
PVP

A PQS is a pain qualified segment and it simply means that the list is the message, 

â€œJordan given that you post everyday and comment on 10 posts or so a day, you spend a ton of time on LinkedIn, no? If you could be shown only Vertical SaaS CROs and CEOs in your feedâ€”would that likely mark your comments more powerful?â€

The list youâ€™d build in this case is active commenters on linkedin who are engaging a lot with non-ICP accounts (if this was a productâ€”like customized LinkedIn feed).

A PVP is a message SO GOOD youâ€™d pay to received it. Permissionless Value Prop. Hereâ€™s what that would look likeâ€¦

â€œJordan, given your activity on LinkedIn, and that only 10% of your last 100 comments were on vSaaS brandsâ€”I thought Iâ€™d give you a list of 500 CROs and CEOs of vSaaS B2B brands that posted on linkedin 20+ times in the last month, and hereâ€™s a ChatGPT prompt to have Atlas auto-follow each one.â€

This is a message that carries independent value to me.

Nothing about fake compliments or ball fluffery, just pure hard value.

Then, when you get on the call, tell me I have beautiful blue eyes or some garbage. That way I know itâ€™s true and you e protected your integrity and you can skippy do dah in the rain with your automated quality messages at scale.
