author: Chris Walker
hook:
Contrary to popular belief, having a GTM team offsite will not fix your go-to-market problem. 

Neither will a pipeline meeting on Wednesdays. 

Neith
text:
Contrary to popular belief, having a GTM team offsite will not fix your go-to-market problem. 

Neither will a pipeline meeting on Wednesdays. 

Neither will a CMO-CRO bi-weekly coffee meeting. 

Neither will firing your CMO and trying to hire a unicorn marketing leader. 

Itâ€™s a Band-Aid. 

It might make it easier for people to work together. 

It might patch up the problem for a while that will come back to you in 3 months when youâ€™re missing your pipeline for Q4. 

Itâ€™s a Band-Aid. 

The real solution? 

Redesign your GTM (aka the Factory that produces your revenue) - Starting with Financial Planning, Modeling, and Budgeting, and then working across the rest of GTM team to Sales, Marketing, Sales Dev, Ops, Post-Sale, etc. 

1. Build a Unified View of GTM with Financial Data & GTM Data that measures both performance (effectiveness) and unit economics (efficiency)

2. Align the entire GTM leadership team on a core KPI stack that has *nothing* to do with attribution by department or channel 

3. Categorize and evaluate GTM investment portfolio allocation by customer lifecycle stage, NOT DEPARTMENT. 

4. Methodically break down compound metrics to isolate the biggest issues / risks / opportunities by customer lifecycle stage

5. Build and align on cross-functional initiatives to solve the biggest issues in your Revenue Factory 

6. Monitor and evaluate impact against the core KPI stack that has nothing to do with attribution by department or channel. 

#finance #gtm #b2b #sales #marketing

p.s. Just to drive home the message - you should be able to *clearly* understand how your GTM is performing and isolate the biggest issues/opportunities without ever discussing or using attribution by channel or department ðŸ™‚

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Attribution (the tool) isnâ€™t the problem. Itâ€™s how itâ€™s used (the process) in B2B companies that is the real problem. 

Just like using a hammer (the
text:
Attribution (the tool) isnâ€™t the problem. Itâ€™s how itâ€™s used (the process) in B2B companies that is the real problem. 

Just like using a hammer (the tool) to pour concrete (the process) doesnâ€™t make sense.

You wouldnâ€™t blame the hammer. You wouldnâ€™t try to switch from a hammer to a mallet. Youâ€™d fix the process and use different tools. 

The *PROCESS* is the real problem. But I watch almost every B2B company try to fix it by changing the *TOOL*. 

What a miss. Which results in:

-Massive GTM Team Misalignment

-Marketing / SDR / Partner teams fighting over credit based on whatever attribution model you choose 

-Lack of data visibility to make confident decisions around how to scale Marketing and SDR investments 

-Financeâ€™s over-simplistic ROI calculations by department and channel provide zero strategic insights for what to do next

-Most GTM leaders default to spending more money, hiring more reps, requesting more budget. Rather than getting more efficient 

-RevOps wasting months debating whether they should switch from a first touch to a linear model & making no changes

-Sales starving at the bottom of the funnel, so they need to do low-quality prospecting which increases CAC & kills scalability 

-CFO feels like Marketing & SDRs arenâ€™t working, but doesnâ€™t know how to drill into CRM data to confirm & figure out what to do next

What a mess. 

And meanwhile, it costs shareholders and investors more than $50MM every quarter that it doesnâ€™t get fixed. And delays the time horizon for the compounding power of a SaaS businesses. 

Itâ€™s one of the most painful, expensive problems in the entire B2B industry today. 

How to fix it:

1. Adopt a shared â€œFirst Teamâ€ Department-Agnostic set of GTM KPIs 

2. Create a new structure and taxonomy for how you tag, track, and evaluate all GTM investments that is smarter and more sophisticated than which department spent the money. 

3. Fix your CRM architecture so you actually have visibility and tracking of KPIs (not touchpoints!!) across the entire pipeline process so you can proper invest, optimize, and scale investments to Create Pipeline 

4. Build Revenue Factory instrumentation that uses touchpoint data and other forms of statistics in a variety of views to answer key specific questions

5. CFO oversees and optimizes the entire GTM investment portfolio and strategic roadmap to get the best short-term and long-term ROI. 

Your Pipeline Problem is the most expensive problem in your entire company. 

Stop trying to change the tool and instead fix the process!! And when you do, you add hundreds of millions of dollars to your company's value and build a true path to scalability and IPO. 

#finance #gtm #b2b #saas #marketing

p.s. Attribution has historically been a "Marketing" tool. But in reality, it's used across the entire customer lifecycle & impacts the entire GTM, including Finance.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
GTM Efficiency is the #1 issue for CEOs and CFOs today. 

And Finance is the department whoâ€™s going to solve it. 

This key performance indicator enco
text:
GTM Efficiency is the #1 issue for CEOs and CFOs today. 

And Finance is the department whoâ€™s going to solve it. 

This key performance indicator encompasses Growth Rate and Unit Economics - the two biggest drivers of increasing enterprise value in a B2B company today. 

The problem is that departments inside a GTM engine try to calculate these numbers individually to â€œprove the ROIâ€ of their department-level investments without consideration or visibility into the top-level financial metrics. 

The Marketing Department calculates â€œAdvertising CACâ€ and takes the digital advertising spend and divides it by website-sourced revenue and calculates a 9-Month Advertising CAC payback period. 

The Demand Gen team celebrates for hitting their goal. 

The SDR team calculates â€œcost per meeting bookedâ€ and takes all the meetings booked and divides it by the number of SDRs and calculates a $2,000 cost per meeting booked.

The SDR team celebrates booking meetings at what seems to be an acceptable efficiency. 

What these calculations miss is all of the additional costs outside of their department that are required to acquire this revenue:

-9 additional months in other Marketing programs (AR / PR / Events / Content / etc.)
-9 additional months in Marketing headcount
-9 additional months in SDR headcount
-18 additional months in Sales expenses (AE, SE, etc.)
-9 additional months in Operations, Tech, Admin, Tools 

And all of a sudden, the Demand Gen team is celebrating a 9-month advertising CAC payback period while the CFO is calculating a total CAC payback period of 56 months. 

Department siloâ€™s look vertically and measure the cost of their small part of the process.

Go-To-Market leaders look horizontally across the entire customer journey to understand the full cost of acquiring, retaining, and expanding an account. 

The CEO and CFO are the only two executives with the view of the entire go-to-market performance. 

They are responsible for deploying a portfolio of investments (Marketing, Sales, SDRs, Operations, Enablement, Tech/Tools, Admin, etc.) to get an appropriate ROI of incremental ARR. 

#finance #gotomarket #gtm #b2b #sales

___

GTM Efficiency = [ Total GTM Spend / Total Net New ARR ] x 100%

Simply put, GTM Efficiency of 100% means it takes $1 in GTM costs to acquire $1 in incremental ARR. 

If a company experiences more than 6 fiscal quarters of GTM Efficiency > 200%, management must recognize that their GTM model has become unsustainable.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
â€œOur Marketing Investments have a time lagâ€. Partially true. And simultaneously incredibly misleading. Letâ€™s break it down ðŸ‘‡

This blanket statement s
text:
â€œOur Marketing Investments have a time lagâ€. Partially true. And simultaneously incredibly misleading. Letâ€™s break it down ðŸ‘‡

This blanket statement shouldn't be a blanket statement. And this mindset leaves tons of CFOs confused, leads to CMOs fired every 18 months, and degrades company KPIs & performance.

1. *Some* â€œMarketingâ€ Investments, when executed properly, have a time lag. 

First, â€œMarketingâ€ is a terrible category for investments that include short-term and long-term, strategic and tactical - massively competing objectives. 

For the past 6 years, I've personally executed Demand Creation programs that have a time lag to results: Non-Conversion-Based organic social media, podcasts, live events, influencer collaborations, etc. I understand these programs deeply & have driven $50MM+ in revenue for my own businesses through them.

*Some* Marketing investments have a time lag. Yet go to any B2B SaaS company IRL & almost none of the investments fall into these categories.

2. Most B2B Marketing programs are the same as 4-8 quarters ago. Meaning the â€œtime lagâ€ has already passed.

Itâ€™s different if youâ€™re $500k ARR & just getting off the ground. But B2B Marketing strategies & investments for a $100MM company are the same as they were 2+ years ago. The time lag has passed & results (ROI) are still going down. Have you waited long enough yet?

3. A majority (up to 90%) of B2B â€œMarketingâ€ investments are spent on short-term activities. You can use leading indicator KPIs so you donâ€™t need to wait a year to know if the investments will pay off.

Up to 90% of â€œMarketingâ€ investments are Performance Marketing objectives and measured against leads, meetings, and pipeline. Thatâ€™s the goal. 

So if you make an investment and then donâ€™t get a meetingâ€¦..that means you also wonâ€™t get pipeline. And also wonâ€™t get revenue. You donâ€™t need to wait 6-12 months for the â€œtime lagâ€ to know itâ€™s ineffective. 

4. Tons of â€œMarketingâ€ investments are totally useless. The time lag theory confuses people into thinking if they just wait 12 months, the investments will start â€œworkingâ€ when they never will. 

-Whatâ€™s the time lag of a display ad that loads on the page but never gets seen?

-Whatâ€™s the time lag of a tradeshow booth that 99% of attendees never see?

-Whatâ€™s the time lag of a $12 CPC Google Ads that a bot clicks on and bounces immediately?

-Whatâ€™s the time lag of a cold call that doesnâ€™t get answered?

-Whatâ€™s the time lag of an e-book that gets downloaded and never opened or read?

-Whatâ€™s the time lag of an email that gets opened just so the recipient can click unsubscribe?

_

Just because you can track something doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s valuable. Or that results will eventually come if you just wait long enough. 

_

Would you rather learn how to build a rocket from Elon Musk or a physics professor who teaches theory but has never done it before?

There's a big difference between reciting knowledge from a 1980s textbook and mastering the craft in real life.

author: Chris Walker
hook:
Bottoms-Up vs. Tops-Down GTM Analytics

Letâ€™s break down the differences ðŸ‘‡

Bottoms Up GTM Analytics: Data and reporting is generated & analyzed from
text:
Bottoms-Up vs. Tops-Down GTM Analytics

Letâ€™s break down the differences ðŸ‘‡

Bottoms Up GTM Analytics: Data and reporting is generated & analyzed from each budget holder then assembled into a department-level deck then again assembled into one large GTM report.

Most B2B companies primarily use this approach and itâ€™s clear it has significant drawbacks when used in isolation:

-Every report uses different data & properties
-Conflicting findings across teams & departments
-Way too tactical & complicated for executives to understand & make decisions
-Core objective is to prove/justify how well everything is performing
-Looks like every investment is working

And this bottoms-up reporting philosophy leads to:

- Focus on micro-optimizations and tactical changes
- Loses sight of the bigger picture
- Decisions that should be fast & easy become slow & hard
- Indecision / Inaction
- Misalignment across the GTM teams around what to do next

To solve this, B2B executives should run a Tops-Down Analytics process in parallel to the bottoms-up.

Tops-Down GTM Analytics: Data and reporting starts with *business metrics* and systematically works down to departments and budget holders, leveraging a standardized and consistent reporting structure across the entire GTM.

The Tops-Down GTM Analytics process:

-Starts with the most critical business metrics - growth rate, NRR, GRR, S&M % of Net New ARR, etc
-The top level business performance metrics set the context for why weâ€™re analyzing the lower-level data
-Leverages standardizes data & fields across the entire GTM
-Breaks down the department-level siloâ€™s and uses a holistic view of performance & investments across the entire GTM
-Analyzes and reports at the right altitude so all executives (CEO, CFO, CMO, CRO, etc.) can all understand
-The objective is to fuel *DECISION MAKING*. Not to prove or justify.Â 
-Puts objective scrutiny on each investment. A lot more frequently we need to be asking the question â€œwhat isnâ€™t workingâ€ instead of trying to prove everything is working.

This tops-down analytics philosophy leads to:

-Strategic & transformational changes
-Fast & aligned decision making
-Fast, clear identification of low ROI investments
-Focused on the bigger picture

Most B2B companies are stuck. And this is the root cause. Midmarket and Enterprise SaaS companies have well-constructed strategies, esteemed investors, strong products, and brilliant people. What they are missing is the core data foundation and analytics engine across their holistic go-to-market motions and investments.

Running these two processes in parallel ensures B2B executives have the right data to quickly flag and diagnose important issues, identify major opportunities, get cross-functional alignment, and forecast & plan with confidence. While still ensuring that the departments and teams have the process and autonomy to advance micro optimizations and tactical changes.

Itâ€™s not an either or, itâ€™s both.

#gtm #gotomarket #revops #b2b

author: Dave Gerhardt
hook:
Content marketers run modern marketing.

Because almost all marketing today is shaped online.

And online marketing shows up as:

- Ads
- Videos
- Art
text:
Content marketers run modern marketing.

Because almost all marketing today is shaped online.

And online marketing shows up as:

- Ads
- Videos
- Articles
- Podcasts and clips like this with Jess Cook
- Social posts
- Newsletters
- Communities
- Influencers

Different formats. But none of it works without a clear content strategy and strong content marketing.

Jess is a great example of this: she started her career as a copywriter for big CPG brands. She cut her teeth writing 200+ variations of a recipe for Rice Krispie Treats.

Then built a career in content marketing: content market manager, director, VP brand and content.

Then turned that into a Head of Marketing role at a startup and was recently promoted to VP on the heels of her success using - wait for it - content to drive revenue.

Not because Vector's content gets a lot of impressions and their podcast is unique or because their little mascot is cute.

But because it's working! Those things are driving revenue. 

I had a conversation with Jess last week (now out on my podcast) and she shared three key marketing plays that she's run over the past year:

1. Influencer Marketing - how does it work in B2B, how did she find influencers, what did it cost, how much pipeline was generated, how did they measure it

2. Podcasting - why they started a podcast, how their podcast stands out, how they record, when/where, how they prep, how they know it's working

3. LinkedIn - we talk a bit about what content types (and strategy) is working well here today

4. Career Path - her path from content to VP Marketing

Erin on my team messaged me last night and said this was the best interview we've done recently - please go listen if you need some tactical inspiration.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
Software products are starting to all look the same. Seemingly everyone is putting the prompt box front and center.

It'll be harder & harder to diffe
text:
Software products are starting to all look the same. Seemingly everyone is putting the prompt box front and center.

It'll be harder & harder to differentiate on the *user* experience. We're going to need to differentiate on the *agent* experience instead.

What I'm seeing from the best products:

1. Product education starts *before* even hitting the website.

With a prompt box UX, the user needs to come to the product already armed with an idea about how to use it. 

Folks are educating users through hackathons, communities, slick launch videos & asking influencers to show off what they've built. Template libraries still work, too. (Half of Lovable's homepage is now devoted to UGC templates.)

2. The product helps you improve your prompt.

Most of us (myself included) aren't prompt engineers. And a garbage prompt can often mean a garbage result -- and not much patience to keep going.

The best products help us clarify our ideas, turning "meh" prompts into "omg" prompts. I particularly love the one-click "enhance prompt" feature in products like bolt.new and Replit.

3. The agentic UX isn't one-and-done.

The UX shouldn't just complete the task and move on. The best agentic experiences recommend next steps & help you do them. 

They can also become the best sales rep for the product: proactively encouraging you to upgrade & then suggesting the plan that's best for you. After all, helping was always the best way of selling.

4. The agent isn't a black box.

The best tools include a preview mode & give users the ability to edit what AI produces. 

It's not just a "do it for me" experience, it's a "do it with me" experience that leads to an outcome people feel great about.

---

The innovation isn't putting a prompt box in the app. It's creating an agentic UX that (finally) feels personal & maybe a bit magical.

ðŸŽ For more growth insights, join 78k+ pros who read Growth Unhinged -- my free weekly newsletter: https://lnkd.in/exTbjKaM

#ai #ux #genai

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: A few weeks ago I shared data that most SaaS startups never make it. Just 3.5% reach $20 million in ARR within ten years of monetizing, worse odds tha
text:
A few weeks ago I shared data that most SaaS startups never make it. Just 3.5% reach $20 million in ARR within ten years of monetizing, worse odds than getting into Harvard. What makes those outliers different â¤µï¸

I investigated new data from ChartMogul, the SaaS metrics & growth platform where I'm an Analyst-in-Residence. Their dataset covers 6,525 software companies with historical data going back 10+ years.

What I found surprised me. The winners didnâ€™t necessarilyÂ *start*Â better. TheyÂ *became*Â better, reinventing their startups from $1M to $20M ARR.

The four key takeaways you need to know:

1. Interestingly, starting metrics at $1M ARR were pretty similar for the companies that made it to $20M & those who stalled out.

The main difference was MoM growth rate. Outliers were growing 16.7% MoM on average; others were growing 8.7%. But even this wasnâ€™t as pronounced as it appears. 

The top quartile of those who *didn't* make it outpaced more than half of the outliers. Clearly, starting momentum isn't the only factor at play.

2. The outliers were meaningfully better at improving their growth metrics compared to everyone else.

Few managed to accelerate growth rates. But the majority got better at everything else including:

 - Average revenue per account:Â 72% improved by more than 10%
 - Share of MRR on annual plans:Â 71% improved by more than 10%
 - Gross revenue retention:Â 51% improved by more than 10%
 - Net revenue retention:Â 45% improved by more than 10%

3. Outliers raised prices, increasing avg revenue per account by 82% (!) from $1 to $20M. This was 20 pts better than others.

There are many paths to a higher revenue per account. The common denominator is to increase perceived value over time while simultaneously monetizing that extra value.

4. Outliers got better at expanding their customers with NRR increasing by about 10 percentage points. This was 6 pts better than others, which compounds year after year.

A major driver of this is shifting from single product to multi-product, allowing for more surface area to expand customers.

---

See the full report in Growth Unhinged here: https://lnkd.in/eva67mqr

A special thank you to founders Alina Vandenberghe ðŸŒ¶ï¸, Daniel Lang, Archie Hollingsworth, Amjad Masad, Zeb Evans, and Varun Anand for sharing their ðŸ”¥ learnings on the $1 to $20M ARR journey.

#startups #saas #retention #pricing

author: Kyle Poyar
hook:
Iâ€™ve worked with 100+ software companies on monetization. What I really think of your pricing model:

Flat-fee pricing: ðŸ¥±
Feature-based: ðŸ˜ˆ 
Seat-based
text:
Iâ€™ve worked with 100+ software companies on monetization. What I really think of your pricing model:

Flat-fee pricing: ðŸ¥±
Feature-based: ðŸ˜ˆ 
Seat-based: ðŸ¦–
Usage-based: ðŸŽ¢ 
Hybrid pricing: ðŸ¤“ 
Outcome-based: â„ï¸ 

Your pricing is (probably) broken. Just like everyone else. But donâ€™t abandon your pricing, fix it. 

Full deep dive in todayâ€™s Growth Unhinged newsletter (with tactical examples of what to do): https://lnkd.in/eWhsq4Rq

Ok, ready for the pricing roast?!?

1. Flat-fee pricing: Donâ€™t expect to make $$

- Small companies get priced out
- Large companies pay too little
- Thereâ€™s no expansion revenue
- High potential for low/negative margin customers

2. Feature-based: Bundle hell

- Almost everyone defaults to the middle tier
- The plans are arbitrary and confusing
- Everyone wants to pick-and-choose
- New features throw your plans into a tailspin

3. Seat-based: Isnâ€™t that a dinosaur?

- Companies are cutting heads with AI, meaning less seat $$
- The value of AI agents doesnâ€™t scale with buying more seats
- Not all users are the same. Why should they pay the same for a seat?
- Puts a cap on potential $$ of an account

4. Usage-based: TradCFOs hate it

- Itâ€™s too hard to forecast
- Not all usage = ROI for the customer
- Customers self-police their usage, hurting long-term growth
- Thereâ€™s not a clear usage metric that correlates with value

5. Hybrid pricing: Iâ€™m gonna need a PhD to figure out how much this costs 

- Thereâ€™s way too much complexity
- Itâ€™s impossible to calculate costs
- Too hard to manage (quoting, billing, UX, etc.)
- Feels like a bait-and-switch

6. Outcome-based: Itâ€™s a pipe dream 

- Measuring outcomes feels impossible
- Customers fight over the bill
- Impossible to estimate outcomes upfront
- You donâ€™t get credit for anything beyond one specific outcome

â€”

There is no such thing as a perfect pricing model. 

The best you can do is to choose the pricing model that allows you to tell the unique story of what you do, who youâ€™re for, and why youâ€™re better than the alternative. And have a plan to manage the inevitable downsides.

â€”

Todayâ€™s newsletter is supported by Metronome. Donâ€™t miss their ðŸ”¥ webinar with a16z on the future of monetization (link in comments).

#pricing #monetization #startups

text:
Something I'm digging about credits: Using them to gamify onboarding ðŸ˜

It's like Dropbox's famous "get free storage space by inviting your friends", but modernized for the AI era.

Users get credits for (a) completing key onboarding steps, (b) watching tutorials & videos on advanced features, and even (c) inviting friends/colleagues to sign up.

Then credits can be spent on, well, anything. Data (phone numbers, emails), enrichment, AI power-ups, etc.

author: Kyle Poyar
hook: Yesterday, ChatGPT hit 2.5 BILLION (ðŸ¤¯) prompts per day, up from 1 billion in December. It's quickly approaching Google's 14 billion daily searches. Ge
text:
Yesterday, ChatGPT hit 2.5 BILLION (ðŸ¤¯) prompts per day, up from 1 billion in December. It's quickly approaching Google's 14 billion daily searches. Getting recommended by AI engines is no longer just a weekend side project (*guilty*).

Josh Blyskal from Profound analyzed data from 100,000 prompts to figure out how these AI engines actually work. Here are nine practical takeaways that you could start applying now to improve your AI search visibility:

(Don't miss the full deep dive in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/e2GdwgNN)

1. Decide which prompts you want to own.

2. Be aware that answer engines behave differently. ChatGPT & Perplexity share only 11% of domain citations. 

3. Write specialized, specific content. 

4. Create surround sound around your product. The best starting points are UGC & social media sites like Reddit, LinkedIn, YouTube, and Quora.

5. Get mentioned on Reddit. It's the single most-cited domain in ChatGPT & Perplexity. 

6. Use structured comparisons and lists. Remember that ChatGPT loves to "borrow" entire answers in chunks rather than do the thinking itself.

7. Make fewer images and more tables. AI engines can't see images well.

8. Measure your influence, not just clicks. The vast majority of AI search is zero-click (but it can still be highly influential.)

9. Stay on top of citation drift. Half of domains cited change in a given month.

Hope you find this useful! If you have other learnings, drop 'em in the comments ðŸ™

#ai #aeo #chatgpt #marketing

author: Chris Walker
hook:
You canâ€™t plan your Marketing budget for 2025 without first understanding:

1. GRR % and NRR %.Â 
2. How your Marketing budget is currently allocated a
text:
You canâ€™t plan your Marketing budget for 2025 without first understanding:

1. GRR % and NRR %.Â 
2. How your Marketing budget is currently allocated and balanced across the customer lifecycleÂ 
3. Total GTM Efficiency % and Growth Rate
4. New Logo CAC
5. Sales Productivity metrics like PRP and Close New Logo Efficiency %
6. Total Sales costs, total SDR costs and all other new logo expensesÂ 
7. Total Marketing headcount costs, technology and the ratio of these compared to program expensesÂ 
8. Trending opportunity Win Rates by stageÂ 
9. Trending ROI of Pipeline Creation investmentsÂ 
10. And likely 15+ other variables 

You canâ€™t analyze your â€œGrowth Marketingâ€ performance and investments without first understanding the full business context and methodically breaking down performance:

LEVEL 1: The Total GTM Performance (GTM Efficiency %, Growth Rate, NRR %, etc.) 

LEVEL 2: New Logo Performance (New Logo GTM Efficiency %, T12 Win Rate & Historical Trend, etc.) 

LEVEL 3: Pipeline Creation Performance (Normalized Pipeline:Spend Ratio, Win Rates by Opportunity Stage, etc.) 

LEVEL 4: Prospecting Effectiveness & Initial Conversion (SDR, AE, etc.). What is our efficiency and effectiveness in engaging in-market accounts into Sales opportunities? 

LEVEL 5: Supply Chain Analysis - Analyze all major investments deployed to create signals for Sales Triggers *comprehensively* including both 1st and 3rd party (data platforms, performance marketing, MQL scores, technology vendors)

LEVEL 6: Demand Creation Investments (some people call this â€œbrandâ€) - Leverage custom analytics to analyze the performance of the (relatively insignificant) amount of budget that currently goes to this category using MTA, MMM, customer research or other means. 

LEVEL 7: THE DATA MODEL. To access this level of connected compound metrics that create fast, clear granular insights, you need the foresight, planning, and architecture to construct a CRM and Financial data model for your go-to-market that collects & analyzes the data as 1 REVENUE FACTORY rather than 4-6 siloâ€™d departments. 

___

CEOs & CFOs are allocating $50MM+ of GTM Investments each year and the process of silo'd department-level planning and investment scrutiny is archaic and ineffective. 

The days of Marketing leaders asking for an arbitrary amount of â€œmore budgetâ€ each year or applying blanket % increases across the GTM are OVER. 

-GTM Budgets, Departmental Allocations, and Allocations across the customer lifecycle can and should be set based on a clear process and data. 

-Business cases for increased GTM budgets, such as Marketing budget increases, should be easy to prepare & OBVIOUS whether or not to approve

-Imbalances of investment across the customer lifecycle, relative to performance, should be OBVIOUS to flag and address through GTM investment portfolio rebalancing

-Everyone on the GTM team should be aligned on #1 priority across the entire GTM 

#marketing #b2b #finance #sales #strategicplanning

author: Chris Walker
hook:
The Demand Waterfall / Predictable Revenue MQL hamster wheel is cracking like cheap glass. 

In fact, it has been for more than 5 years. The data was
text:
The Demand Waterfall / Predictable Revenue MQL hamster wheel is cracking like cheap glass. 

In fact, it has been for more than 5 years. The data was clear in 2018 that this strategy of getting tons of cheap MQLs so our SDRs can cold call them results in:

-Untenable customer acquisition cost (CAC)
-Extreme sales/marketing alignment issuesÂ 
-Low Sales productivityÂ 
-Poor Marketing ROIÂ 
-Totally breaks with scale 

But we were in the boom times from 2018-2022. Money was cheap and companies were operating for â€œgrowth at all costsâ€. Investors pushed companies to deploy massive amounts of capital to grow, regardless of the unit economics. 

Most companies didnâ€™t care (or didnâ€™t even look at the data to see) that their â€œMQLsâ€ converted to customers at 0.1% (1 out of 1,000 â€œleadsâ€ actually become a customer). This extreme inefficiency forced companies to overhire SDRs and Sales Reps to sort through all this garbage trying to find a needle in a haystack. Marketing programs, SDR headcount, and Sales headcount costs bloated across the entire GTM. 

Now, itâ€™s 2024 and thereâ€™s been a total 180-degree turn in B2B. Every company is forced to operate for â€œprofitable, efficient growthâ€. 

-Revenue growth rates are down > 50%
-NRR has consistently declined for the past 6+ quarters
-CAC payback periods have more than doubled to 36 to 48+ months
-Budgets are tightening
-GTM teams are shrinking
-More layoffs are coming
-And unit economics and EBITDA margin are now the top priorities

Companies are stuck making incremental optimizations to these outdated models like trying to improve the MQL:SQL conversion rate by 2% or improve outbound connect rates by 1% or lowering the cost per lead by $12. 

But Incremental improvements arenâ€™t going to get the job done.

This new era of profitable, efficient growth (PEG) requires a fundamentally new approach to B2B Go-To-Market. The financial metrics *require* it and we've just about reached the breaking point. 

#b2b #gtm #marketing #sales #gotomarket

p.s. Changing from an MQL to an MQA feels like a good solution but doesnâ€™t solve the root cause problem. Itâ€™s the exact same motion just with a different trigger to activate outbound Sales. Lots of companies and executives I talk to are scratching their heads wondering why ABM and account intent data isnâ€™t living up to its promise.

â€œ{{ge
text:
AI message personalization is A CANCER on sales and hereâ€™s what to do INSTEADâ€¦

Think about what just happened in this messageâ€¦

===============
â€œ{{generic summarized fact about me that sounds like a robot wrote it}}â€

â€œHereâ€™s what everyone doesâ€

â€œHereâ€™s what we doâ€

â€œWe are cheap and crappyâ€

An offer to read more
===============

Why does this suck you ask? Oh let me count the ways.

1. Letâ€™s just assume you can fix the intro to make it less robot, the problem is that because the targeting is just â€œfoundersâ€ dude literally told me about my own work and completely violated the teachings, without even addressing that. Which mean itâ€™s a lie, he didnâ€™t read my work. So the message is now hollow.

Letâ€™s now also assume he fixed the â€œpersonalizedâ€ line and it felt unique an authentic and like he meant it. Just go with me.

2. Hereâ€™s the hardest part, the insight, just describing my situation. Well bro is cooked out the gate, because his insight is literally what I solve forâ€¦ so he has NO CHANCE.

3. A value prop of we save money is not nearly as good as â€œI already did something useful for you, want more?â€ Thatâ€™s what a true PVP would look like.

Personalized emails, no matter how well done, canâ€™t recover from poor lists. Thereâ€™s no message no universe where I would buy this.

If youâ€™re selling pregnancy test kits you should target women who go to fertility clinics monthly. 

Because no amount of amazing personalized messages will convince a gay man he should buy a pregnancy test.

Not to put too fine of a point on this, but if you manually inspect your list and you find someone that literally sells a variant of what you do, then your list sucks. And if your list sucks, your message has no chance.

You canâ€™t write your way out of a targeting problem, but you can target your way out of a pipeline problem.

The real question is, do you REALLY know who should and shouldnâ€™t buy and why? 

Answer that question first and the targeting and messaging will be easy, because itâ€™s just weeding out the bad prospects and describing to the good ones why they should receive your message.
